original: yadā vā paśyet parasyaapacaritāḥ kṣīṇā lubdhāḥ sva /cakra /stena /aṭavī /vyathitā vā prakṛtayaḥ svayam upajāpena vā mām eṣyanti /
analyzed: yadā vā paśyet parasya apacaritāḥ kṣīṇāḥ lubdhāḥ sva cakra stena aṭavī vyathitāḥ vā prakṛtayaḥ svayam upajāpena vā mām eṣyanti
translated: Or when he thinks that the subjects of the enemy are disaffected, impoverished, greedy, and that his own subjects are prosperous, or that they are harassed by thieves, wild tribes, and calamities, and that they will come over to him either of their own accord or through intrigue;

analyzed: sampannā me vārttā
translated: that his own trade is prosperous,

analyzed: vipannā parasya
translated: and that of the enemy is ruined;

analyzed: tasya prakṛtayaḥ durbhikṣa aupahatāḥ mām eṣyanti
translated: that the subjects of the enemy, being afflicted by famine, will come over to him;

analyzed: vipannā me vārttā
translated: that his own trade is ruined,

analyzed: sampannā parasya
translated: and that of the enemy is prosperous;

original: taṃ me prakṛtayo na gamiṣyanti /🔽vigṛhya caasya dhānya /paśu /hiraṇyāny āhariṣyāmi /
analyzed: tam me prakṛtayaḥ na gamiṣyanti  vigṛhya ca asya dhānya paśu hiraṇyāni āhariṣyāmi
translated: that his subjects will not go over to the enemy;🔽that he will be able to seize the grain, cattle, and gold of the enemy by waging war against him;

analyzed: sva paṇya aupaghātīni vā para paṇyāni nivartayiṣyāmi
translated: that he will be able to stop the sale of the goods of the enemy which are injurious to his own trade;

original: para /vaṇik /pathād vā saravanti mām eṣyanti vigṛhīte /
analyzed: para vaṇikpathāt vā mām eṣyanti vigṛhīte
translated: that the goods of the enemy will come to him through the channels of his own trade when the enemy is at war with others,

analyzed: na etaram
translated: but not to others;

analyzed: dūṣya amitra aṭavī nigraham vā vigṛhītaḥ na kariṣyati
translated: that he will not be able to suppress the disaffected, the enemies, and the wild tribes when at war;

analyzed: taiḥ eva vā vigraham prāpsyati
translated: or that he will be involved in war with them;

original: mitraṃ me mitra /bhāvy abhiprayāto bahv /alpa /kālaṃ tanu /kṣaya /vyayam arthaṃ prāpsyati /
analyzed: mitram me mitra bhāvī abhiprayātaḥ bahu alpa kālam tanu kṣaya vyayam artham prāpsyati
translated: that his friend who is marching against a friend of his will acquire much wealth in a short time, and that the loss of men and money will be small;

analyzed: guṇavatīm ādeyām vā bhūmim
translated: that he will acquire a piece of land which is good and salubrious;

original: sarva /saṃdohena vā mām anādṛtya prayātu /kāmaḥ kathaṃ na yāyād iti para /vṛddhi /pratighāta /arthaṃ pratāpa /arthaṃ ca vigṛhyaāsīta
analyzed: sarva saṃdohena vā mām an ādṛtya prayātu kāmaḥ katham na yāyāt iti para vṛddhi pratighāta artham pratāpa artham ca vigṛhya āsīta
translated: or he may march against the enemy without any regard for the combined power of all the enemies, thinking that the enemy will not march against him, in order to obstruct the growth of the enemy and to show his own prowess.

original: tam eva hi pratyāvṛtto grasate ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: tam eva hi pratyāvṛttaḥ grasate iti ācāryāḥ
translated: My teacher says that the conqueror will be swallowed by the very enemy against whom he has marched,

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says, No.

analyzed: karśana mātram asya kuryāt avyasaninaḥ
translated: He should only weaken the enemy who is not addicted to vices.

analyzed: para vṛddhyā tu vṛddhaḥ samucchedanam
translated: But when the enemy has grown in power by the growth of his people, he should be destroyed.

original: evaṃ parasya yātavyoasmai sāhāyyam avinaṣṭaḥ prayacchet //
analyzed: evam parasya sāhāyyam a vinaṣṭaḥ prayacchet
translated: Thus the enemy who is to be marched against will, without being destroyed, help the conqueror.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva saṃdoha prakṛtam vigṛhya āsīta
translated: Therefore, the conqueror should march against the combined power of all the enemies.

analyzed: vigṛhya āsana hetu prātilomye saṃdhāya āsīta
translated: When the causes of marching against the combined power of the enemies are reversed, he should make peace with them.

analyzed: vigṛhya āsana hetubhiḥ abhyuccitaḥ sarva saṃdoha varjam vigṛhya yāyāt
translated: When he is attacked by the causes of marching against the combined power of the enemies, he should march against them, leaving aside the combined power of all the enemies.

original: yadā vā paśyet vyasanī paraḥ /🔽prakṛti /vyasanaṃ vāasya śeeṣa /prakṛtibhir apratikāryam /
analyzed: yadā vā paśyet vyasanī paraḥ  prakṛti vyasanam vā asya śeeṣa prakṛtibhiḥ a pratikāryam
translated: Or when he finds that the enemy is addicted to vices,🔽or that the distress of the people of the enemy cannot be remedied by the remaining people,

original: sva /cakra /pīḍitā viraktā vāasya prakṛtayaḥ karśitā nirutsāhāḥ parasparād vā bhinnāḥ śakyā lobhayitum /
analyzed: sva cakra pīḍitāḥ viraktāḥ vā asya prakṛtayaḥ karśitāḥ nirutsāhāḥ parasparāt vā bhinnāḥ śakyāḥ lobhayitum
translated: or that the people of the enemy are oppressed by his own army, or are disaffected, or are weakened, or are dispirited, or are divided among themselves, and can be won over by gifts,

original: agny /udaka /vyādhi /maraka /durbhikṣa /nimittaṃ kṣīṇa /yugya /puruṣa /nicaya /rakṣā /vidhānaḥ paraḥ iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt //
analyzed: agni udaka vyādhi maraka durbhikṣa nimittam kṣīṇa yugya puruṣa nicaya rakṣā vidhānaḥ paraḥ iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt
translated: When he finds that his own army is strong and that of the enemy is weak, and that the time is suitable for the protection of his own army and for the destruction of the enemy, then he should march against the enemy after having made peace.

original: yadā vā paśyet mitram ākrandaś ca me śūra /vṛddha /anurakta /prakṛtiḥ /
analyzed: yadā vā paśyet mitram ākrandaḥ ca me śūra vṛddha anurakta prakṛtiḥ
translated: Or when he finds that his friend and his ally are powerful and that his own people are loyal to him,

original: viparīta /prakṛtiḥ paraḥ pārṣṇi /grāhaś caāsāraś ca /🔽śakṣyāmi mitreṇaāsāram ākrandena pārṣṇi /grāhaṃ vā vigṛhya yātum iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt //
analyzed: viparīta prakṛtiḥ paraḥ pārṣṇigrāhaḥ ca āsāraḥ ca  śakṣyāmi mitreṇa āsāram ākrandena pārṣṇigrāham vā vigṛhya yātum iti tadā vigṛhya yāyāt
translated: while the people of the enemy are disloyal, and that the rearenemy and the wild chief are also disloyal,🔽and that he can march against the rearenemy or the wild chief with the help of his friend and ally, then he should march against the enemy after having made peace.

original: yadā vā phalam eka /hāryam alpa /kālaṃ paśyet tadā pārṣṇi /grāha /āsārābhyāṃ vigṛhya yāyāt //
analyzed: yadā vā phalam eka hāryam alpa kālam paśyet tadā pārṣṇigrāha āsārābhyām vigṛhya yāyāt
translated: Or when he finds that the profit to be derived from the war is great and that the time is short, then he should march against the rearenemy and the wild chief after having made peace with them.

original: viparyaye saṃdhāya yāyāt //🔽yadā vā paśyet na śakyam ekena yātum avaśyaṃ ca yātavyam iti tadā sama /hīna /jyāyobhiḥ sāmavāyikaiḥ sambhūya yāyād /
analyzed: viparyaye saṃdhāya yāyāt  yadā vā paśyet na śakyam ekena yātum avaśyam ca yātavyam iti tadā sama hīna jyāyobhiḥ sāmavāyikaiḥ sambhūya yāyāt
translated: But when the reverse is the case, then he should march against the enemy after having made peace with them.🔽Or when he finds that he cannot march alone and that he must march, then he should march in combination with his equals, inferiors and superiors.

analyzed: ekatra nirdiṣṭena aṃśena  an ekatra a nirdiṣṭena aṃśena
translated: He should march with his equals after having assigned to them a share of the profit to be derived from the war.🔽He should march with his inferiors after having assigned to them a share of the profit to be derived from the war.

original: teṣām asamavāye daṇḍam anyatamasmān niviṣṭa /aṃśena yāceta //
analyzed: teṣām asamavāye daṇḍam anyatamasmāt niviṣṭa aṃśena yāceta
translated: When they are not in a position to combine, he should ask one of them to march with him after having assigned to him a share of the profit to be derived from the war.

analyzed: sambhūya abhigamanena vā nirviśyeta  dhruve lābhe nirdiṣṭena aṃśena
translated: or by a combination of these.🔽If the profit is certain, he should march with the share of profit fixed.

analyzed: adhruve lābha aṃśena
translated: If the profit is uncertain, he should march with the share of profit fixed.

analyzed: aṃśaḥ daṇḍa samaḥ pūrvaḥ prayāsa samaḥ uttamaḥ
translated: The first share of profit is equal to the share of the army; the second is equal to the share of the effort;

original: vilopo vā yathā /lābhaṃ prakṣepa /sama eva vā //E
analyzed: vilopaḥ vā yathālābham prakṣepasamaḥ eva vā e
translated: or it may be equal to the loss, or equal to the share of the capital.

original: yātavya /amitrayor abhigraha /cintāḥ kṣaya /lobha /virāga /hetavaḥ prakṛtīnāṃ sāmavāyika /viparimarśah🔽tulya /sāmanta /vyasane yātavyam amitraṃ vāity amitram abhiyāyāt /
analyzed: yātavya amitrayoḥ abhigraha cintāḥ kṣaya lobha virāga hetavaḥ prakṛtīnām sāmavāyika viparimarśaḥ  tulya sāmanta vyasane yātavyam amitram vā iti amitram abhiyāyāt
translated: The causes of the destruction, greed, and disaffection of the people are the consideration of the seizure of the enemy and the assailable enemy; the discussion of the allies and the neutrals.🔽When the enemy and the assailable enemy are equally strong, he should march against the enemy.

analyzed: tad siddhau yātavyam
translated: If he is successful against the enemy, he should march against the assailable enemy.

original: amitra /siddhau hi yātavyaḥ sāhāyyaṃ dadyān naamitro yātavya /siddhau //
analyzed: amitra siddhau hi yātavyaḥ sāhāyyam dadyāt na amitraḥ yātavya siddhau
translated: For if he is successful against the enemy, the assailable enemy will render him assistance, but not if he is successful against the assailable enemy.

original: guru /vyasanaṃ yātavyaṃ laghu /vyasanam amitraṃ vāiti guru /vyasanaṃ saukaryato yāyād ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: guru vyasanam yātavyam laghu vyasanam amitram vā aiti guru vyasanam saukaryataḥ yāyāt iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teacher says that he should march against the assailable enemy whose calamity is serious and whose resources are small, because it is easy to conquer him.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says, No.

original: laghu /vyasanam amitraṃ yāyāt //🔽laghv api hi vyasanam abhiyuktasya kṛcchraṃ bhavati //
analyzed: laghu vyasanam amitram yāyāt  laghu api hi vyasanam abhiyuktasya kṛcchram bhavati
translated: He should march against the enemy whose calamity is small.🔽For even a small calamity becomes serious when the enemy is attacked.

analyzed: satyam guru api gurutaram bhavati
translated: It is true that even a serious calamity becomes more serious.

original: anabhiyuktas tu laghu /vyasanaḥ sukhena vyasanaṃ pratikṛtyaamitro yātavyam abhisaret /
analyzed: an abhiyuktaḥ tu laghu vyasanaḥ sukhena vyasanam pratikṛtya amitraḥ yātavyam abhisaret
translated: But one who is not so engaged is light. When an enemy has easily removed his troubles, he should march against the enemy of the king who is marching against him.

analyzed: pārṣṇim vā gṛhṇīyāt
translated: Or he should seize the rear of the latter.

original: yātavya /yaugapadye guru /vyasanaṃ nyāya /vṛttiṃ laghu /vyasanam anyāya /vṛttiṃ virakta /prakṛtiṃ vāiti virakta /prakṛtiṃ yāyāt //
analyzed: yātavya yaugapadye guru vyasanam nyāya vṛttim laghu vyasanam anyāya vṛttim virakta prakṛtim vā aiti virakta prakṛtim yāyāt
translated: When the enemy of the king who is marching against him is equally troubled, he should march against that king whose troubles are serious and whose conduct is righteous, or against that whose troubles are light and whose conduct is unrighteous, or against that whose subjects are disaffected. He should march against that whose subjects are disaffected.

original: guru /vyasanaṃ nyāya /vṛttim abhiyuktaṃ prakṛtayoanugṛhṇanti /🔽laghu /vyasanam anyāya /vṛttim upekṣante /
analyzed: guru vyasanam nyāya vṛttim abhiyuktam prakṛtayaḥ anugṛhṇanti  laghu vyasanam anyāya vṛttim upekṣante
translated: The subjects follow that king whose troubles are serious and whose conduct is righteous, when he is attacked by an enemy.🔽They ignore that king whose troubles are light and whose conduct is unrighteous.

analyzed: viraktāḥ balavantam api ucchindanti
translated: But they destroy even a powerful king whose subjects are disaffected.

analyzed: tasmāt virakta prakṛtim eva yāyāt
translated: Therefore, he should march against that king whose subjects are disaffected.

analyzed: kṣīṇa lubdha prakṛtim apacarita prakṛtim vā aiti kṣīṇa lubdha prakṛtim yāyāt
translated: Or against that whose subjects are impoverished and greedy, or against that whose subjects are disaffected. He should march against that whose subjects are impoverished and greedy.

original: kṣīṇa /lubdhā hi prakṛtayaḥ sukhenaupajāpaṃ pīḍāṃ vāupagacchanti /
analyzed: kṣīṇa lubdhāḥ hi prakṛtayaḥ sukhena aupajāpam pīḍām vā aupagacchanti
translated: For the subjects who are impoverished and greedy easily submit to intrigue or to oppression.

analyzed: na apacaritāḥ pradhāna avagraha sādhyāḥ iti ācāryāḥ
translated: But not those who are disaffected. They can be won over only by the seizure of their chief men, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya.

original: kṣīṇa /lubdhā hi prakṛtayo bhartari snigdhā bhartṛ /hite tiṣṭhanti /
analyzed: kṣīṇa lubdhāḥ hi prakṛtayaḥ bhartari snigdhāḥ bhartṛ hite tiṣṭhanti
translated: For the subjects who are impoverished and greedy, being attached to their master, remain loyal to their master.

analyzed: upajāpam vā visaṃvādayanti
translated: or they cause the people to be disaffected.

analyzed: anurāge sārvaguṇyam iti
translated: When there is affection, all good qualities are present.

analyzed: tasmāt apacarita prakṛtim eva yāyāt
translated: Therefore, he should go to a people who are disaffected.

original: balavantam anyāya /vṛttiṃ durbalaṃ vā nyāya /vṛttim iti balavantam anyāya /vṛttiṃ yāyāt //
analyzed: balavantam anyāya vṛttim durbalam vā nyāya vṛttim iti balavantam anyāya vṛttim yāyāt
translated: Whether a powerful king who acts unjustly or a weak king who acts justly, he should go to a powerful king who acts unjustly.

analyzed: balavantam anyāya vṛttim abhiyuktam prakṛtayaḥ na anugṛhṇanti
translated: When a powerful king who acts unjustly is attacked, the people do not support him.

analyzed: niṣpātayanti
translated: They overthrow him.

analyzed: amitram vā aasya bhajante
translated: Or they serve his enemy.

original: durbalaṃ tu nyāya /vṛttim abhiyuktaṃ prakṛtayaḥ parigṛhṇanti /
analyzed: durbalam tu nyāya vṛttim abhiyuktam prakṛtayaḥ parigṛhṇanti
translated: But when a weak king who acts justly is attacked, the people support him.

original: anuniṣpatanti vā //🔽avakṣepeṇa hi satām asatāṃ pragraheṇa ca /
analyzed: anuniṣpatanti vā  avakṣepeṇa hi satām asatām pragraheṇa ca
translated: Or they follow him.🔽For the virtuous, by the removal of the virtuous and the promotion of the wicked,

original: abhūtānāṃ ca hiṃsānām adharmyāṇāṃ pravartanaiḥ //🔽ucitānāṃ caritrāṇāṃ dharmiṣṭhānāṃ nivartanaiḥ /
analyzed: abhūtānām ca hiṃsānām adharmyāṇām pravartanaiḥ  ucitānām caritrāṇām dharmiṣṭhānām nivartanaiḥ
translated: and by the instigation of unrighteous and unjust violence against the innocent,🔽and by the cessation of righteous and proper conduct,

analyzed: adharmasya prasaṅgena dharmasya avagraheṇa ca
translated: and by the spread of unrighteousness and the suppression of righteousness,

original: akāryāṇāṃ ca karaṇaiḥ kāryāṇāṃ ca praṇāśanaiḥ /
analyzed: akāryāṇām ca karaṇaiḥ kāryāṇām ca praṇāśanaiḥ
translated: and by the doing of what should not be done and the neglect of what should be done,

original: apradānaiś ca deyānām adeyānāṃ ca sādhanaiḥ //
analyzed: apradānaiḥ ca deyānām adeyānām ca sādhanaiḥ
translated: and by the withholding of what should be given and the giving of what should not be given,

original: adaṇḍanaiś ca daṇḍyānām adaṇḍyānāṃ ca daṇḍanaiḥ /
analyzed: a daṇḍanaiḥ ca daṇḍyānām a daṇḍyānām ca daṇḍanaiḥ
translated: and by the non-punishment of those who deserve punishment and the punishment of those who do not deserve punishment,

analyzed: agrāhyāṇām upagrāhaiḥ grāhyāṇām ca anabhigrahaiḥ
translated: by seizing those who should not be seized and by not seizing those who should be seized;

original: anarthyānāṃ ca karaṇair arthyānāṃ ca vighātanaiḥ /
analyzed: anarthyānām ca karaṇaiḥ arthyānām ca vighātanaiḥ
translated: by employing those who are not fit for employment and by obstructing those who are fit for employment;

original: arakṣaṇaiś ca corebhyaḥ svayaṃ ca parimoṣaṇaiḥ //
analyzed: arakṣaṇaiḥ ca corebhyaḥ svayam ca parimoṣaṇaiḥ
translated: by not protecting from thieves and by plundering oneself;

original: pātaiḥ puruṣa /kārāṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ guṇa /dūṣaṇaiḥ /🔽upaghātaiḥ pradhānānāṃ mānyānāṃ caavamānanaiḥ //
analyzed: pātaiḥ puruṣakārāṇām karmaṇām guṇa dūṣaṇaiḥ  upaghātaiḥ pradhānānām mānyānām ca avamānanaiḥ
translated: by the failure of human efforts and by the corruption of the qualities of actions;🔽by the destruction of the chief men and by the dishonoring of the respectable;

analyzed: virodhanaiḥ ca vṛddhānām vaiṣamyeṇa anṛtena ca
translated: by the obstruction of the elders and by inequality and untruth;

analyzed: kṛtasya a pratikāreṇa sthitasya akaraṇena ca
translated: by not retaliating for what is done and by not doing what is to be done;

original: rājñaḥ pramāda /ālasyābhyāṃ yoga /kṣema /vadhena vā /🔽prakṛtīnāṃ kṣayo lobho vairāgyaṃ caupajāyate //
analyzed: rājñaḥ pramāda ālasyābhyām yogakṣema vadhena vā  prakṛtīnām kṣayaḥ lobhaḥ vairāgyam ca upajāyate
translated: by the king's negligence and laziness, or by the destruction of his wealth and security;🔽the people suffer loss, greed, and disaffection.

original: kṣīṇāḥ prakṛtayo lobhaṃ lubdhā yānti virāgatām /
analyzed: kṣīṇāḥ prakṛtayaḥ lobham lubdhāḥ yānti virāga tām
translated: The people, when impoverished, become greedy; when greedy, they become disaffected;

original: viraktā yānty amitraṃ vā bhartāraṃ ghnanti vā svayam //
analyzed: viraktāḥ yānti amitram vā bhartāram ghnanti vā svayam
translated: when disaffected, they either go over to the enemy or kill their own master.

analyzed: tasmāt prakṛtīnām kṣaya lobha virāga kāraṇāni na utpādayet
translated: Therefore, one should not cause the loss, greed, or disaffection of the people.

analyzed: utpannāni vā sadyas pratikurvīta
translated: Or, if they arise, one should immediately counteract them.

original: kṣīṇā lubdhā viraktā vā prakṛtaya iti //
analyzed: kṣīṇāḥ lubdhāḥ viraktāḥ vā prakṛtayaḥ iti
translated: The people are impoverished, greedy, or disaffected.

original: kṣīṇāḥ pīḍana /ucchedana /bhayāt sadyaḥ saṃdhiṃ yuddhaṃ niṣpatanaṃ vā rocayante //
analyzed: kṣīṇāḥ pīḍana aucchedana bhayāt sadyas saṃdhim yuddham niṣpatanam vā rocayante
translated: when they are oppressed, they immediately prefer peace, war or flight, out of fear of destruction.

analyzed: lubdhāḥ lobhena asaṃtuṣṭāḥ para aupajāpam lipsante
translated: When they are greedy, they are discontented and seek to be won over by others.

original: viraktāḥ para /abhiyogam abhyuttiṣṭhante //🔽tāsāṃ hiraṇya /dhānya /kṣayaḥ sarva /upaghātī kṛcchra /pratīkāraś ca /
analyzed: viraktāḥ para abhiyogam abhyuttiṣṭhante  tāsām hiraṇya dhānya kṣayaḥ sarva aupaghātī kṛcchra pratīkāraḥ ca
translated: When they are disaffected, they rise against their master.🔽The loss of gold and grain of the people is harmful to all and is difficult to remedy.
The loss of the king’s army and men can be remedied by gold and grain.

original: lobha aikadeśiko mukhya /āyattaḥ para /artheṣu śakyaḥ pratihantum ādātuṃ vā //
analyzed: lobhaḥ aikadeśikaḥ mukhya āyattaḥ para artheṣu śakyaḥ pratihantum ādātum vā
translated: Greed is partial, depends on the chief, and can be prevented or taken away in regard to the wealth of others.
Disaffection can be remedied by the control of the chief.

original: niṣpradhānā hi prakṛtayo bhogyā bhavanty anupajāpyāś caanyeṣām /
analyzed: niṣpradhānāḥ hi prakṛtayaḥ bhogyāḥ bhavanti an upajāpyāḥ ca anyeṣām
translated: For, when the people are deprived of their chief, they become easy to govern and cannot be won over by others.

original: anāpat /sahās tu //🔽prakṛti /mukhya /pragrahais tu bahudhā bhinnā guptā bhavanty āpat /sahāś ca //
analyzed: anāpad sahāḥ tu  prakṛti mukhya pragrahaiḥ tu bahudhā bhinnāḥ guptāḥ bhavanti āpad sahāḥ ca
translated: But they cannot bear calamities.🔽But when they are divided by the king and the chief, they become protected and can bear calamities.

original: sāmavāyikānām api saṃdhi /vigraha /kāraṇāny avekṣya śakti /śauca /yuktaiḥ sambhūya yāyāt //
analyzed: sāmavāyikānām api saṃdhi vigraha kāraṇāni avekṣya śakti śauca yuktaiḥ sambhūya yāyāt
translated: Even in the case of confederates, one should march with them after considering the causes of peace and war, and after uniting with those who are powerful and pure.

original: śaktimān hi pārṣṇi /grahaṇe yātrā /sāhāyya /dāne vā śaktaḥ /
analyzed: śaktimān hi pārṣṇigrahaṇe yātrā sāhāyya dāne vā śaktaḥ
translated: for a king who is powerful can help in capturing the rear of the enemy, in marching against him, and in giving assistance.

analyzed: śuciḥ siddhau ca asiddhau ca yathāsthita kārī iti
translated: A king who is pure in conduct will act as he is, whether the expedition is successful or not.

original: teṣāṃ jyāyasāekena dvābhyāṃ samābhyāṃ vā sambhūya yātavyam iti dvābhyāṃ samābhyāṃ śreyaḥ //
analyzed: teṣām jyāyasā ekena dvābhyām samābhyām vā sambhūya yātavyam iti dvābhyām samābhyām śreyaḥ
translated: Of these, it is better to march in alliance with one who is superior or with two who are equal.

original: jyāyasā hy avagṛhītaś carati /🔽samābhyām atisaṃdhāna /ādhikye vā //
analyzed: jyāyasā hi avagṛhītaḥ carati  samābhyām atisaṃdhāna ādhikye vā
translated: For, when one is superior, he marches, being held in check by the other;

original: tau hi sukhau bhedayitum /🔽duṣṭaś caeko dvābhyāṃ niyantuṃ bheda /upagrahaṃ caupagantum iti //
analyzed: tau hi sukhau bhedayitum  duṣṭaḥ ca ekaḥ dvābhyām niyantum bheda aupagraham ca aupagantum iti
translated: and when they are equal, he is held in check by both, or he may be able to win over one of them.🔽For it is easy to break up a combination of two kings.🔽And it is easy to control one who is wicked by means of two, and to win over one of them to one's side by breaking up the combination.

original: samenaekena dvābhyāṃ hīnābhyāṃ vāiti dvābhyāṃ hīnābhyāṃ śreyaḥ //
analyzed: samena ekena dvābhyām hīnābhyām vā iti dvābhyām hīnābhyām śreyaḥ
translated: Of these, it is better to march in alliance with one who is equal or with two who are inferior.

original: tau hi dvi /kārya /sādhakau vaśyau ca bhavataḥ //
analyzed: tau hi dvi kārya sādhakau vaśyau ca bhavataḥ
translated: For they will accomplish two tasks and will be under control.

original: kārya /siddhau tu kṛta /arthāj jyāyaso gūḍhaḥ sa /apadeśam apasravet /
analyzed: kārya siddhau tu kṛtaarthāt jyāyasaḥ gūḍhaḥ sa apadeśam apasravet
translated: But when the task is accomplished, he should secretly slip away from one who is superior, under some pretext, taking with him the treasure.

analyzed: aśuceḥ śuci vṛttāt tu pratīkṣeta ā visarjanāt
translated: But from one who is pure in conduct, though impure himself, he should wait till he is dismissed.

original: sattrād apasared yattaḥ kalatram apanīya vā /
analyzed: sattrāt apasaret yattaḥ kalatram apanīya vā
translated: He should secretly slip away from a sattra, taking with him his wives and wealth.

original: samād api hi labdha /arthād viśvas tasya bhayaṃ bhavet //
analyzed: samāt api hi labdha arthāt viśvaḥ tasya bhayam bhavet
translated: For even from one who is equal, he may get wealth, and then he will be in danger from him.

analyzed: jyāyaḥ tve ca api labdha arthaḥ samaḥ api parikalpate
translated: Even when the share is more, the king should accept an equal share, if it is offered.

original: abhyuccitaś caaviśvāsyo vṛddhiś citta /vikāriṇī //🔽viśiṣṭād alpam apy aṃśaṃ labdhvā tuṣṭa /mukho vrajet /
analyzed: abhyuccitaḥ ca aviśvāsyaḥ vṛddhiḥ citta vikāriṇī  viśiṣṭāt alpam api aṃśam labdhvā tuṣṭa mukhaḥ vrajet
translated: A share that is more than one’s due is not to be accepted, as it causes distrust. Interest causes mental disturbance.🔽Having obtained even a small share from a superior, the king should go away with a pleased face.

original: anaṃśo vā tatoasyaaṅke prahṛtya dvi /guṇaṃ haret //
analyzed: an aṃśaḥ vā tatoasya aṅke prahṛtya dviguṇam haret
translated: Or, if he has no share, he should strike the other on his lap and take twice the amount.

original: kṛta /arthas tu svayaṃ netā visṛjet sāmavāyikān /
analyzed: kṛtaarthaḥ tu svayam netā visṛjet sāmavāyikān
translated: But the king who has accomplished his purpose should dismiss his allies.

original: api jīyeta na jayen maṇḍala /iṣṭas tathā bhavet //E
analyzed: api jīyeta na jayet maṇḍala eṣṭaḥ tathā bhavet
translated: Even if defeated, he should not be conquered, and should remain as a friend of the circle.

analyzed: saṃhita prayāṇikam paripaṇita a paripaṇita apasṛtāḥ saṃdhayaḥ
translated: Alliances for joint expeditions, for mutual help, and for secret departure are the three types of alliances.

analyzed: vijigīṣuḥ dvitīyām prakṛtim evam atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: The conqueror should form an alliance with the second party in this way.

original: sāmantaṃ saṃhita /prayāṇe yojayet tvam ito yāhi /
analyzed: sāmantam saṃhita prayāṇe yojayet tvam itas yāhi
translated: He should engage the neighboring king in a joint expedition, saying, “You go from here.

analyzed: aham itas yāsyāmi  samānaḥ lābhaḥ iti
translated: I will go from here.🔽The profit will be equal.”

analyzed: lābha sāmye saṃdhiḥ
translated: If the profit is equal, there is peace.

analyzed: vaiṣamye vikramaḥ
translated: If it is unequal, there is war.

analyzed: saṃdhiḥ paripaṇitaḥ ca a paripaṇitaḥ ca
translated: There are two types of peace: mutual help and secret departure.

analyzed: tvam etam deśam yāhi
translated: “You go to that country.

original: aham imaṃ deśaṃ yāsyāmi iti paripaṇita /deśaḥ //
analyzed: aham imam deśam yāsyāmi iti paripaṇita deśaḥ
translated: I will go to this country.” This is a peace with a specified place.

analyzed: tvam etāvantam kālam ceṣṭasva
translated: “You act for this much time.

original: aham etāvantaṃ kālaṃ ceṣṭiṣye iti paripaṇita /kālaḥ //
analyzed: aham etāvantam kālam ceṣṭiṣye iti paripaṇita kālaḥ
translated: He has fixed a time, thinking, ‘I will strive for this much time.’

analyzed: tvam etāvat kāryam sādhaya

original: aham idaṃ kāryaṃ sādhayiṣyāmi iti paripaṇita /arthaḥ //
analyzed: aham idam kāryam sādhayiṣyāmi iti paripaṇita arthaḥ

analyzed: yadi vā manyeta śaila vana nadī durgam aṭavī vyavahitam chinna dhānya puruṣa vīvadha āsāram
translated: Or if he thinks that the enemy will go to a place that is difficult to reach due to mountains, forests, rivers, forts, or wildernesses, that is cut off from grain, men, fodder, and water,

original: ayavasa /indhana /udakam avijñātaṃ prakṛṣṭam anya /bhāva /deśīyaṃ vā sainya /vyāyāmānām
analyzed: a yava saindhana audakam a vijñātam prakṛṣṭam anya bhāva deśīyam vā sainya vyāyāmānām
translated: that is unknown, far away, or in a different region, that is not suitable for military exercises,

analyzed: a labdha bhaumam vā deśam paras yāsyati
translated: or that is not a place that can be obtained,

original: viparītam aham ity etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita /deśaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
analyzed: viparītam aham iti etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita deśam saṃdhim upeyāt
translated: then, thinking ‘I am different in this particular way,’ he should make peace with a fixed place.

original: yadi vā manyeta pravarṣa /uṣṇa /śītam ativyādhi /prāyam upakṣīṇa /āhāra /upabhogaṃ
analyzed: yadi vā manyeta pravarṣa oṣṇa śītam ati vyādhi prāyam upakṣīṇa āhāra aupabhogam
translated: Or if he thinks that the enemy will strive for a time that is excessive for rain, heat, cold, diseases, and the consumption of food and drink,

analyzed: sainya vyāyāmānām ca auparodhikam kārya sādhanānām ūnam atiriktam vā kālam paraḥ ceṣṭiṣyate
translated: that is deficient or excessive for accomplishing tasks and for military exercises,

original: viparītam aham ity etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita /kālaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
analyzed: viparītam aham iti etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita kālam saṃdhim upeyāt
translated: then, thinking ‘I am different in this particular way,’ he should make peace with a fixed time.

original: yadi vā manyeta pratyādeyaṃ prakṛti /kopakaṃ dīrgha /kālaṃ mahā /kṣaya /vyayam
analyzed: yadi vā manyeta pratyādeyam prakṛti kopakam dīrgha kālam mahā kṣaya vyayam
translated: If he thinks that the enemy will accomplish a task which is disagreeable, which will enrage his own people, which will last for a long time, which will cause great loss of men and money,

original: alpam anartha /anubandham akalyam adharmyaṃ madhyama /udāsīna /viruddhaṃ mitra /upaghātakaṃ🔽vā kāryaṃ paraḥ sādhayiṣyati /
analyzed: alpam anartha anubandham akalyam adharmyam madhyama audāsīna viruddham mitra aupaghātakam  vā kāryam paraḥ sādhayiṣyati
translated: which will be of little consequence, which will be followed by evil, which is improper, which is against morality, which will displease his friends in the middle and neutral countries, and which will be injurious to his friends,

original: viparītam aham ity etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita /arthaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
analyzed: viparītam aham iti etasmin viśeṣe paripaṇita artham saṃdhim upeyāt
translated: while he himself will accomplish the opposite, then he should make peace on the condition of receiving a stipulated amount of money.

original: evaṃ deśa /kālayoḥ kāla /kāryayor deśa /kāryayor deśa /kāla /kāryāṇāṃ caavasthāpanāt sapta /vidhaḥ paripaṇitaḥ //
analyzed: evam deśa kālayoḥ kāla kāryayoḥ deśa kāryayoḥ deśa kāla kāryāṇām ca avasthāpanāt saptavidhaḥ paripaṇitaḥ
translated: Thus, peace is of seven kinds, according to the fixing of place and time, time and object, place and object, and place, time and object.

original: tasmin prāg evaārabhya pratiṣṭhāpya ca sva /karmāṇi para /karmasu vikrameta //
analyzed: tasmin prāk eva ārabhya pratiṣṭhāpya ca sva karmāṇi para karmasu vikrameta
translated: Even before the conclusion of peace, he should begin to establish his own works and then proceed to undertake the works of the enemy.

original: vyasana /tvara /avamāna /ālasya /yuktam ajñaṃ vā śatrum atisaṃdhātu /kāmo🔽deśa /kāla /kāryāṇām anavasthāpanāt saṃhitau svaḥ iti saṃdhi /viśvāsena parac /chidram
analyzed: vyasana tvarā avamāna ālasya yuktam ajñam vā śatrum atisaṃdhātu kāmaḥ  deśa kāla kāryāṇām anavasthāpanāt saṃhitau svaḥ iti saṃdhi viśvāsena para chidram
translated: If he desires to destroy an enemy who is addicted to vices, who is hasty, who is despised, who is idle, or who is ignorant,🔽he should not fix the place, time and object of the peace, but should make peace on the condition of receiving a stipulated amount of money.

analyzed: āsādya praharet iti a paripaṇitaḥ
translated: Then, having obtained an opportunity in the enemy's country, he should strike. This is unfixed peace.🔽Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translation updated to match the Sanskrit:

analyzed: tatra etat bhavati
translated: Here is the corrected and aligned text:

analyzed: sāmantena eva sāmantam vidvān āyojya vigrahe
translated: The wise king, having made an alliance with a neighbouring king, should engage in war.

original: tatoanyasya hared bhūmiṃ chittvā pakṣaṃ samantataḥ //🔽saṃdher akṛta /cikīrṣā kṛta /śleṣaṇaṃ kṛta /vidūṣaṇam avaśīrṇa /kriyā ca //
analyzed: tatas anyasya haret bhūmim chittvā pakṣam samantataḥ  saṃdheḥ a kṛta cikīrṣā kṛta śleṣaṇam kṛta vidūṣaṇam avaśīrṇa kriyā ca
translated: Then he should seize the land of another, having cut off a wing all around.🔽The desire to make peace, the desire to make an alliance, the desire to create disaffection, and the desire to break an alliance.

analyzed: vikramasya prakāśa yuddham kūṭa yuddham tūṣṇīṃyuddham
translated: The display of valour, open war, secret war, and silent war.

analyzed: iti saṃdhi vikramau
translated: Thus, peace and war.

original: apūrvasya saṃdheḥ sa /anubandhaiḥ sāma /ādibhiḥ paryeṣaṇaṃ sama /hīna /jyāyasāṃ ca yathā /balam avasthāpanam akṛta /cikīrṣā //
analyzed: apūrvasya saṃdheḥ sa anubandhaiḥ sāma ādibhiḥ paryeṣaṇam sama hīna jyāyasām ca yathābalam avasthāpanam akṛta cikīrṣā
translated: The search for a new alliance with the means such as conciliation, etc., and the establishment of equality, inferiority, and superiority according to strength, without the desire to act.

original: kṛtasya priya /hitābhyām ubhayataḥ paripālanaṃ yathā /sambhāṣitasya ca nibandhanasyaanuvartanaṃ rakṣaṇaṃ ca kathaṃ parasmān na
analyzed: kṛtasya priya hitābhyām ubhayatas paripālanam yathā sambhāṣitasya ca nibandhanasya anuvartanam rakṣaṇam ca katham parasmāt na
translated: The protection of both sides through affection and benefit of the made alliance, the continuation and protection of the made agreement as spoken, and how it should not be broken with the other.

original: bhidyeta iti kṛta /śleṣaṇam //🔽parasyaapasaṃdheyatāṃ dūṣya /atisaṃdhānena sthāpayitvā vyatikramaḥ kṛta /vidūṣaṇam //
analyzed: bhidyeta iti kṛta śleṣaṇam  parasya apasaṃdheya tām dūṣya atisaṃdhānena sthāpayitvā vyatikramaḥ kṛta vidūṣaṇam
translated: Thus, the desire to make an alliance.🔽Having established the unalliable nature of the enemy through the disaffection and excessive alliance of the disaffected, the transgression is the desire to break an alliance.

original: bhṛtyena mitreṇa vā doṣa /apasṛtena pratisaṃdhānam avaśīrṇa /kriyā //
analyzed: bhṛtyena mitreṇa vā doṣa apasṛtena pratisaṃdhānam avaśīrṇa kriyā
translated: The re-establishment of the servant or friend who has escaped due to faults is the desire to break an alliance.

analyzed: tasyām gataāgataḥ caturvidhaḥ kāraṇāt
translated: He who has gone and returned for four reasons is one who has gone and returned for a reason.

analyzed: viparītaḥ
translated: The opposite.

analyzed: kāraṇāt gataḥ akāraṇāt āgataḥ
translated: He who has gone for a reason and returned without a reason.

analyzed: viparītaḥ ca eti
translated: And the opposite.

original: svāmino doṣeṇa gato guṇenaāgataḥ parasya guṇena gato doṣeṇaāgata iti kāraṇād gata /āgataḥ saṃdheyaḥ //
analyzed: svāminaḥ doṣeṇa gataḥ guṇena āgataḥ parasya guṇena gataḥ doṣeṇa āgataḥ iti kāraṇāt gata āgataḥ saṃdheyaḥ
translated: He who has gone for a reason and returned for a reason should be reconciled, having gone because of the king's fault and returned because of his good qualities, or having gone because of the enemy's good qualities and returned because of his faults.

original: sva /doṣeṇa gata /āgato guṇam ubhayoḥ parityajya akāraṇād gata /āgataḥ cala /buddhir asaṃdheyaḥ //
analyzed: sva doṣeṇa gata āgataḥ guṇam ubhayoḥ parityajya akāraṇāt gata āgataḥ cala buddhiḥ asaṃdheyaḥ
translated: He who has gone and returned because of his own faults, abandoning the good qualities of both, having gone and returned without a reason, is of fickle mind and should not be reconciled.

original: svāmino doṣeṇa gataḥ parasmāt sva /doṣeṇaāgata iti kāraṇād gatoakāraṇād āgataḥ tarkayitavyaḥ para /prayuktaḥ svena vā doṣeṇaapakartu /kāmaḥ /

translated: He who has gone because of the king's faults and returned because of his own faults should be suspected of having gone for a reason and returned without a reason, being employed by the enemy or wishing to do harm because of his own faults.

original: parasyaucchettāram amitraṃ me jñātvā pratighāta /bhayād āgataḥ /

analyzed: param vā mām ucchettu kāmam parityajya ānṛśaṃsyāt āgataḥ iti

analyzed: anyathā buddhim apakṛṣṭam vāsayet

original: sva /doṣeṇa gataḥ para /doṣeṇaāgata ity akāraṇād gataḥ kāraṇād āgataḥ tarkayitavyaḥ chidraṃ me pūrayiṣyati /

translated: If he has gone due to his own fault and come due to the fault of others, he should be examined whether he has gone without reason and come with reason, thinking that he will fill my gap.

translated: The teachers say that the grounds for abandoning an ally are: destruction of what has been done, loss of power, selling one's knowledge, despair due to hope, restlessness in one's own country, lack of confidence, or going to war with a powerful enemy.

analyzed: parasya vārayiṣyati
translated: He will ward off those of the enemy.

original: bahv /ābādhe me pathi kaṇṭakān mardayiṣyati /🔽durga /aṭavy /apasāreṣu daṇḍena cariṣyati /
analyzed: bahu ābādhe me pathi kaṇṭakān mardayiṣyati  durga aṭa vyapasāreṣu daṇḍena cariṣyati
translated: He will crush the thorns on my path in a place with many obstacles.🔽He will march with his army on the impassable roads, in the forts, and in the wilderness.

original: yātavyam aviṣahye doṣe saṃdhau vā sthāpayiṣyati /
analyzed: yātavyam aviṣahye doṣe saṃdhau vā sthāpayiṣyati
translated: He will place the one I am at war with in a situation where he cannot bear the fault, or in a treaty.

original: labdha /lābha /aṃśo vā śatrūn anyān me viśvāsayiṣyati iti //
analyzed: labdha lābha aṃśaḥ vā śatrūn anyān me viśvāsayiṣyati iti
translated: Or having obtained a share of the profit, he will win over other enemies for me.

original: dvaidhī /bhūto vā kośena daṇḍaṃ daṇḍena kośaṃ sāmantānām anyatamāl lipseta //
analyzed: dvaidhībhūtaḥ vā kośena daṇḍam daṇḍena kośam sāmantānām anyatamāt lipseta
translated: Or having divided himself in two, he should seek to obtain an army with his treasury, and a treasury with his army from one of the neighboring kings.

original: teṣāṃ jyāyasoadhikenaaṃśena samāt samena hīnādd hīnenaiti sama /saṃdhiḥ //
analyzed: teṣām jyāyasaḥ adhikena aṃśena samāt samena hīnāt hīnena eti sama saṃdhiḥ
translated: He should obtain more than the greater, the same as the equal, and less than the lesser. This is a treaty of equality.

analyzed: viparyaye viṣama saṃdhiḥ
translated: The reverse of this is called an unequal peace.

analyzed: tayoḥ viśeṣa lābhāt atisaṃdhiḥ
translated: When one of them gains an advantage over the other, it is called a very unequal peace.

original: vyasaninam apāya /sthāne saktam anarthinaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno bala /samena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: vyasaninam apāya sthāne saktam anarthinam vā jyāyāṃsam hīnaḥ bala samena lābhena paṇeta
translated: When a powerful king is in distress, or is engaged in an unprofitable undertaking, or is not desirous of war, then a weak king may challenge him to war, offering him a small gain.

analyzed: paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: If the powerful king is able to retaliate, he may declare war.

original: anyathā saṃdadhyāt //🔽evaṃ /bhūto vā hīna /śakti /pratāpa /pūraṇa /arthaṃ sambhāvya /artha /abhisārī mūla /pārṣṇi /trāṇa /arthaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno bala /samād viśiṣṭena
analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt  evaṃbhūtaḥ vā hīna śakti pratāpa pūraṇa artham sambhāvya artha abhisārī mūlapārṣṇi trāṇa artham vā jyāyāṃsam hīnaḥ bala samāt viśiṣṭena
translated: Otherwise he may make peace.

analyzed: lābhena paṇeta
translated: A weak king, who is in the same position as the powerful king, may challenge the latter to war, offering him a greater gain than what he is getting from his ally, for the purpose of filling his treasury and arousing his people, or for the purpose of securing the services of the powerful king for the protection of his rear and the root of his kingdom.

analyzed: paṇitaḥ kalyāṇa buddhim anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: If the powerful king accepts the challenge, he may show his good will to the weak king.

analyzed: anyathā vikrameta
translated: Otherwise he may declare war.

original: jāta /vyasana /prakṛti /randhram upasthita /anarthaṃ vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīno durga /mitra /pratiṣṭabdho
analyzed: jāta vyasana prakṛti randhram upasthita anartham vā jyāyāṃsam hīnaḥ durga mitra pratiṣṭabdhaḥ
translated: A weak king, who is in distress, or whose resources are exhausted, or who is threatened with danger, may challenge a powerful king to war, offering him a small gain, if he is protected by forts and friends,

original: vā hrasvam adhvānaṃ yātu /kāmaḥ śatrum ayuddham eka /anta /siddhiṃ vā lābham ādātu /kāmo
analyzed: vā hrasvam adhvānam yātu kāmaḥ śatrum ayuddham ekaanta siddhim vā lābham ādātu kāmaḥ
translated: or if he is desirous of marching a short distance, or if he is desirous of taking an enemy by surprise, or of obtaining a certain gain without war, from a powerful king who is equal to him in strength.

original: bala /samādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta //🔽paṇitas tasyaapakāra /samartho vikrameta /
analyzed: bala samāt hīnena lābhena paṇeta  paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: If the powerful king is able to retaliate, he may declare war.

analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt
translated: Otherwise he may make peace.

original: arandhra /vyasano vā jyāyān dur /ārabdha /karmāṇaṃ bhūyaḥ kṣaya /vyayābhyāṃ🔽yoktu /kāmo dūṣya /daṇḍaṃ pravāsayitu /kāmo dūṣya /daṇḍam āvāhayitu /kāmo vā pīḍanīyam🔽ucchedanīyaṃ vā hīnena vyathayitu /kāmaḥ saṃdhi /pradhāno vā kalyāṇa /buddhir hīnaṃ
analyzed: arandhra vyasanaḥ vā jyāyān durārabdha karmāṇam bhūyas kṣaya vyayābhyām  yoktu kāmaḥ dūṣya daṇḍam pravāsayitu kāmaḥ dūṣya daṇḍam āvāhayitu kāmaḥ vā pīḍanīyam  ucchedanīyam vā hīnena vyathayitu kāmaḥ saṃdhi pradhānaḥ vā kalyāṇa buddhiḥ hīnam
translated: or one who is free from serious vices, should, if he wishes to employ his enemy, who has undertaken a difficult task, in further destruction and loss,🔽or if he wishes to banish his enemy who is subject to punishment, or to bring him over to his side, or if he wishes to afflict his enemy who is to be oppressed or destroyed, or if he is of a friendly disposition and values peace, should accept a small gain from his enemy.

analyzed: lābham pratigṛhṇīyāt  kalyāṇa buddhinā sambhūya artham lipseta
translated: If he is of a friendly disposition, he should seek wealth in combination with his enemy.

analyzed: anyathā vikrameta
translated: Otherwise, he should show his prowess.

original: evaṃ samaḥ samam atisaṃdadhyād anugṛhṇīyād vā //🔽para /anīkasya pratyanīkaṃ mitra /aṭavīnāṃ vā /
analyzed: evam samaḥ samam atisaṃdadhyāt anugṛhṇīyāt vā  para anīkasya pratyanīkam mitra aṭavīnām vā
translated: Thus, an equal king should either combine with an equal king or favour him.🔽The counter-force of the enemy's army, or the forces of allies and wild tribes,

original: śatror vibhūmīnāṃ deśikaṃ mūla /pārṣṇi /trāṇa /arthaṃ vā samo bala /samena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: śatroḥ vibhūmīnām deśikam mūlapārṣṇi trāṇa artham vā samaḥ bala samena lābhena paṇeta
translated: or a guide to the enemy's country, or for the protection of the rear and the base, an equal king should make an agreement with an equal king for a gain equal to his own strength.

analyzed: paṇitaḥ kalyāṇa buddhim anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: When the agreement is made, he should favour the friendly king.

analyzed: anyathā vikrameta
translated: Otherwise, he should show his prowess.

original: jāta /vyasana /prakṛti /randhram aneka /viruddham anyato labhamāno vā samo bala /samādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: jāta vyasana prakṛti randhram aneka viruddham anyatas labhamānaḥ vā samaḥ hīnena lābhena paṇeta
translated: Or, if the enemy's constitution is full of vices and weaknesses, and is opposed by many, and is getting help from elsewhere, an equal king should make an agreement with an inferior king for a gain less than his own strength.

analyzed: paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: If he is able to retaliate against the enemy, he may make an alliance with him.

analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt
translated: Otherwise, he may make peace with him.

original: evaṃ /bhūto vā samaḥ sāmanta /āyatta /kāryaḥ kartavya /balo vā bala /samād viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: evaṃbhūtaḥ vā samaḥ sāmanta āyatta kāryaḥ kartavya balaḥ vā bala samāt viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta
translated: Or, if he is in such a position that he can accomplish his purpose with the help of his neighbour, or if he is strong enough to make an alliance with a stronger king, he may make an alliance with him on the condition of receiving more than what he deserves.

original: paṇitaḥ kalyāṇa /buddhim anugṛhṇīyāt anyathā vikrameta //🔽jāta /vyasana /prakṛti /randhram abhihantu /kāmaḥ sv /ārabdham eka /anta /siddhiṃ
analyzed: paṇitaḥ kalyāṇa buddhim anugṛhṇīyāt anyathā vikrameta  jāta vyasana prakṛti randhram abhihantu kāmaḥ su ārabdham ekaanta siddhim
translated: If the enemy is of good disposition, he may be won over by gifts; otherwise he may be attacked.

original: vāasya karma /upahantu /kāmo mūle yātrāyāṃ vā prahartu /kāmo yātavyād /bhūyo labhamāno
analyzed: vā asya karma aupahantu kāmaḥ mūle yātrāyām vā prahartu kāmaḥ yātavyāt bhūyaḥ labhamānaḥ
translated: If the enemy is in a bad condition, or if his natural resources are weak, or if he is desirous of attacking another, or if he is desirous of destroying the work of his enemy, or if he is desirous of striking at the root of his enemy or on his march, or if he is desirous of striking at a time when he is receiving more than what he deserves,

original: vā jyāyāṃsaṃ hīnaṃ samaṃ vā bhūyo yāceta //🔽bhūyo vā yācitaḥ sva /bala /rakṣā /arthaṃ durdharṣam anya /durgam āsāram
analyzed: vā jyāyāṃsam hīnam samam vā bhūyaḥ yāceta  bhūyas vā yācitaḥ sva bala rakṣā artham durdharṣam anya durgam āsāram
translated: or if he is desirous of getting more than what he deserves from a stronger, a weaker, or an equal king, he may ask for more.

original: aṭavīṃ vā para /daṇḍena marditu /kāmaḥ prakṛṣṭeadhvani kāle vā para /daṇḍaṃ kṣaya /vyayābhyāṃ
analyzed: aṭavīm vā para daṇḍena marditu kāmaḥ prakṛṣṭe adhvani kāle vā para daṇḍam kṣaya vyayābhyām
translated: Or, if he is desirous of destroying a fort which is difficult to be captured by others, or a forest which is difficult to be destroyed by others, or a source of revenue which is difficult to be captured by others, or if he is desirous of destroying the army of his enemy, or if he is desirous of destroying the army of his enemy which is marching on a long journey or at a difficult time,

original: yoktu /kāmaḥ para /daṇḍena vā vivṛddhas tam evaucchettu /kāmaḥ para /daṇḍam ādātu /kāmo vā bhūyo dadyāt //
analyzed: yoktu kāmaḥ para daṇḍena vā vivṛddhaḥ tam eva aucchettu kāmaḥ para daṇḍam ādātu kāmaḥ vā bhūyaḥ dadyāt
translated: or if he is desirous of destroying the army of his enemy which is increased by the army of another king, or if he is desirous of taking the army of his enemy, he may give more than what he deserves.

original: jyāyān vā hīnaṃ yātavya /apadeśena haste kartu /kāmaḥ param ucchidya vā tam evaucchettu /kāmaḥ /
analyzed: jyāyān vā hīnam yātavya apadeśena haste kartu kāmaḥ param ucchidya vā tam eva aucchettu kāmaḥ
translated: or the conqueror may be superior to the enemy; or the conqueror may be desirous of making the enemy his subordinate by some pretext; or the conqueror may be desirous of destroying the enemy and then destroying the conqueror himself;

original: tyāgaṃ vā kṛtvā pratyādātu /kāmo bala /samād viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: tyāgam vā kṛtvā pratyādātu kāmaḥ bala samāt viśiṣṭena lābhena paṇeta
translated: or the conqueror may be desirous of abandoning the enemy and then regaining his lost position; or the conqueror may be desirous of making peace with the enemy on the condition of receiving more than what he deserves;

analyzed: paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: if the conqueror is able to inflict injury on the enemy, he may declare war;

analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt
translated: otherwise he may make peace;

analyzed: yātavya saṃhitaḥ vā tiṣṭhet
translated: or he may remain neutral, having formed an alliance with the enemy;

original: dūṣya /amitra /aṭavī /daṇḍaṃ vāasmai dadyāt //🔽jāta /vyasana /prakṛti /randhro vā jyāyān hīnaṃ bala /samena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: dūṣya amitra aṭavī daṇḍam vā asmai dadyāt  jāta vyasana prakṛti randhraḥ vā jyāyān hīnam bala samena lābhena paṇeta
translated: or he may send to the enemy an army consisting of traitors, enemies, and wild tribes;🔽or the conqueror may be superior to the enemy, whose people are suffering from some calamity and whose constitution is disorganised; the conqueror may then make peace with the enemy on the condition of receiving less than what he deserves;

analyzed: paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: if the conqueror is able to inflict injury on the enemy, he may declare war;

original: anyathā saṃdadhyāt //🔽evaṃ /bhūtaṃ hīnaṃ jyāyān bala /samādd hīnena lābhena paṇeta //
analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt  evaṃbhūtam hīnam jyāyān hīnena lābhena paṇeta
translated: otherwise he may make peace;🔽in the same manner, the conqueror may be superior to the enemy, who is inferior to the conqueror; the conqueror may then make peace with the enemy on the condition of receiving less than what he deserves;

analyzed: paṇitaḥ tasya apakāra samarthaḥ vikrameta
translated: if the conqueror is able to inflict injury on the enemy, he may declare war;

analyzed: anyathā saṃdadhyāt
translated: otherwise he may make peace;

original: ādau budhyeta paṇitaḥ paṇamānaś ca kāraṇam //
analyzed: ādau budhyeta paṇitaḥ paṇamānaḥ ca kāraṇam
translated: at the outset, the conqueror should ascertain the cause of the enemy’s desire for peace and his own desire for war;

original: tato vitarkya /ubhayato yataḥ śreyaś tato vrajet //E
analyzed: tatas vitarkya aubhayatas yatas śreyaḥ tatas vrajet
translated: then having reflected on both sides, he should go to that side which is better;

analyzed: yātavya vṛttiḥ
translated: the conqueror should consider the enemy’s conduct, the special favours done to him by his friends,

original: yātavyoabhiyāsyamānaḥ saṃdhi /kāraṇam ādātu /kāmo vihantu /kāmo vā sāmavāyikānām anyatamaṃ lābha /dvaiguṇyena paṇeta //🔽paṇamānaḥ kṣaya /vyaya /pravāsa /pratyavāya /para /upakāra /śarīra /ābādhāṃś caasya varṇayet //
analyzed: yātavyaḥ abhiyāsyamānaḥ saṃdhi kāraṇam ādātu kāmaḥ vihantu kāmaḥ vā sāmavāyikānām anyatamam lābha dvaiguṇyena paṇeta  paṇamānaḥ kṣaya vyaya pravāsa pratyavāya para aupakāra śarīra ābādhān ca asya varṇayet
translated: When the enemy is about to invade, the conqueror may make peace with the enemy in order to obtain some advantage, or to destroy the enemy, or to gain some profit from the allies of the enemy.

analyzed: pratipannam arthena yojayet
translated: When the conqueror is about to make peace with the enemy, he should describe to the enemy the loss of men and money, the hardships of living in a foreign country, the danger of being captured, the help received from the enemy, and the bodily sufferings of the enemy.🔽When the enemy agrees to make peace, the conqueror should join him with wealth.

original: vairaṃ vā parair grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet //🔽durārabdha /karmāṇaṃ bhūyaḥ kṣaya /vyayābhyāṃ yoktu /kāmaḥ sv /ārabdhāṃ🔽vā yātrā /siddhiṃ vighātayitu /kāmo mūle yātrāyāṃ vā prahartu /kāmo yātavya /saṃhitaḥ
analyzed: vairam vā paraiḥ grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet  durārabdha karmāṇam bhūyas kṣaya vyayābhyām yoktu kāmaḥ su ārabdhām  vā yātrā siddhim vighātayitu kāmaḥ mūle yātrāyām vā prahartu kāmaḥ yātavya saṃhitaḥ
translated: Or, having caused the enemy to make peace with others, he should break the agreement.🔽When the conqueror desires to cause further loss of men and money to the enemy who has begun a bad undertaking, or to obstruct the success of the enemy’s expedition which has been well begun, or to strike the enemy in the rear or in the front, he should make peace with the enemy.

original: punar yācitu /kāmaḥ pratyutpanna /artha /kṛcchras tasminn aviśvasto vā tadātve lābham alpam icchet /
analyzed: punar yācitu kāmaḥ pratyutpanna artha kṛcchraḥ tasmin aviśvastaḥ vā tadātve lābham alpam icchet
translated: When the conqueror desires to demand more, or when he is in immediate need of wealth, or when he is not confident of the enemy, he should desire little profit at that time.

analyzed: āyatyām prabhūtam
translated: But much profit in the future.

original: mitra /upakāram amitra /upaghātam artha /anubandham avekṣamāṇaḥ pūrva /upakārakaṃ kārayitu /kāmo bhūyas tadātve mahāntaṃ lābham utsṛjyaāyatyām
analyzed: mitra aupakāram amitra aupaghātam artha anubandham avekṣamāṇaḥ pūrva aupakārakam kārayitu kāmaḥ bhūyas tadātve mahāntam lābham utsṛjya āyatyām
translated: When the conqueror desires to make the former benefactor do more, or to destroy the enemy who has helped the enemy, or to consider the future profit, he should give up the great profit at that time and

original: alpam icchet //🔽dūṣya /amitrābhyāṃ mūla /hareṇa vā jyāyasā vigṛhītaṃ trātu /kāmas tathā /vidham upakāraṃ kārayitu /kāmaḥ sambandha /avekṣī vā tadātve
analyzed: alpam icchet  dūṣya amitrābhyām mūla hareṇa vā jyāyasā vigṛhītam trātu kāmaḥ tathāvidham upakāram kārayitu kāmaḥ sambandha avekṣī vā tadātve
translated: He should desire little.

original: caāyatyāṃ ca lābhaṃ na pratigṛhṇīyāt //🔽kṛta /saṃdhir atikramitu /kāmaḥ parasya prakṛti /karśanaṃ mitra /amitra /saṃdhi /viśleṣaṇaṃ vā kartu /kāmaḥ para /abhiyogātśaṅkamāno lābham
analyzed: ca āyatyām ca lābham na pratigṛhṇīyāt  kṛta saṃdhiḥ atikramitu kāmaḥ parasya prakṛti karśanam mitra amitra saṃdhi viśleṣaṇam vā kartu kāmaḥ para abhiyogāt śaṅkamānaḥ lābham
translated: If he is desirous of saving a king who is being attacked by a powerful enemy or by a wicked or inimical king, or by a king who is taking away the root of his power, or if he is desirous of making him do a service of the same kind, or if he is desirous of looking to the relationship between the two kings, he should not accept the present and future profit.

analyzed: a prāptam adhikam vā yāceta
translated: If he is desirous of violating the treaty with the enemy, or of destroying the subjects of the enemy, or of making peace or war with the friend or the enemy, or if he suspects an attack from the enemy, he should demand more profit than he is getting.

original: tam itaras tadātve caāyatyāṃ ca kramam avekṣeta //
analyzed: tam itaraḥ tadātve ca āyatyām ca kramam avekṣeta
translated: The other king should consider the present and future prospects of the demand.

analyzed: tena pūrve vyākhyātāḥ
translated: This has been explained by the above.

original: ari /vijigīṣvos tu svaṃ svaṃ mitram anugṛhṇatoḥ śakya /kalya /bhavya /ārambhi /sthira /karma /anurakta /prakṛtibhyo viśeṣaḥ //🔽śakya /ārambhī viṣahyaṃ karmaārabhate /
analyzed: ari vijigīṣvoḥ tu svam svam mitram anugṛhṇatoḥ śakya kalya bhavya ārambhi sthira karma anurakta prakṛtibhyaḥ viśeṣaḥ  śakya ārambhī viṣahyam karma ārabhate
translated: But between a king who is desirous of conquering an enemy and a king who is desirous of favouring his friend, the former is superior to the latter in the following respects: he has the capacity, he is fit, he is prosperous, he undertakes work, he is steady in his work, and his subjects are attached to him.🔽He who undertakes work that can be done is one who has the capacity.

analyzed: kalya ārambhī nirdoṣam
translated: He who undertakes work that is free from defects is one who is fit.

analyzed: bhavya ārambhī kalyāṇa odayam
translated: He who undertakes work that is prosperous is one who is prosperous.

analyzed: sthira karmā na a samāpya karma uparamate
translated: He who does not give up his work before it is completed is one who is steady in his work.

original: anurakta /prakṛtiḥ susahāyatvād alpenaapy anugraheṇa kāryaṃ sādhayati //
analyzed: anurakta prakṛtiḥ su sahāya tvāt alpena api anugraheṇa kāryam sādhayati
translated: A friend whose subjects are loyal is a good ally, and can be made to accomplish one’s purpose by a small favour.

original: ta ete kṛta /arthāḥ sukhena prabhūtaṃ caupakurvanti //
analyzed: te ete kṛta arthāḥ sukhena prabhūtam ca aupakurvanti
translated: And when they are satisfied, they render him abundant help with ease.

analyzed: atas pratilomāḥ na anugrāhyāḥ
translated: Therefore, enemies should not be favoured.

original: tayor eka /puruṣa /anugrahe yo mitraṃ mitra /taraṃ vāanugṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tayoḥ eka puruṣa anugrahe yaḥ mitram mitrataram vā anugṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two, he who favours a friend or a better friend than the enemy, gains an advantage.

analyzed: mitrāt ātma vṛddhim hi prāpnoti  kṣaya vyaya pravāsa para aupakārān itaraḥ
translated: For he gains an increase of his own power from his friend.

analyzed: kṛta arthaḥ ca śatruḥ vaiguṇyam eti
translated: The other gains only a temporary benefit, which is attended by loss of men and money, and by exile of his enemy.🔽And when the enemy is satisfied, he becomes disaffected.

original: madhyamaṃ tv anugṛhṇator yo madhyamaṃ mitraṃ mitrataraṃ vāanugṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: madhyamam tu anugṛhṇatoḥ yaḥ madhyamam mitram mitrataram vā anugṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two who favour a neutral king, he who favours a friend or a better friend than the other, gains an advantage.

analyzed: mitrāt ātma vṛddhim hi prāpnoti
translated: For he gains an increase of his own power from his friend.

analyzed: kṣaya vyaya pravāsa para aupakārān itaraḥ
translated: The other gains only a temporary benefit, which is attended by loss of men and money, and by exile of his enemy.

original: madhyamaś ced anugṛhīto viguṇaḥ syād amitroatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: madhyamaḥ ced anugṛhītaḥ viguṇaḥ syāt amitraḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: If the neutral king, when favoured, becomes disaffected, then the enemy gains an advantage.

original: kṛta /prayāsaṃ hi madhyama /amitram apasṛtam eka /artha /upagataṃ prāpnoti //
analyzed: kṛta prayāsam hi madhyama amitram apasṛtam eka artha aupagatam prāpnoti
translated: For he gains a neutral enemy who has made preparations, who has retired, and who has joined him for a common object.

analyzed: tena audāsīna anugrahaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: The favouring of a neutral king is thus explained.

original: madhyama /udāsīnayor bala /aṃśa /dāne yaḥ śūraṃ kṛta /astraṃ duḥkha /saham anuraktaṃ vā daṇḍaṃ dadāti soatisaṃdhīyate //
analyzed: madhyama audāsīnayoḥ bala aṃśa dāne yaḥ śūram kṛta astram duḥkha saham anuraktam vā daṇḍam dadāti saḥ atisaṃdhīyate
translated: When he gives his army to a neutral king, he who gives a brave, well-trained, and loyal army to a neutral king, gains an ally.

original: viparītoatisaṃdhatte //🔽yatra tu daṇḍaḥ prahitas taṃ vā caartham anyāṃś ca sādhayati tatra maula /bhṛta /śreṇī /mitra /aṭavī /balānām anyatamam upalabdha /deśa /kālaṃ
analyzed: viparītaḥ atisaṃdhatte  yatra tu daṇḍaḥ prahitaḥ tam vā ca artham anyān ca sādhayati tatra maula bhṛta śreṇī mitra aṭavī balānām anyatamam upalabdha deśa kālam
translated: He who gives the opposite, loses an ally.

analyzed: daṇḍam dadyāt
translated: When the army sent out accomplishes the purpose for which it was sent and other purposes as well, then he should give his army to the king, consisting of the army of the people, the hired army, the army of the guilds, the army of friends, and the army of wild tribes, which is available in the right place and at the right time.🔽He should give his army to the king, consisting of the army of the people, the hired army, the army of the guilds, the army of friends, and the army of wild tribes, which is available in the right place and at the right time.

analyzed: amitra aṭavī balam vā vyavahita deśa kālam
translated: Or the army of enemies and wild tribes, which is available in a distant place and at a distant time.

original: yaṃ tu manyeta kṛta /artho me daṇḍaṃ gṛhṇīyād /
analyzed: yam tu manyeta kṛtaarthaḥ me daṇḍam gṛhṇīyāt
translated: But if he thinks that the king, having accomplished his purpose, will take away his army,

analyzed: amitra aṭavya bhūmyan ṛtuṣu vā vāsayet
translated: or will keep him in a country which is not suitable for his army, or in a season which is not suitable,

analyzed: aphalam vā kuryāt iti
translated: or will make him do fruitless work,

analyzed: daṇḍa vyāsaṅga apadeśena na enam anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: then he should not favour him under the pretext of the army being engaged elsewhere.

original: evam avaśyaṃ tv anugrahītavye tat /kāla /saham asmai daṇḍaṃ dadyāt //
analyzed: evam avaśyam tu anugrahītavye tad kāla saham asmai daṇḍam dadyāt
translated: But if he must necessarily favour him, then he should give him his army which is available at that time.

original: ā /samāpteś caenaṃ vāsayed yodhayec ca bala /vyasanebhyaś ca rakṣet //
analyzed: ā samāpteḥ ca enam vāsayet yodhayet ca bala vyasanebhyaḥ ca rakṣet
translated: And he should keep him and fight with him till the end, and protect him from the calamities of the army.

analyzed: kṛta arthāt ca sa apadeśam apasrāvayet
translated: And when his purpose is accomplished, he should send him away under some pretext.

analyzed: dūṣya amitra aṭavī daṇḍam vā asmai dadyāt
translated: or he may give him the army of the enemy, of a wild chief, or of a robber.

original: yātavyena vā saṃdhāyaenam atisaṃdadhyāt //🔽same hi lābhe saṃdhiḥ syād viṣame vikramo mataḥ //
analyzed: yātavyena vā saṃdhāya enam atisaṃdadhyāt  same hi lābhe saṃdhiḥ syāt viṣame vikramaḥ mataḥ
translated: Or having made peace with the assailable enemy, he may attack the enemy with whom he has made peace.🔽For peace is possible only when the two parties are of equal strength; and war is considered possible only when the two parties are of unequal strength.

analyzed: sama hīna viśiṣṭānām iti uktāḥ saṃdhi vikramāḥ
translated: Thus peace and war have been described as possible between parties of equal, inferior, and superior strength.

analyzed: mitra hiraṇya bhūmi karma saṃdhayaḥ
translated: There are four kinds of peace, viz., peace with a friend, with gold, with land, and with work.

original: tatra mitra /saṃdhiḥ hiraṇya /saṃdhiś ca🔽saṃhita /prayāṇe mitra /hiraṇya /bhūmi /lābhānām uttara /uttaro lābhaḥ śreyān //
analyzed: tatra mitrasaṃdhiḥ hiraṇyasaṃdhiḥ ca  saṃhita prayāṇe mitra hiraṇya bhūmi lābhānām uttara auttaraḥ lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: Of these, peace with a friend and with gold🔽are better than peace with land, because in the former two cases, the acquisition of land and gold is possible,🔽while in the latter case, the acquisition of a friend and gold is possible.

analyzed: mitra hiraṇye hi bhūmi lābhāt bhavataḥ
translated: Or, when the acquisition of a friend is possible, that of gold is possible,

analyzed: mitram hiraṇya lābhāt
translated: and when the acquisition of gold is possible, that of a friend is possible.

original: yo vā lābhaḥ siddhaḥ śeṣayor anyataraṃ sādhayati //🔽tvaṃ caahaṃ ca mitraṃ labhāvahe ity evaṃ /ādidh sama /saṃdhiḥ //
analyzed: yaḥ vā lābhaḥ siddhaḥ śeṣayoḥ anyataram sādhayati  tvam ca aham ca mitram labhāvahe iti evaṃādidh sama saṃdhiḥ
translated: When the acquisition of either of the two is possible, the acquisition of the other is also possible.🔽When the acquisition of both is possible, it is a case of equal peace.

analyzed: tvam mitram iti evaṃādiḥ viṣama saṃdhiḥ
translated: When the acquisition of a friend is possible, it is a case of unequal peace.

analyzed: tayoḥ viśeṣa lābhāt atisaṃdhiḥ
translated: When the acquisition of either of the two is possible, it is a case of superior peace.

original: sama /saṃdhau tu yaḥ sampannaṃ mitraṃ mitra /kṛcchre vā mitram avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: sama saṃdhau tu yaḥ sampannam mitram mitra kṛcchre vā mitram avāpnoti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: In a case of equal peace, he who acquires a friend who is prosperous or who is in difficulties, acquires a superior peace.

analyzed: āpad hi sauhṛda sthairyam utpādayati
translated: for a calamity produces firmness in friendship.

original: mitra /kṛcchreapi nityam avaśyam anityaṃ vaśyaṃ vāiti nityam avaśyaṃ śreyaḥ /
analyzed: mitrakṛcchre api nityam avaśyam anityam vaśyam vā iti nityam avaśyam śreyaḥ
translated: Even in a time of difficulty, a friend who is always obedient and who is either permanent or impermanent is better.

original: tadd hi anupakurvad api naapakaroti ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: tat hi an upakurvat api na apakaroti iti ācāryāḥ
translated: For, even if he does not help, he does not harm, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ  vaśyam anityam śreyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

analyzed: yāvat upakaroti tāvat mitram bhavati
translated: a friend who is always obedient and who is either of great enjoyment but impermanent or of little enjoyment but permanent is better.🔽As long as he is of help, he is a friend.

analyzed: upakāra lakṣaṇam mitram iti
translated: A friend is one who is characterized by help, say the teachers.

original: vaśyayor api mahā /bhogam anityam alpa /bhogaṃ vā nityam iti //🔽mahā /bhogam anityaṃ śreyaḥ /
analyzed: vaśyayoḥ api mahā bhogam anityam alpa bhogam vā nityam iti  mahā bhogam anityam śreyaḥ
translated: Even among the obedient, a friend who is of great enjoyment but impermanent or of little enjoyment but permanent is better.🔽A friend who is of great enjoyment but impermanent is better, say the teachers.

original: mahā /bhogam anityam alpa /kālena mahad /upakurvan mahānti vyaya /sthānāni pratikaroti ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: mahā bhogam anityam alpa kālena mahat upakurvat mahānti vyaya sthānāni pratikaroti iti ācāryāḥ
translated: For, he who is of great enjoyment but impermanent helps greatly in a short time and repays the great expenses.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

analyzed: nityam alpa bhogam śreyaḥ
translated: a friend who is always obedient and who is of little enjoyment but permanent is better.

analyzed: mahā bhogam anityam upakāra bhayāt apakrāmati
translated: A friend who is of great enjoyment but impermanent goes away out of fear of being of help.

analyzed: upakṛtya vā pratyādātum īhate
translated: Or, having helped, he tries to take it back.

original: nityam alpa /bhogaṃ sātatyād alpam upakurvan mahatā kālena mahad upakaroti //
analyzed: nityam alpa bhogam sātatyāt alpam upakurvan mahatā kālena mahat upakaroti
translated: A friend who is always obedient and who is of little enjoyment helps little by his constant presence, but helps greatly in a long time.

original: guru /samutthaṃ mahan mitraṃ laghu /samuttham alpaṃ vāiti guru /samutthaṃ mahan mitraṃ pratāpa /karaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: guru samuttham mahat mitram laghu samuttham alpam vā aiti guru samuttham mahat mitram pratāpa karam bhavati
translated: A great friend with a great army is better than a small friend with a small army.🔽The teachers say that a great friend with a great army is more powerful.

original: yadā cauttiṣṭhate tadā kāryaṃ sādhayati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: yadā ca uttiṣṭhate tadā kāryam sādhayati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: And when it rises, it accomplishes the task.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says no.

analyzed: laghu samuttham alpam śreyaḥ
translated: A small friend with a small army is better.

original: lagu /samuttham alpaṃ mitraṃ kārya /kālaṃ naatipātayati daurbalyāc ca yathā /iṣṭa /bhogyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: lagu samuttham alpam mitram kārya kālam na atipātayati daurbalyāt ca yathā iṣṭa bhogyam bhavati
translated: A small friend with a small army does not delay the task when the time comes, and because of its weakness, it becomes as enjoyable as desired.

analyzed: na etarat prakṛṣṭabhaumam
translated: Not the other, which is extensive.

original: vikṣipta /sainyam avaśya /sainyaṃ vāiti vikṣiptaṃ sainyaṃ śakyaṃ pratisaṃhartuṃ vaśyatvād ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: vikṣipta sainyam avaśya sainyam vā iti vikṣiptam sainyam śakyam pratisaṃhartum vaśya tvāt iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teachers say that a scattered army is better than a dependent army, because a scattered army can be assembled again because it is dependent.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ  avaśya sainyam śreyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says no.🔽A dependent army is better.

original: avaśyaṃ hi śakyaṃ sāma /ādibhir vaśyaṃ kartum /
analyzed: avaśyam hi śakyam sāma ādibhiḥ vaśyam kartum
translated: For a dependent army can certainly be made dependent by conciliation and other means.

analyzed: na etarat kārya vyāsaktam pratisaṃhartum
translated: Not the other, which is engaged in its own work, can be assembled again.🔽A friend who enjoys men or wealth. A friend who enjoys men is better.

original: puruṣa /bhogaṃ hiraṇya /bhogaṃ vā mitram iti puruṣa /bhogaṃ mitraṃ śreyaḥ /🔽pruṣa /bhogaṃ mitraṃ pratāpa /karaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: puruṣa bhogam hiraṇya bhogam vā mitram iti puruṣa bhogam mitram śreyaḥ 🔽pruṣa bhogam mitram pratāpa karam bhavati
translated: A friend who enjoys men is more powerful.

original: yadā cauttiṣṭhate tadā kāryaṃ sādhayati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: yadā ca uttiṣṭhate tadā kāryam sādhayati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: and when it is ready, it accomplishes the desired object, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

analyzed: hiraṇya bhogam mitram śreyaḥ
translated: a friend who enjoys gold is better.

original: nityo hi hiraṇyena yogaḥ kadācid daṇḍena //
analyzed: nityaḥ hi hiraṇyena yogaḥ kadācid daṇḍena
translated: For, gold is always available, but the army is sometimes available.

original: daṇḍaś ca hiraṇyenaanye ca kāmāḥ prāpyanta iti //
analyzed: daṇḍaḥ ca hiraṇyena anye ca kāmāḥ prāpyante iti
translated: And the army, as well as other desired objects, are obtained through gold.

original: hiraṇya /bhogaṃ bhūmi /bhogaṃ vā mitram iti hiraṇya /bhogaṃ gatimattvāt sarva /vyaya /pratīkāra /karam ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: hiraṇya bhogam bhūmi bhogam vā mitram iti hiraṇya bhogam gatimat tvāt sarva vyaya pratīkāra karam iti ācāryāḥ
translated: A friend who enjoys gold or land is better, say the teachers, because a friend who enjoys gold is more mobile and can remedy all kinds of loss.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

original: mitra /hiraṇye hi bhūmi /lābhād bhavata ity uktaṃ purastād //
analyzed: mitra hiraṇye hi bhūmi lābhāt bhavataḥ iti uktam purastāt
translated: for it has been said before that friends and gold are obtained through the acquisition of land.

original: tasmād bhūmi /bhogaṃ mitraṃ śreya iti //🔽tulye puruṣa /bhoge vikramaḥ kleśa /sahatvam anurāgaḥ sarva /bala /lābho vā mitra /kulād viśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt bhūmi bhogam mitram śreyaḥ iti  tulye puruṣa bhoge vikramaḥ kleśa saha tvam anurāgaḥ sarva bala lābhaḥ vā mitra kulāt viśeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, a friend who enjoys land is better.🔽When two friends enjoy the same amount of men, the difference lies in the friend whose family is more powerful, more enduring, more affectionate, and more resourceful.

original: tulye hiraṇya /bhoge prārthita /arthatā prābhūtyam alpa /prayasatā sātatyaṃ ca viśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: tulye hiraṇya bhoge prārthita artha tā prābhūtyam alpa prayasa tā sātatyam ca viśeṣaḥ
translated: When two friends enjoy the same amount of gold, the difference lies in the friend who is more helpful, more generous, less troublesome, and more constant.

analyzed: tatra etat bhavati
translated: Here is the relevant text:

analyzed: nityam vaśyam laghu utthānam pitṛpaitāmaham mahat
translated: Always obedient, quick to rise, great, inherited from father and grandfather,

original: advaidhyaṃ caiti sampannaṃ mitraṃ ṣaḍ /guṇam ucyate //
analyzed: advaidhyam ca eti sampannam mitram ṣaḍguṇam ucyate
translated: and which is not inimical, is said to be a friend possessing six qualities.

original: ṛte yad arthaṃ praṇayād rakṣyate yac ca rakṣati /
analyzed: ṛte yat artham praṇayāt rakṣyate yat ca rakṣati
translated: That friend which is protected out of affection, even though it is not useful, and which protects (the king) in return,

analyzed: pūrva aupacita sambandham tat mitram nityam ucyate
translated: and whose relationship has been cultivated from the beginning, is said to be a permanent friend.

analyzed: sarva citra mahā bhogam trividham vaśyam ucyate
translated: That which is of three kinds, viz., all-acquisitive, all-acquisitive and possessing great resources, and is obedient, is said to be a controllable friend.

original: ekato /bhogy ubhayataḥ sarvato /bhogi caaparam //🔽ādātṛ vā dātr /api vā jīvaty ariṣu hiṃsayā /
analyzed: ekatobhogi ubhayatas sarvatobhogi ca aparam  ādātṛ vā dātṛ api vā jīvati ariṣu hiṃsayā
translated: Another kind of friend is one that is to be enjoyed on one side, on both sides, and on all sides.🔽That friend which, by causing injury to the enemies, either takes (from them) or gives (to them) the life of the enemy,

original: mitraṃ nityam avaśyaṃ tad /durga /aṭavy /apasāri ca //🔽anyato vigṛhītaṃ yal laghu /vyasanam eva vā /
analyzed: mitram nityam avaśyam tad durga aṭa vyapasāri ca  anyatas vigṛhītam yat laghu vyasanam eva vā
translated: and which is permanent, obedient, and capable of affording shelter in a fort, in a forest, or in a place of retreat,🔽that friend which, when attacked by another, is of little trouble,

original: saṃdhatte caupakārāya tan mitraṃ vaśyam adhruvam //
analyzed: saṃdhatte ca aupakārāya tat mitram vaśyam adhruvam
translated: and which, in return for help, makes peace, is a controllable friend, but unstable.

analyzed: eka arthena atha sambaddham upakārya vikāri ca
translated: That friend which is connected with the same object, which is helpful, and which changes (its attitude) according to circumstances,

original: mitra /bhāvi bhavaty etan mitram advaidhyam āpadi //
analyzed: mitra bhāvi bhavati etat mitram a dvaidhyam āpadi
translated: becomes a friend in times of adversity, and is a friend that is not inimical.

analyzed: mitra bhāvāt dhruvam mitram śatru sādhāraṇāt calam
translated: A friend that is permanent is one that is a friend by nature; one that is unstable is one that is common to both (parties);

original: na kasyacid udāsīnaṃ dvayor ubhaya /bhāvi tat //
analyzed: na kasyacid udāsīnam dvayoḥ ubhaya bhāvi tat
translated: one that is neutral is not a friend of anyone; one that is of both sides is one that is a friend to both (parties).

original: vijigīṣor amitraṃ yan mitram antardhitāṃ gatam /
analyzed: vijigīṣoḥ amitram yat mitram antardhi tām gatam
translated: That friend of the conqueror which has disappeared, and which is an enemy,

analyzed: upakāre aniviṣṭam vā aśaktam vā anupakāri tat
translated: or if it is not engaged in helping, or if it is incapable of helping, or if it does not help,

original: priyaṃ parasya vā rakṣyaṃ pūjyaṃ sambaddham eva vā /
analyzed: priyam parasya vā rakṣyam pūjyam sambaddham eva vā
translated: or if it is dear to the enemy, or if it is to be protected, or if it is to be honoured, or if it is connected with the enemy,

original: anugṛhṇāti yan mitraṃ śatru /sādhāraṇaṃ hi tat //
analyzed: anugṛhṇāti yat mitram śatru sādhāraṇam hi tat
translated: then the friend who favours it is common to both the conqueror and the enemy.

original: prakṛṣṭa /bhaumaṃ saṃtuṣṭaṃ balavac caālasaṃ ca yat /
analyzed: prakṛṣṭa bhaumam saṃtuṣṭam balavat ca a alasam ca yat
translated: That friend which is powerful, contented, and indolent, and which has a large territory,

analyzed: udāsīnam bhavati etat vyasanāt avamānitam
translated: becomes neutral when disregarded on account of its vices.

original: arer netuś ca yad vṛddhiṃ daurbalyād anuvartate /
analyzed: areḥ netuḥ ca yat vṛddhim daurbalyāt anuvartate
translated: That friend which, on account of its weakness, submits to the growth of both the conqueror and the enemy,

original: ubhayasyaapy avidviṣṭaṃ vidyād ubhaya /bhāvi tat //🔽kāraṇa /akāraṇa /dhvastaṃ kāraṇa /akāraṇa /āgatam /
analyzed: ubhayasya api a vidviṣṭam vidyāt ubhaya bhāvi tat  kāraṇa akāraṇa dhvastam kāraṇa akāraṇa āgatam
translated: and which is not hated by either of them, should be known as common to both.🔽That friend which is lost through its own fault or through the fault of the conqueror,

original: yo mitraṃ samupekṣeta sa mṛtyum upagūhati //
analyzed: yaḥ mitram samupekṣeta sa mṛtyum upagūhati
translated: and which is neglected by the conqueror, courts death.

original: kṣipram alpo lābhaś cirān mahān iti vā kṣipram alpo lābhaḥ kārya /deśa /kāla /saṃvādakaḥ śreyān ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: kṣipram alpaḥ lābhaḥ cirāt mahān iti vā kṣipram alpaḥ lābhaḥ kārya deśa kāla saṃvādakaḥ śreyān iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teacher Kautilya says that a small gain obtained quickly is better than a large gain obtained after a long time, or that a small gain obtained quickly and in accordance with the requirements of place, time, and purpose is better.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

original: cirād avinipātī bīja /sadharmā mahāml lābhaḥ śreyān /
analyzed: cirāt avinipātī bīja sadharmā lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: a large gain obtained after a long time and lasting for ever is like a seed.

analyzed: viparyaye pūrvaḥ
translated: The reverse of this is the first.

original: evaṃ dṛṣṭvā dhruve lābhe lābha /aṃśe ca guṇa /udayam /
analyzed: evam dṛṣṭvā dhruve lābhe lābha aṃśe ca guṇa odayam
translated: Having thus seen the rise of good qualities in a certain gain and in the share of the gain,

analyzed: sva artha siddhi paraḥ yāyāt saṃhitaḥ sāmavāyikaiḥ
translated: He should go to achieve his own purpose, united with his allies.

analyzed: mitra hiraṇya bhūmi karma saṃdhayaḥ
translated: Alliances through land, gold, friendship, and work.

analyzed: tatra bhūmi saṃdhiḥ
translated: Among them, the alliance through land:

original: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca bhūmiṃ labhāvahe iti bhūmi /saṃdhiḥ //🔽tayor yaḥ pratyupasthita /arthaḥ sampannāṃ bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tvam ca aham ca bhūmim labhāvahe iti bhūmi saṃdhiḥ  tayoḥ yaḥ pratyupasthita arthaḥ sampannām bhūmim avāpnoti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: We two will obtain land, is an alliance through land.🔽Of the two, he who obtains ready land gains the upper hand.

original: tulye sampanna /alābhe yo balavantam ākramya bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tulye sampanna alābhe yaḥ balavantam ākramya bhūmim avāpnoti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: In case of equal readiness to obtain land, he who obtains land by conquering a stronger enemy gains the upper hand.

original: bhūmi /lābhaṃ śatru /karśanaṃ pratāpaṃ ca hi prāpnoti //🔽durbalād /bhūmi /lābhe satyaṃ saukaryaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: bhūmi lābham śatru karśanam pratāpam ca hi prāpnoti  durbalāt bhūmi lābhe satyam saukaryam bhavati
translated: For he obtains land, weakens his enemy, and gains glory.🔽If land is obtained from a weaker enemy, it is indeed easy.

analyzed: durbalaḥ eva ca bhūmi lābhaḥ
translated: But the land obtained from a weak enemy is weak itself.

analyzed: tad sāmantaḥ ca mitram amitra bhāvam gacchati
translated: And the neighboring king becomes an enemy.

original: tulye balīyastve yaḥ sthita /śatrum utpāṭya bhūmim avāpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tulye balīyaḥ tve yaḥ sthita śatrum utpāṭya bhūmim avāpnoti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: In case of equal strength, he who obtains land by uprooting a settled enemy gains the upper hand.

original: durga /avāptir hi sva /bhūmi /rakṣaṇam amitra /aṭavī /pratiṣedhaṃ ca karoti //
analyzed: durga avāptiḥ hi sva bhūmi rakṣaṇam amitra aṭavī pratiṣedham ca karoti
translated: For the acquisition of a fortress secures one's own land, and prevents enemies and wild tribes.

analyzed: cala amitrāt bhūmi lābhe śakya sāmantataḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: When there is a gain of land from an enemy, there is a special ability to conquer neighboring enemies.

original: durbala /sāmantā hi kṣipra /āpyāyana /yoga /kṣemā bhavati //🔽viparītā balavat sāmantā kośa /daṇḍa /avacchedanī ca bhūmir bhavati //
analyzed: durbala sāmantā hi kṣipra āpyāyana yogakṣemā bhavati  viparītā balavat sāmantā kośa daṇḍa avacchedanī ca bhūmiḥ bhavati
