translated: When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.🔽When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.🔽When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.

original: sampannā nitya /amitrā manda /guṇā vā bhūmir anitya /amitrāiti sampannā nitya /amitrā śreyasī bhūmiḥ sampannā hi kośa /daṇḍau sampādayati /🔽tau caamitra /pratighātakau ity ācāryāḥ //🔽naiti kauṭilyaḥ //
analyzed: sampannā nitya amitrā manda guṇā vā bhūmiḥ anitya amitrā iti sampannā nitya amitrā śreyasī bhūmiḥ sampannā hi kośa daṇḍau sampādayati  tau ca amitra pratighātakau iti ācāryāḥ  na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.

original: nitya /amitra /alābhe bhūyān śatru /lābho bhavati //🔽nityaś ca śatrur upakṛte caapakṛte ca śatrur eva bhavati /🔽anityas tu śatrur upakārād anapakārād vā śāmyati //
analyzed: nitya amitra alābhe bhūyān śatru lābhaḥ bhavati  nityaḥ ca śatruḥ upakṛte ca apakṛte ca śatruḥ eva bhavati  anityaḥ tu śatruḥ upakārāt anapakārāt vā śāmyati
translated: When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.🔽When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.🔽When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.

original: yasyā hi bhūmer bahu /durgāś cora /gaṇair mleccha /aṭavībhir vā nitya /avirahitāḥ pratyantāḥ sā nitya /amitrā /🔽viparyaye tv anitya /amitrā //
analyzed: yasyāḥ hi bhūmeḥ bahu durgāḥ cora gaṇaiḥ mleccha aṭavībhiḥ vā nitya avirahitāḥ pratyantāḥ sā nitya amitrā 🔽viparyaye tu anitya amitrā
translated: When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.🔽When the enemy is strong, the king should make peace with him; when he is weak, he should attack him; when he is in a prosperous condition, he should seek his friendship; and when he is in a miserable condition, he should forsake him.

original: alpā pratyāsannā mahatī vyavahitā vā bhūmir iti alpā pratyāsannā śreyasī //
analyzed: alpā pratyāsannā mahatī vyavahitā vā bhūmiḥ iti alpā pratyāsannā śreyasī
translated: A small territory is better than a large one if it is near at hand, and a large one is better than a small one if it is far away. A small territory near at hand is better,

original: sukhā hi prāptuṃ pālayitum abhisārayituṃ ca bhavati //
analyzed: sukhā hi prāptum pālayitum abhisārayitum ca bhavati
translated: because it is easy to acquire, to protect, and to conquer.

analyzed: viparītā vyavahitā
translated: A large territory far away is the reverse.

original: vyavahitayor api daṇḍa /dhāraṇāātma /dhāraṇā vā bhūmir iti ātma /dhāraṇā śreyasī //
analyzed: vyavahitayoḥ api daṇḍa dhāraṇā ātma dhāraṇā vā bhūmiḥ iti ātma dhāraṇā śreyasī
translated: Of two territories far away, that which can be held by the king himself is better than that which can be held by the appointment of a governor.

original: sā hi sva /samutthābhyāṃ kośa /daṇḍābhyāṃ dhāryate //🔽viparītā daṇḍa /dhāraṇā daṇḍa /sthānam //🔽bāliśāt prājñād vā bhūmi /lābha iti bāliśād /bhūmi /lābhaḥ śreyān //
analyzed: sā hi sva samutthābhyām kośa daṇḍābhyām dhāryate  viparītā daṇḍa dhāraṇā daṇḍa sthānam  bāliśāt prājñāt vā bhūmi lābhaḥ iti bāliśāt bhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: For the former can be held by the king himself with his army and treasury.🔽The latter, which can be held by the appointment of a governor, is a mere nominal possession.🔽Of two territories, one acquired from a fool and the other from a wise man, that acquired from a fool is better.

analyzed: su prāpyā anupālyā hi bhavati
translated: For it is easily acquired and easily protected.

analyzed: a pratyādeyā ca
translated: And it is not to be lost.

analyzed: viparītā prājñāt anuraktā
translated: That acquired from a wise man is the reverse.

analyzed: pīḍanīya aucchedanīyayoḥ ucchedanīyāt bhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: Of two territories, one acquired by oppression and the other by destruction, that acquired by destruction is better.

original: ucchedanīyo hy anapāśrayo durbala /apāśrayo vāabhiyuktaḥ kośa /daṇḍāv ādāyaapasartu /kāmaḥ prakṛtibhis tyajyate /
analyzed: ucchedanīyaḥ hi anapāśrayaḥ durbala apāśrayaḥ vā abhiyuktaḥ kośa daṇḍau ādāya apasartu kāmaḥ prakṛtibhiḥ tyajyate
translated: For a king who is desirous of going away with his army and treasury, being helpless or having weak allies, is abandoned by his people if he is to be oppressed.

analyzed: na pīḍanīyaḥ durga mitra pratiṣṭabdhaḥ
translated: But not if he is to be destroyed, because he is protected by his forts and allies.

original: durga /pratiṣṭabdhayor api sthala /nadī /durgīyābhyāṃ sthala /durgīyād bhūmi /lābhaḥ śreyān //🔽sthāleyaṃ hi surodha /avamarda /avaskandam anihśrāvi /śatru ca //
analyzed: durga pratiṣṭabdhayoḥ api sthala nadī durgīyābhyām sthala durgīyāt bhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān  sthāleyam hi su rodha avamarda avaskandam a nihśrāvi śatru ca
translated: For a land fort is difficult to be attacked, to be captured, to be besieged, and to be destroyed by the enemy.
But a river fort is twice as difficult to be attacked.

analyzed: udakam ca pātavyam vṛtti karam ca amitrasya
translated: And water is to be drunk, and it is a means of livelihood for the enemy.

analyzed: nadī parvata durgīyābhyām nadī durgīyāt bbhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: Between a river fort and a mountain fort, the acquisition of land is better if it is on a river.

original: nadī /durgaṃ hi hasti /stambha /saṃkrama /setu /bandha /naubhiḥ sādhyam anitya /gāmbhīryam avasrāvy udakaṃ ca //
analyzed: nadī durgam hi hasti stambha saṃkrama setu bandha naubhiḥ sādhyam anitya gāmbhīryam avasrāvi udakam ca
translated: For a river fort can be conquered by elephants, by building a dam, by constructing a bridge, and by boats, and its depth is not constant, and the water can be diverted.

analyzed: pārvatam tu svārakṣam duruparodhi kṛcchra ārohaṇam
translated: But a mountain fort is well protected, difficult to be entered, and difficult to be climbed.

original: bhagne caekasmin na sarva /vadhaḥ /🔽śilā /vṛkṣa /pramokṣaś ca mahā /apakāriṇām //
analyzed: bhagne ca ekasmin na sarva vadhaḥ  śilā vṛkṣa pramokṣaḥ ca mahā apakāriṇām
translated: And when one part is broken, not all is destroyed.🔽And stones and trees can be thrown down to destroy the enemy.

analyzed: nimna sthala yodhibhyaḥ nimna yodhibhyaḥ bhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān
translated: Between a fort that can be fought in low ground and one that can be fought in high ground, the acquisition of land is better if it can be fought in low ground.

analyzed: nimna yodhinaḥ hi uparuddha deśa kālāḥ
translated: For those who fight in low ground are restricted in place and time.

analyzed: sthala yodhinaḥ tu sarva deśa kāla yodhinaḥ
translated: But those who fight in high ground can fight in all places and at all times.

original: khanaka /ākāśa /yodhibhyaḥ khanakebhyo bhūmi /lābhaḥ śreyān //🔽khanakā hi khātena śastreṇa caubhayathā yudhyante /
analyzed: khanaka ākāśa yodhibhyaḥ khanakebhyaḥ bhūmi lābhaḥ śreyān  khanakāḥ hi khātena śastreṇa ca ubhayathā yudhyante
translated: For the tillers of the soil, the acquisition of land is better than the acquisition of space fighters.🔽For the tillers of the soil fight in both ways, with the plough as a weapon and with the weapon of tilling.

analyzed: śastreṇa eva ākāśa yodhinaḥ
translated: But the space fighters fight only with weapons.

analyzed: evam vidhi ebhyaḥ pṛthivīm labhamānaḥ arthaśāstra vid
translated: Thus, one who knows the science of wealth, acquiring land from those who are of such a nature,

analyzed: saṃhitebhyaḥ parebhyaḥ ca viśeṣam adhigacchati e
translated: obtains superiority over those who are united with others.

analyzed: mitra hiraṇya bhūmi karma samdhayah tatra an avasita samdhih
translated: Alliances for friendship, gold, land, and work - among them, an unsettled alliance is

original: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca śūnyaṃ niveśayāvahe ity anavasita /saṃdhiḥ //
analyzed: tvam ca aham ca śūnyam niveśayāvahe iti anavasita saṃdhiḥ
translated: when one says, You and I will establish a settlement in a deserted place, this is an unsettled alliance.

original: tayor yaḥ pratyupasthita /artho yathā /ukta /guṇāṃ bhūmiṃ niveśayati soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tayoḥ yaḥ pratyupasthita arthaḥ yathā ukta guṇām bhūmim niveśayati saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of those two, he who establishes a settlement with land having the qualities mentioned above, when the opportunity presents itself, gains an advantage.

original: tatraapi sthalam audakaṃ vāiti mahataḥ sthalād alpam audakaṃ śreyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra api sthalam audakam vā iti mahataḥ sthalāt alpam audakam śreyaḥ
translated: Even there, whether it is dry land or water-based land, a small water-based land is better than a large dry land.

original: sātatyād avasthitatvāc ca phalānām //🔽sthalayor api prabhūta /pūrva /apara /sasyam alpa /varṣa /pākam asakta /ārambhaṃ śreyaḥ //
analyzed: sātatyāt avasthita tvāt ca phalānām  sthalayoḥ api prabhūta pūrva apara sasyam alpa varṣa pākam asakta ārambham śreyaḥ
translated: Because of the continuity and stability of the fruits.🔽Even among dry lands, one with abundant crops in the beginning and end, ripening in less rain, and requiring less effort is better.

analyzed: audakayoḥ api dhānya vāpam a dhānya vāpāt śreyaḥ
translated: Even among water-based lands, one with rice cultivation is better than one without rice cultivation.

original: tayor alpa /bahutve dhānya /kāntād alpān mahad adhānya /kāntaṃ śreyaḥ //🔽mahaty avakāśe hi sthālyāś caanūpyāś caoṣadhayo bhavanti //
analyzed: tayoḥ alpa bahu tve dhānya kāntāt alpāt mahat a dhānya kāntam śreyaḥ  mahati avakāśe hi sthālyāḥ ca anūpyāḥ ca oṣadhayaḥ bhavanti
translated: Of the two, the one with less grain and more land is better than the one with less land and more grain.🔽For in a large tract of land, crops and other plants grow in abundance.

analyzed: durgā ādīni ca karmāṇi prabhūtyena kriyante
translated: And many works such as the construction of forts are carried out in abundance.

analyzed: kṛtrimāḥ hi bhūmi guṇāḥ  khani dhānya bhogayoḥ khani bhogaḥ kośa karaḥ
translated: For the qualities of land are artificial.🔽Of mines and grain, the mine is the source of the treasury.

analyzed: dhānya bhogaḥ kośa koṣṭha agāra karaḥ
translated: The grain is the source of the treasury, the granary, and the storehouse.

analyzed: dhānya mūlāḥ hi durga ādīnām karmaṇām ārambhāḥ
translated: For the undertakings of works such as the construction of forts are based on grain.

analyzed: mahā viṣaya vikrayaḥ vā khani bhogaḥ śreyān
translated: Or the mine is better, as it is the source of the sale of valuable commodities.

original: dravya /hasti /vana /bhogayor dravya /vana /bhogaḥ sarva /karmaṇāṃ yoniḥ prabhūta /nidhāna /kṣamaś ca /
analyzed: dravya hasti vana bhogayoḥ dravya vana bhogaḥ sarva karmaṇām yoniḥ prabhūta nidhāna kṣamaḥ ca
translated: Of the sources of wealth, elephants, and forests, the source of wealth and forests is the source of all works and is capable of accumulating large stores.

analyzed: viparītaḥ hasti vana bhogaḥ iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The source of elephants and forests is the reverse, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Not so, says Kautilya.

original: śakyaṃ dravya /vanam anekam anekasyāṃ bhūmau vāpayitum /
analyzed: śakyam dravya vanam anekam anekasyām bhūmau vāpayitum
translated: It is possible to grow the many kinds of wealth and forests on many kinds of land.

analyzed: na hasti vanam
translated: But not the forest of elephants.

analyzed: hasti pradhānaḥ hi para anīka vadhaḥ iti
translated: For the destruction of the enemy's army is based on elephants.

analyzed: vāri sthala patha bhogayoḥ anityaḥ vāri patha bhogaḥ
translated: The enjoyment of the water route is uncertain, while that of the land route is certain.

original: nityaḥ sthala /patha /bhogaḥ //🔽bhinna /manuṣyā śreṇī /manuṣyā vā bhūmir iti bhinna /manuṣyā śreyasī //
analyzed: nityaḥ sthala patha bhogaḥ  bhinna manuṣyā śreṇī manuṣyā vā bhūmiḥ iti bhinna manuṣyā śreyasī
translated: The enjoyment of the land route is permanent.🔽Land with different kinds of people is better than land with only one kind of people.

analyzed: bhinna manuṣyā bhogyā bhavati  an upajāpyā ca anyeṣām
translated: Land with different kinds of people can be enjoyed.🔽And it cannot be easily taken away by others.

analyzed: anāpad sahā tu
translated: But it cannot withstand calamities.

analyzed: viparītā śreṇī manuṣyā
translated: Land with only one kind of people is the opposite.

analyzed: kope mahā doṣā
translated: If it is angered, it can cause great harm.

original: tasyāṃ cāturvarṇya /niveśe sarva /bhoga /sahatvād avara /varṇa /prāyā śreyasī /🔽bāhulyād dhruvatvāc ca kṛṣyāḥ karṣakavatī /
analyzed: tasyām cāturvarṇya niveśe sarva bhoga saha tvāt avara varṇa prāyā śreyasī  bāhulyāt dhruva tvāt ca kṛṣyāḥ karṣakavatī
translated: And in that, land with all the four castes is better because it can bear all kinds of enjoyment.🔽Land with farmers is better because farming is more abundant and certain.🔽And because farming and other undertakings are the means of livelihood, land with cattle keepers is better.

original: kṛṣyāś caanyeṣāṃ caārambhāṇāṃ prayojakatvāt go /rakṣakavatī /🔽paṇya /nicaya /ṛṇa /anugrahād āḍhya /vaṇigvatī //🔽bhūmi /guṇānām apāśrayaḥ śreyān //
analyzed: kṛṣyāḥ ca anyeṣām ca ārambhāṇām prayojaka tvāt gorakṣakavatī  paṇya nicaya ṛṇa anugrahāt āḍhya vaṇigvatī  bhūmi guṇānām apāśrayaḥ śreyān
translated: Land with wealthy merchants is better because it provides loans and favors based on stored goods.🔽Land with good qualities is better if it is not dependent on anything else.

original: durga /apāśrayā puruṣa /apāśrayā vā bhūmir iti puruṣa /apāśrayā śreyasī //
analyzed: durga apāśrayā puruṣa apāśrayā vā bhūmiḥ iti puruṣa apāśrayā śreyasī
translated: Land dependent on people is better than land dependent on forts.

analyzed: puruṣavat hi rājyam
translated: For a kingdom is like a person.

original: apuruṣā gaur vandhy eva kiṃ duhīta //
analyzed: apuruṣā gauḥ vandhī eva kim duhīta
translated: What use is a barren cow without a person?

original: mahā /kṣaya /vyaya /niveśāṃ tu bhūmim avāptu /kāmaḥ pūrvam eva kretāraṃ
analyzed: mahā kṣaya vyaya niveśām tu bhūmim avāptu kāmaḥ pūrvam eva kretāram
translated: One who desires to acquire land for a great revenue, for a great expenditure, or for a great settlement, should first make an agreement with a purchaser who is

original: paṇeta durbalam arāja /bījinaṃ nirutsāham apakṣam anyāya /vṛttiṃ vyasaninaṃ daiva /pramāṇaṃ
analyzed: paṇeta durbalam a rāja bījinam nirutsāham apakṣam anyāya vṛttim vyasaninam daiva pramāṇam
translated: weak, who is not a king, who is not enterprising, who has no allies, who is of unjust conduct, who is addicted to vices, who is guided by fate,

original: yat /kiṃcana /kāriṇaṃ vā //🔽mahā /kṣaya /vyaya /niveśāyāṃ hi bhūmau durbalo rāja /bījī niviṣṭaḥ sagandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhiḥ saha kṣaya /vyayenaavasīdati //🔽balavān arāja /bījī kṣaya /vyaya /bhayād asagandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhis tyajyate //
analyzed: yatkiṃcanakāriṇam vā  mahā kṣaya vyaya niveśāyām hi bhūmau durbalaḥ rāja bījī niviṣṭaḥ sa gandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhiḥ saha kṣaya vyayena avasīdati  balavān a rāja bījī kṣaya vyaya bhayāt a sagandhābhiḥ prakṛtibhiḥ tyajyate
translated: or who does whatever comes to his mind.🔽For in land which is of great revenue, great expenditure, or great settlement, a weak king, having settled there, perishes along with his people who are attached to him, by the revenue and expenditure.🔽A strong man who is not a king, being afraid of revenue and expenditure, is abandoned by his people who are not attached to him.

original: nirutsāhas tu daṇḍavān api daṇḍasyaapraṇetā sadaṇḍaḥ kṣaya /vyayenaavabhajyate //
analyzed: nirutsāhaḥ tu daṇḍavān api daṇḍasya apraṇetā sa daṇḍaḥ kṣaya vyayena avabhajyate
translated: But one who is not enterprising, though having an army, being not a leader of the army, is divided by revenue and expenditure, along with the army.

original: kośavān apy apakṣaḥ kṣaya /vyaya /anugraha /hīnatvān na kutaścit prāpnoti //
analyzed: kośavān api apakṣaḥ kṣaya vyaya anugraha hīna tvāt na kutaścid prāpnoti
translated: One who has a treasury, but has no allies, does not obtain anything from anywhere, because of the lack of revenue, expenditure, and favor.

analyzed: anyāya vṛttiḥ niviṣṭam api utthāpayet
translated: One of unjust conduct, even if settled, would cause to rise up.

analyzed: sa katham a niviṣṭam niveśayet
translated: How would he settle one who is not settled?

analyzed: tena vyasanī vyākhyātaḥ
translated: Therefore, one who is addicted to vices is explained.

analyzed: daiva pramāṇaḥ mānuṣa hīnaḥ nirārambhaḥ vipanna karma ārambhaḥ vā avasīdati
translated: He who is guided by fate, who is inferior to his human opponent, who does not undertake any action, or who undertakes a defective action, perishes.

analyzed: yatkiṃcanakārī na kiṃcid āsādayati
translated: He who does anything at random does not attain anything.

analyzed: sa ca eṣām pāpiṣṭhatamaḥ bhavati
translated: And he is the most sinful of them all.

original: yat /kiṃcid /ārabhamāṇo hi vijigīṣoḥ kadācic chidram āsādayed ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: yat kiṃcid ārabhamāṇaḥ hi vijigīṣoḥ kadācid chidram āsādayet iti ācāryāḥ
translated: My teacher says that he who undertakes any action may sometimes attain a weak point of his victorious enemy.

original: yathā chidraṃ tathā vināśam apy āsādayed iti kauṭilyaḥ //
analyzed: yathā chidram tathā vināśam api āsādayet iti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says that he may attain destruction as well as a weak point.

original: teṣām alābhe yathā pārṣṇi /grāha /upagrahe vakṣyāmas tathā bhūmim avasthāpayet //
analyzed: teṣām alābhe yathā pārṣṇigrāha aupagrahe vakṣyāmaḥ tathā bhūmim avasthāpayet
translated: In the absence of these, he should establish himself in the country in the same manner as he would do in securing the help of an ally against his enemy in the rear, as will be described later on.

analyzed: iti abhihita saṃdhiḥ
translated: Thus has been described peace.

original: guṇavatīm ādeyāṃ vā bhūmiṃ balavatā krayeṇa yācitaḥ saṃdhim avasthāpya dadyāt //
analyzed: guṇavatīm ādeyām vā bhūmim balavatā krayeṇa yācitaḥ saṃdhim avasthāpya dadyāt
translated: When asked by a powerful enemy to make peace on condition of giving him valuable or acquirable territory in exchange for money, he may give it.

original: ity anibhṛta /saṃdhiḥ //🔽samena vā yācitaḥ kāraṇam avekṣya dadyāt pratyādeyā me bhūmir vaśyā vā /
analyzed: iti a nibhṛta saṃdhiḥ  samena vā yācitaḥ kāraṇam avekṣya dadyāt pratyādeyā me bhūmiḥ vaśyā vā
translated: Thus has been described peace with a condition.🔽When asked by an equal enemy to make peace on condition of giving him valuable or acquirable territory, he may give it, provided he finds it to be advantageous.🔽He may think that the territory is not acquirable by me, or that it is under my control;

original: anayā pratibaddhaḥ paro me vaśyo bhaviṣyati bhūmi /vikrayād vā mitra /hiraṇya /lābhaḥ kārya /sāmarthya /karo me bhaviṣyati iti //
analyzed: anayā pratibaddhaḥ paraḥ me vaśyaḥ bhaviṣyati bhūmi vikrayāt vā mitra hiraṇya lābhaḥ kārya sāmarthya karaḥ me bhaviṣyati iti
translated: or that by this means my enemy will be under my control; or that by selling the territory I shall gain friends, gold, and the means of carrying on my works.

original: tena hīnaḥ kretā vyākhyātaḥ //🔽evaṃ mitraṃ hiraṇyaṃ ca sajanām ajanāṃ ca gām /
analyzed: tena hīnaḥ kretā vyākhyātaḥ  evam mitram hiraṇyam ca sajanām ajanām ca gām
translated: and the buyer who is not so endowed is said to be inferior.

analyzed: labhamānaḥ atisaṃdhatte śāstra vid sāmavāyikān
translated: Thus, a king who knows the science of politics gains an upper hand over his allies by obtaining friends, gold, and cattle with or without people.

analyzed: mitra hiraṇya bhūmi karma samdhayah
translated: The alliances are of four kinds, viz., of friendship, of gold, of land, and of work.

analyzed: tatra karma samdhiḥ
translated: Of these, the alliance of work is as follows:

original: tvaṃ caahaṃ ca durgaṃ kārayāvahe iti karma /saṃdhiḥ //
analyzed: tvam ca aham ca durgam kārayāvahe iti karma saṃdhiḥ
translated: We two shall build a fort. This is the alliance of work.

original: tayor yo daiva /kṛtam aviṣahyam alpa /vyaya /ārambhaṃ durgaṃ kārayati soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: tayoḥ yaḥ daiva kṛtam aviṣahyam alpa vyaya ārambham durgam kārayati saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of these two, he who builds a fort which is not naturally strong but which can be built with little expense and labour gains an upper hand.

original: tatraapi sthala /nadī /parvata /durgāṇām uttara /uttaraṃ śreyaḥ //🔽setu /bandhayor apy āhārya /udakāt saha /udakaḥ śreyān //
analyzed: tatra api sthala nadī parvata durgāṇām uttarauttaram śreyaḥ  setubandhayoḥ api āhārya audakāt saha audakaḥ śreyān
translated: Of the forts built on land, on a river, and on a mountain, the last is better than the preceding one.🔽Of the two kinds of forts, viz., one with an artificial source of water and the other with a natural source of water, the latter is better than the former.

analyzed: saha audakayoḥ api prabhūta vāpa sthānaḥ śreyān
translated: Of the two forts with a natural source of water, that which has a large area for cultivation is better.

original: dravya /vanayor api yo mahat /sāravad /dravya /aṭavīkaṃ viṣaya /ante nadī /mātṛkaṃ dravya /vanaṃ chedayati soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: dravya vanayoḥ api yaḥ mahat sāravat dravya aṭavīkam viṣaya ante nadī mātṛkam dravya vanam chedayati saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two kinds of forests, viz., one consisting of valuable timber and the other of ordinary timber, he who causes a forest of valuable timber to be felled on the border of his kingdom and on the banks of a river gains an upper hand.

original: nadī /mātṛkaṃ hi sv /ājīvam apāśrayaś caāpadi bhavati //
analyzed: nadī mātṛkam hi sva ājīvam apāśrayaḥ ca āpadi bhavati
translated: For a forest on the banks of a river is a source of livelihood and a refuge in times of distress.

original: hasti /vanayor api yo bahu /śūra /mṛgaṃ durbala /prativeśaṃ /ananta /avakleśi viṣaya /ante hasti /vanaṃ badhnāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: hasti vanayoḥ api yaḥ bahu śūra mṛgam viṣaya ante hasti vanam badhnāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Even between two forests of elephants, the one which has many brave elephants and few weak ones, and which is situated near a weak neighbour, and which is not subject to endless troubles, and which is near a place of supply, is the one to be chosen.

analyzed: tatra api bahu kuṇṭha alpa śūrayoḥ alpa śūram śreyaḥ
translated: Even there, the one with many weak and few brave elephants is better.

analyzed: śūreṣu hi yuddham
translated: For, in the case of brave elephants, there is fighting.

analyzed: alpāḥ śūrāḥ bahūn a śūrān bhañjanti
translated: A few brave elephants can crush many weak ones.

original: te bhagnāḥ sva /sainya /avaghātino bhavanti ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: te bhagnāḥ sva sainya avaghātinaḥ bhavanti iti ācāryāḥ
translated: And when they are crushed, they will destroy their own army, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Not so, says Kautilya.

analyzed: kuṇṭhāḥ bahavaḥ śreyāṃsaḥ
translated: Many weak elephants are better.

original: skandha /viniyogād anekaṃ karma kurvāṇāḥ sveṣām apāśrayo yuddhe /
analyzed: skandha viniyogāt anekam karma kurvāṇāḥ sveṣām apāśrayaḥ yuddhe
translated: For, by employing them in carrying loads, they can do many things, and they are a support to their own people in battle.

analyzed: pareṣām durdharṣāḥ vibhīṣaṇāḥ ca
translated: And they are unassailable and terrifying to the enemy.

original: bahuṣu hi kuṇṭheṣu vinaya /karmaṇā śakyaṃ śauryam ādhātum /
analyzed: bahuṣu hi kuṇṭheṣu vinaya karmaṇā śakyam śauryam ādhātum
translated: For, in the case of many weak elephants, bravery can be instilled by training.

original: na tv evaalpeṣu śūreṣu bahutvam iti //
analyzed: na tu eva alpeṣu śūreṣu bahu tvam iti
translated: But not so in the case of a few brave elephants, because of their small number.

original: khanyor api yaḥ prabhūta /sārām adurga /mārgām alpa /vyaya /ārambhāṃ khaniṃ khānayati /
analyzed: khanyoḥ api yaḥ prabhūta sārām a durga mārgām alpa vyaya ārambhām khanim khānayati
translated: Even between two mines, the one which has abundant ore, which has a road not difficult to traverse, and which requires little expenditure and labour, is the one to be chosen.

analyzed: sā u atisaṃdhatte
translated: He who digs such a mine gains more.

original: tatraapi mahā /sāram alpam alpa /sāraṃ vā prabhūtam iti mahā /sāram alpaṃ śreyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra api mahā sāram alpam alpa sāram vā prabhūtam iti mahā sāram alpam śreyaḥ
translated: Of these, it is better to have a small quantity of the most valuable merchandise, than a large quantity of the least valuable.

original: vajra /maṇi /muktā /pravāla /hema /rūpya /dhātur hi prabhūtam alpa /sāram atyargheṇa grasate ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: vajra maṇi muktā pravāla hema rūpya dhātuḥ hi prabhūtam alpa sāram atyargheṇa grasate iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teachers say that a large quantity of the least valuable merchandise, such as diamonds, gems, pearls, corals, gold, and silver, is swallowed up by a small quantity of the most valuable merchandise, which is sold at a high price.

original: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //🔽cirād alpo mahā /sārasya kretā vidyate /
analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ  cirāt alpaḥ mahā sārasya kretā vidyate
translated: Kautilya, however, says no.🔽A buyer of a small quantity of the most valuable merchandise is found after a long time,

analyzed: prabhūtaḥ sātatyāt alpa sārasya
translated: but a buyer of a large quantity of the least valuable merchandise is found immediately.

original: etena vaṇik /patho vyākhyātaḥ //🔽tatraapi vāri /sthala /pathayor vāri /pathaḥ śreyān /
analyzed: etena vaṇikpathaḥ vyākhyātaḥ  tatra api vāri sthala pathayoḥ vāri pathaḥ śreyān
translated: This explains the trade routes.🔽Of these, the teachers say that the water route is better than the land route,

analyzed: alpa vyaya vyāyāmaḥ prabhūta paṇya odayaḥ ca iti ācāryāḥ
translated: because it involves less expenditure and labour, and brings in more profit.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya, however, says no.

original: samruddha /gatir asārvakālikaḥ prakṛṣṭa /bhaya /yonir niṣpratīkāraś ca vāri /pathaḥ /
analyzed: samruddha gatiḥ asārvakālikaḥ prakṛṣṭa bhaya yoniḥ niṣpratīkāraḥ ca vāri pathaḥ
translated: The water route is obstructed in its course, is not available at all times, is the source of great danger, and is beyond remedy.

original: viparītaḥ sthala /pathaḥ //🔽vāri /pathe tu kūla /samyāna /pathayoḥ kūla /pathaḥ paṇya /pattana /bāhulyātśreyān /
analyzed: viparītaḥ sthala pathaḥ  vāri pathe tu kūla samyāna pathayoḥ kūla pathaḥ paṇya pattana bāhulyāt śreyān
translated: The land route is the reverse of this.🔽Of the water route, the teachers say that the route along the bank of a river is better than the route along the bed of a river, because it is frequented by trading towns.

analyzed: nadī pathaḥ vā
translated: Or the route along the bed of a river is better.

analyzed: sātatyāt viṣahya ābādha tvāt ca
translated: Because it is continuous and is not obstructed by any difficulty.

analyzed: sthala pathe api haimavataḥ dakṣiṇāpathāt śreyān
translated: On the land route, the southern route of the Himalayas is better.

analyzed: hasti aśva gandha danta ajina rūpya suvarṇa paṇyāḥ sāravattarāḥ iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The goods of elephants, horses, perfumes, ivory, skins, silver and gold are more valuable, say the teachers.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says, No.

analyzed: kambala ajina aśva paṇya varjāḥ śaṅkha vajra maṇi muktā suvarṇa paṇyāḥ ca prabhūtatarāḥ dakṣiṇāpathe
translated: Except blankets, skins, horses and merchandise, the goods of shells, diamonds, gems, pearls and gold are more abundant in the southern route.

original: dakṣiṇā /patheapi bahu /khaniḥ sāra /paṇyaḥ prasiddha /gatir alpa /vyaya /vyāyāmo vā vaṇik /pathaḥ śreyān /
analyzed: dakṣiṇāpathe api bahu khaniḥ sāra paṇyaḥ prasiddha gatiḥ alpa vyaya vyāyāmaḥ vā vaṇikpathaḥ śreyān
translated: On the southern route, a trade route with many mines, valuable goods, well-known routes, and little expense and effort is better.

analyzed: prabhūta viṣayaḥ vā phalgu puṇyaḥ
translated: Or one with abundant territory, though of little profit and merit.

original: tena pūrvaḥ paścimaś ca vaṇik /patho vyākhyātaḥ //
analyzed: tena pūrvaḥ paścimaḥ ca vaṇikpathaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the eastern and western trade routes are explained.

analyzed: tatra api cakra pāda pathayoḥ cakra pathaḥ vipula ārambha tvāt śreyān
translated: Among them, the wheel and foot routes, the wheel route is better because it is extensive.

analyzed: deśa kāla sambhāvanaḥ vā khara oṣṭra pathaḥ
translated: Or the camel and donkey route, which is suitable for time and place.

analyzed: ābhyām aṃsa pathaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By these, the shoulder route is explained.

analyzed: para karma odayaḥ netuḥ kṣayaḥ vṛddhiḥ viparyaye
translated: The rise of the leader is from the work of others, and his decline is from the reverse.

original: tulye karma /pathe sthānaṃ jñeyaṃ svaṃ vijigīṣuṇā //
analyzed: tulye karma pathe sthānam jñeyam svam vijigīṣuṇā
translated: On an equal trade route, one's own position should be known by the conqueror.

analyzed: alpa āgama ati vyaya tā kṣayaḥ vṛddhiḥ viparyaye
translated: Loss is the result of small income and excessive expenditure, and gain is the reverse.

original: samāya /vyayatā sthānaṃ karmasu jñeyam ātmanaḥ //🔽tasmād alpa /vyaya /ārambhaṃ durga /ādiṣu mahā /udayam //
analyzed: sa māyā vyaya tā sthānam karmasu jñeyam ātmanaḥ  tasmāt alpa vyaya ārambham durga ādiṣu mahā udayam
translated: One should know that one's own position in undertakings is the result of equal income and expenditure.

original: karma labdhvā viśiṣṭaḥ syād ity uktāḥ karma /saṃdhayaḥ //E
analyzed: karma labdhvā viśiṣṭaḥ syāt iti uktāḥ karmasaṃdhayaḥ
translated: Therefore, having undertaken an action that has little expenditure and great results, such as the construction of forts, one should become distinguished. Thus have the expedients of action been described.

analyzed: pārṣṇigrāh cintā
translated: Considerations about the rear

original: saṃhatyaari /vijigīṣvor amitrayoḥ para /abhiyoginoḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇator yaḥ śakti /sampannasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: saṃhatya ari vijigīṣvoḥ amitrayoḥ para abhiyoginoḥ pārṣṇim gṛhṇatoḥ yaḥ śakti sampannasya pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: When two enemies, one seeking to conquer and the other to resist, are seizing each other's rear, he who seizes the rear of the one who is powerful gains the upper hand.

original: śakti /sampanno hy amitram ucchidya pārṣṇi /grāham ucchindyāt /
analyzed: śakti sampannaḥ hi amitram ucchidya pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt
translated: For one who is powerful can destroy the enemy and then destroy the one who is seizing his rear.

original: na hīna /śaktir alabdha /lābhaḥ //🔽śakti /sāmye yo vipula /ārambhasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: na hīna śaktiḥ alabdha lābhaḥ  śakti sāmye yaḥ vipula ārambhasya pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Not one who is weak and has not gained anything.🔽When both are equally powerful, he who seizes the rear of the one who has undertaken a vast action gains the upper hand.

original: vipula /ārambho hy amitram ucchidya pārṣṇi /grāham ucchindyāt /
analyzed: vipula ārambhaḥ hi amitram ucchidya pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt
translated: For one who has undertaken a vast action can destroy the enemy and then destroy the one who is seizing his rear.

analyzed: na alpa ārambhaḥ sakta cakraḥ
translated: Not one who has undertaken a small action and whose army is engaged elsewhere.

original: ārambha /sāmye yaḥ sarva /saṃdohena prayātasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: ārambha sāmye yaḥ sarvasaṃdohena prayātasya pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: When both have undertaken an action of equal magnitude, he who seizes the rear of the one who has marched with all his forces gains the upper hand.

analyzed: śūnya mūlaḥ hi asya su karaḥ bhavati
translated: For one whose root is empty is easy to deal with.

original: naika /deśa /bala /prayātaḥ kṛta /pārṣṇi /pratividhānaḥ //🔽bala /upādāna /sāmye yaś cala /amitraṃ prayātasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: na eka deśa bala prayātaḥ kṛta pārṣṇi pratividhānaḥ  bala aupādāna sāmye yaḥ cala amitram prayātasya pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: One should not march against an enemy who has a strong base in his own country, who has taken measures to secure his rear, and who has not gone out to conquer a part of the enemy's territory.🔽When two kings of equal strength march against an enemy, he who attacks the rear of the enemy who has gone out to conquer a part of the enemy's territory gains the upper hand.

original: cala /amitraṃ prayāto hi sukhenaavāpta /siddhiḥ pārṣṇi /grāham ucchindyāt /
analyzed: cala amitram prayātaḥ hi sukhena avāpta siddhiḥ pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt
translated: For one who has gone out to conquer a part of the enemy's territory can easily achieve success and destroy the enemy who attacks his rear.

analyzed: na sthita amitram prayātaḥ
translated: But not one who has gone out to conquer a strong enemy.

original: asau hi durga /pratihataḥ pārṣṇi /grāhe ca pratinivṛttaḥ sthitenaamitreṇaavagṛhyate //
analyzed: asau hi durga pratihataḥ pārṣṇigrāhe ca pratinivṛttaḥ sthitena amitreṇa avagṛhyate
translated: For the latter, being obstructed by fortifications, will turn back against the enemy who attacks his rear and will be captured by the strong enemy.

analyzed: tena pūrve vyākhyātāḥ
translated: Therefore the above cases are explained.

original: śatru /sāmye yo dhārmika /abhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: śatru sāmye yaḥ dhārmika abhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: When two kings of equal strength attack an enemy, he who attacks the rear of the king who is righteous and energetic gains the upper hand.

original: dhārmika /abhiyogī hi sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca dveṣyo bhavati /
analyzed: dhārmika abhiyogī hi sveṣām pareṣām ca dveṣyaḥ bhavati
translated: For the righteous and energetic king becomes hateful to his own people and to the enemy.

analyzed: adhārmika abhiyogī sampriyaḥ
translated: The unrighteous and energetic king becomes dear.

analyzed: tena mūla hara tādātvika kadarya abhiyoginām pārṣṇigrahaṇam vyākhyātam
translated: Therefore the attack on the rear of the king who is a root-harvester, the king who is a spendthrift, and the king who is a miser is explained.

analyzed: mitra abhiyoginoḥ pārṣṇigrahaṇe te eva hetavaḥ
translated: In the case of the attack on the rear of two kings who are energetic in attacking an ally, the same reasons apply.

original: mitram amitraṃ caabhiyuñjānayor yo mitra /abhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: mitram amitram ca abhiyuñjānayoḥ yaḥ mitra abhiyoginaḥ pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two kings, one who is attacking a friend and the other an enemy, he who seizes the rear of the king who is attacking a friend, gains an advantage over the other.

analyzed: mitra abhiyogī hi sukhena avāpta siddhiḥ pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt
translated: For the king who is attacking a friend can easily achieve success and destroy the rear of the enemy.

original: sukaro hi mitreṇa saṃdhir naamitreṇa //🔽mitram amitraṃ cauddharator yoamitra /uddhāriṇaḥ pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇāti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: sukaraḥ hi mitreṇa saṃdhiḥ na amitreṇa  mitram amitram ca auddharatoḥ yaḥ amitra auddhāriṇaḥ pārṣṇim gṛhṇāti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: For it is easy to make peace with a friend, but not with an enemy.🔽Of the two kings, one who is attacking a friend and the other an enemy, he who seizes the rear of the king who is attacking an enemy, gains an advantage over the other.

analyzed: vṛddha mitraḥ hi amitra auddhārī pārṣṇigrāham ucchindyāt
translated: For the king who is attacking an enemy can destroy the rear of the enemy, having a powerful friend.

original: naitaraḥ sva /pakṣa /upaghātī //🔽tayor alabdha /lābha /apagamane yasya /amitro mahato lābhād viyuktaḥ kṣaya /vyaya /adhiko vā sa pārṣṇi /grāhoatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: na etaraḥ sva pakṣa aupaghātī  tayoḥ alabdha lābha apagamane yasya amitraḥ mahataḥ lābhāt viyuktaḥ kṣaya vyaya adhikaḥ vā sa pārṣṇigrāhaḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: But not the other king who is injuring his own ally.🔽Of the two kings, one of whom has deprived his enemy of a great gain, and the other of whom has caused his enemy to lose what he has already gained, the king who has deprived his enemy of a great gain, and who has to suffer a greater loss and expenditure, gains an advantage over the other.

original: labdha /lābha /apagamane yasyaamitro lābhena śaktyā hīnaḥ sa pārṣṇi /grāhoatisaṃdhatte /
analyzed: labdha lābha apagamane yasya amitraḥ lābhena śaktyā hīnaḥ sa pārṣṇigrāhaḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two kings, one of whom has deprived his enemy of what he has already gained, and the other of whom has caused his enemy to lose what he has already gained, the king who has caused his enemy to lose what he has already gained, and who is inferior to his enemy in the matter of gain and power, gains an advantage over the other.

original: yasya vā yātavyaḥ śatror vigraha /apakāra /samarthaḥ syāt //
analyzed: yasya vā yātavyaḥ śatroḥ vigraha apakāra samarthaḥ syāt
translated: Or the king who is marching against the enemy of his enemy, and who is capable of rendering help to the enemy of his enemy in the matter of war, gains an advantage over the other.

original: pārṣṇi /grāhayor api yaḥ śakya /ārambha /bala /upādāna /adhikaḥ sthita /śatruḥ pārśva /sthāyī vā soatisaṃdhatte //🔽pārśva /sthāyī hi yātavya /abhisāro mūla /ābādhakaś ca bhavati /
analyzed: pārṣṇigrāhayoḥ api yaḥ sthita śatruḥ pārśva sthāyī vā saḥ atisaṃdhatte  pārśva sthāyī hi yātavya abhisāraḥ mūla ābādhakaḥ ca bhavati
translated: Of the two who are attacking the rear of an enemy, he who is superior in the strength of his army, in the supply of provisions, and in the number of his troops, and who is either situated near the enemy or is a neighbour of the enemy, gains an advantage.🔽For a neighbour is both a source of danger to the rear of the enemy and a source of trouble to the base of the enemy.

original: mūla /ābādhaka eva paścāt /sthāyī //🔽pārṣṇi /grāhās trayo jñeyāḥ śatroś ceṣṭā /nirodhakāḥ /
analyzed: mūla ābādhakaḥ eva paścāt sthāyī  pārṣṇigrāhāḥ trayaḥ jñeyāḥ śatroḥ ceṣṭā nirodhakāḥ
translated: One who is situated in the rear is only a source of trouble to the base of the enemy.🔽Three kinds of enemies are to be known as the obstructers of the movements of an enemy,

original: sāmantaḥ pṛṣṭhato vargaḥ prativeśau ca pārśvayoḥ //
analyzed: sāmantaḥ pṛṣṭhatas vargaḥ prativeśau ca pārśvayoḥ
translated: viz., a neighbour, an army situated in the rear, and a hostile king situated on the flank.

original: arer netuś ca madhyastho durbaloantardhir ucyate /
analyzed: areḥ netuḥ ca madhya sthaḥ durbalaḥ antardhiḥ ucyate
translated: A weak king situated between the conqueror and the enemy is called an interloper.

analyzed: pratighātaḥ balavataḥ durga aṭa vyapasāravān
translated: The interloper of a strong king is said to be one who has forts, wildernesses, and means of escape.

original: madhyamaṃ tvari /vijigīṣvor lipsamānayor madhyamasya pārṣṇiṃ gṛhṇator labdha /lābha /apagamane yo madhyamaṃ mitrād viyojayaty amitraṃ 🔽ca mitram āpnoti soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: madhyamam tu ari vijigīṣvoḥ lipsamānayoḥ madhyamasya pārṣṇim gṛhṇatoḥ labdha lābha apagamane yaḥ madhyamam mitrāt viyojayati amitram  ca mitram āpnoti saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Of the two, the conqueror and the enemy, who are desirous of capturing the territory of a neutral king, he who, having captured the rear of the neutral king, causes the neutral king to abandon his acquired territory and to separate himself from his friend, and who then🔽makes an enemy a friend, gains an advantage.

analyzed: saṃdheyaḥ ca śatruḥ upakurvāṇaḥ
translated: And an enemy who is helpful is to be reconciled.

analyzed: na mitram mitra bhāvāt utkrāntam
translated: But a friend who has ceased to be a friend is not to be reconciled.

analyzed: tena audāsīna lipsā vyākhyātā
translated: By this is explained the desire for neutrality.

analyzed: pārṣṇigrahaṇa abhiyānayoḥ tu mantra yuddhāt abhyuccayaḥ
translated: But in the case of the seizure of the enemy's rear and of marching against him, the use of mantras and war are superior.

analyzed: vyāyāma yuddhe hi kṣaya vyayābhyām ubhayoḥ avṛddhiḥ
translated: But in the case of the enemy’s rear and front, the employment of spies and open war are better than the employment of the army🔽For in a war of open fight, both the conqueror and the conquered do not gain anything, but suffer loss of men and money

original: jitvāapi hi kṣiṇa /daṇḍa /kośaḥ parājito bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: jitvā api hi kṣiṇa daṇḍa kośaḥ parājitaḥ bhavati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: My teacher says that even after conquering the enemy, the conqueror becomes vanquished if he loses his army and treasury

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says not so

original: sumahatāapi kṣaya /vyayena śatru /vināśoabhyupagantavyaḥ //🔽tulye kṣaya /vyaye yaḥ purastād dūṣya /balaṃ ghātayitvā nihśalyaḥ paścād vaśya /balo yudhyeta soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: su mahatā api kṣaya vyayena śatru vināśaḥ abhyupagantavyaḥ  tulye kṣaya vyaye yaḥ purastāt dūṣya balam ghātayitvā nihśalyaḥ paścāt vaśya balaḥ yudhyeta saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Even at the cost of a very heavy loss of men and money, the destruction of the enemy should be accomplished🔽When two kings are equally strong, he who, after destroying the army of the enemy’s ally, fights with his own army free from troubles, gains more than the other

original: dvayor api purastād dūṣya /bala /ghātinor yo bahulataraṃ śaktimattaram atyanta /dūṣyaṃ ca ghātayet soatisaṃdhatte //
analyzed: dvayoḥ api purastāt dūṣya bala ghātinoḥ yaḥ bahulataram śaktimattaram atyanta dūṣyam ca ghātayet saḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: When two kings are equally strong, he who destroys the army of the enemy’s ally which is more numerous, stronger and more disaffected, gains more than the other

analyzed: tena amitra aṭavī bala ghātaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: This explains the destruction of the army of the enemy, wild tribes, and of the army of the conqueror himself

original: pārṣṇi /grāhoabhiyoktā vā yātavyo vā yadā bhavet /
analyzed: pārṣṇigrāhaḥ abhiyoktā vā yātavyaḥ vā yadā bhavet
translated: When the enemy’s rear or front is attacked, or when the conqueror is attacked by the enemy,

original: vijigīṣus tadā tatra netram etat samācaret //
analyzed: vijigīṣuḥ tadā tatra netram etat samācaret
translated: then the conqueror should employ the following expedients

analyzed: pārṣṇigrāhaḥ bhavet netā śatroḥ mitra abhiyoginaḥ
translated: The conqueror should become the leader of the army of the enemy’s ally who is attacking the enemy,

analyzed: vigrāhya pūrvam ākrandam pārṣṇigrāha abhisāriṇā
translated: having previously made an agreement with the king who is marching against the enemy in the rear.

analyzed: ākrandena abhiyuñjānaḥ pārṣṇigrāham nivārayet  tathā ākranda abhisāreṇa pārṣṇigrāha abhisāriṇam
translated: The king who is attacked by the enemy in the rear should ward off the enemy in the rear by making an agreement with the enemy.

analyzed: ari mitreṇa mitram ca purastāt avaghaṭṭayet
translated: Similarly, the king who is attacked by the enemy in the rear should ward off the king who is marching against the enemy in the rear by making an agreement with the enemy in the rear.🔽He should also frighten his friend with the help of his enemy.

original: mitra /mitram areś caapi mitra /mitreṇa vārayet //🔽mitreṇa grāhayet pārṣṇim abhiyuktoabhiyoginaḥ /
analyzed: mitra mitram areḥ ca api mitra mitreṇa vārayet  mitreṇa grāhayet pārṣṇim abhiyuktaḥ abhiyoginaḥ
translated: He should ward off the friend of his enemy with the help of his friend.🔽The king who is attacked by the enemy in the rear should win over the enemy by making an agreement with his friend.

analyzed: mitra mitreṇa ca ākrandam pārṣṇigrāhān nivārayet
translated: And he should ward off the enemy in the rear by making an agreement with the friend of his friend.

analyzed: evam maṇḍalam ātma artham vijigīṣuḥ niveśayet
translated: Thus the conqueror should establish his circle of states for his own benefit.

analyzed: pṛṣṭhatas ca purastāt ca mitra prakṛti sampadā
translated: And with the wealth of friends and allies in the rear and in the front.

original: kṛtsne ca maṇḍale nityaṃ dūtān gūḍhāṃś ca vāsayet /
analyzed: kṛtsne ca maṇḍale nityam dūtān gūḍhān ca vāsayet
translated: And he should always keep spies and secret agents in the entire circle of states.

original: mitra /bhūtaḥ sapatnānāṃ hatvā hatvā ca saṃvṛtaḥ //
analyzed: mitra bhūtaḥ sapatnānām hatvā hatvā ca saṃvṛtaḥ
translated: Having killed and killed again, he should remain concealed as a friend of the enemies.

analyzed: asaṃvṛtasya kāryāṇi prāptāni api viśeṣataḥ
translated: Even the accomplished works of an unconcealed king are destroyed without doubt,🔽like a broken raft in the ocean.

analyzed: nihsaṃśayam vipadyante bhinna plave iva odadhau 🔽hīna śakti pūraṇam
translated: The filling up of the weak points

original: sāmavāyikair evam abhiyukto vijigīṣur yas teṣāṃ pradhānas taṃ brūyāt tvayā me saṃdhiḥ /
analyzed: sāmavāyikaiḥ evam abhiyuktaḥ vijigīṣuḥ yaḥ teṣām pradhānaḥ tam brūyāt tvayā me saṃdhiḥ
translated: When a king is thus attacked by a combination of kings, he should say to the most important among them, ‘I wish to make peace with you.

analyzed: idam hiraṇyam
translated: This is the gold.

analyzed: aham ca mitram
translated: I am your friend.

analyzed: dviguṇā te vṛddhiḥ
translated: Your profit will be double.

analyzed: na arhasi ātma kṣayeṇa mitra mukhān amitrān vardhayitum
translated: It does not behove you to strengthen your enemies under the guise of friends by destroying yourself.

original: ete hi vṛddhās tvām eva paribhaviṣyanti iti //
analyzed: ete hi vṛddhāḥ tvām eva paribhaviṣyanti iti
translated: For these powerful kings will oppress you.’

original: bhedaṃ vā brūyāt anapakāro yathāaham etaiḥ sambhūyaabhiyuktas tathā tvām apy ete saṃhita /balāḥ svasthā vyasane vāabhiyokṣyante /
analyzed: bhedam vā brūyāt anapakāraḥ yathā aham etaiḥ sambhūya abhiyuktaḥ tathā tvām api ete saṃhita balāḥ svasthāḥ vyasane vā abhiyokṣyante
translated: Or he may say, ‘Just as I have been attacked by these kings united together, so will these united kings attack you, whether you are in a prosperous condition or in a calamity.

analyzed: balam hi cittam vikaroti
translated: For power disturbs the mind.

original: tad eṣāṃ vighātaya iti //🔽bhinneṣu pradhānam upagṛhya hīneṣu vikramayet /🔽hīnān anugrāhya vā pradhāne /
analyzed: tat eṣām vighātaye iti  bhinneṣu pradhānam upagṛhya hīneṣu vikramayet  hīnān anugrāhya vā pradhāne
translated: I shall therefore destroy their power.’🔽When they are thus divided, he should win over the most important among them and attack the inferior ones.

original: yathā vā śreyoabhimanyeta tathā //🔽vairaṃ vā parair grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet //
analyzed: yathā vā śreyaḥ abhimanyeta tathā  vairam vā paraiḥ grāhayitvā visaṃvādayet
translated: Or having favoured the inferior kings, he may attack the most important one.🔽Or he may do whatever he thinks to be beneficial.🔽Or having made them take an oath of enmity with each other, he may break the agreement.

original: phala /bhūyastvena vā pradhānam upajāpya saṃdhiṃ kārayet //
analyzed: phala bhūyaḥ tvena vā pradhānam upajāpya saṃdhim kārayet
translated: Or having won over the most important king by offering him a larger share of the profit, he may make peace with him.

original: athaubhaya /vetanāḥ phala /bhūyastvaṃ darśayantaḥ sāmavāyikān atisaṃhitāḥ stha ity udddūṣayeyuḥ //
analyzed: atha aubhayavetanāḥ phala bhūyaḥ tvam darśayantaḥ sāmavāyikān atisaṃhitāḥ stha iti uddūṣayeyuḥ
translated: If the mercenaries show that they are more numerous than the combined forces of the enemy, they may be employed to create disaffection among the allies of the enemy.

original: duṣṭeṣu saṃdhiṃ dūṣayet //🔽athaubhaya /vetanā bhūyo bhedam eṣāṃ kuryuḥ evaṃ tad yad asmābhir darśitam iti //
analyzed: duṣṭeṣu saṃdhim dūṣayet  atha aubhayavetanāḥ bhūyas bhedam eṣām kuryuḥ evam tat yat asmābhiḥ darśitam iti
translated: When the enemy is in a bad condition, he may be attacked.🔽If the mercenaries are more numerous than the combined forces of the enemy, they may be employed to create disaffection among the enemy.

analyzed: bhinneṣu anyatama aupagraheṇa ceṣṭeta
translated: When the enemy is divided, he may be attacked by winning over one of the parties.

analyzed: pradhāna abhāve sāmavāyikānām utsāhayitāram sthira karmāṇam anurakta prakṛktim
translated: In the absence of a leader, the king may employ a person who is capable of inspiring the allies, who is of steady conduct, who is devoted to the king,

original: lobhād bhayād vā saṃghātam upāgataṃ vijigīṣor bhītaṃ rājya /pratisambaddhaṃ mitraṃ
analyzed: lobhāt bhayāt vā saṃghātam upāgatam vijigīṣoḥ bhītam rājya pratisambaddham mitram
translated: who has joined the king out of greed or fear, who is afraid of the conqueror, who is related to the king by marriage, who is a friend,

original: cala /amitraṃ vā pūrvān uttara /abhāve sādhayet utsāhayitāram ātma /nisargeṇa /
analyzed: cala amitram vā pūrvān uttara abhāve sādhayet utsāhayitāram ātma nisargeṇa
translated: or who is a fickle enemy, in order to inspire the allies. He may employ a person who is capable of inspiring the allies by offering him his own kingdom.

analyzed: sthira karmāṇam sāntva praṇipātena
translated: He may employ a person of steady conduct by conciliating and bowing to him.

analyzed: anurakta prakṛtim kanyā dāna yāpanābhyām  lubdham aṃśa dvaiguṇyena
translated: He may employ a person who is devoted to the king by giving him his daughter in marriage and by supporting him.🔽He may employ a greedy person by giving him double the share.

analyzed: bhītam ebhyaḥ kośa daṇḍa anugraheṇa
translated: He may employ a frightened person by giving him the protection of his treasury and army.

analyzed: svatas bhītam viśvāsya pratibhū pradānena
translated: He may employ a person who is afraid of himself by winning his confidence and by giving him a surety.

analyzed: rājya pratisambaddham ekībhāva aupagamanena
translated: in the case of a kingdom, by accepting the sovereignty of the enemy.

analyzed: mitram ubhayatas priya hitābhyām
translated: A friend is so called because he is dear and helpful to both.

analyzed: upakāra tyāgena vā
translated: Or because he is ready to give up his life for the sake of another.

analyzed: cala amitram avadhṛtam anapakāra aupakārābhyām
translated: A wavering friend is so called because he is not sure whether he is helpful or not.

original: yo vā yathāayogaṃ bhajeta taṃ tathā sādhayet /
analyzed: yaḥ vā yathā ayogam bhajeta tam tathā sādhayet
translated: Or he should be treated in the same way as he deserves.

analyzed: sāma dāna bheda daṇḍaiḥ vā yathā āpatsu vyākhyāsyāmaḥ
translated: Or by conciliation, gift, dissension, and punishment, as will be explained in the case of calamities.

original: vyasana /upaghāta /tvarito vā kośa /daṇḍābhyāṃ deśe kāle kārye vāavadhṛtaṃ saṃdhim upeyāt //
analyzed: vyasana aupaghāta tvaritaḥ vā kośa daṇḍābhyām deśe kāle kārye vā avadhṛtam saṃdhim upeyāt
translated: Or he should make peace quickly, having determined the time, place, and work, by means of his treasury and army, in case of calamity.

analyzed: kṛta saṃdhiḥ hīnam ātmānam pratikurvīta
translated: Having made peace, he should remedy his own inferiority.

analyzed: pakṣe hīnaḥ bandhu mitra pakṣam kurvīta
translated: If he is inferior in allies and friends, he should make allies and friends.

analyzed: durgam aviṣahyam vā
translated: Or in a fortress that cannot be assailed.

original: durga /mitra /pratiṣṭabdho hi sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca pūjyo bhavati //
analyzed: durga mitra pratiṣṭabdhaḥ hi sveṣām pareṣām ca pūjyaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who is supported by a fortress and allies becomes respectable to his own people and to the enemy.

analyzed: mantra śakti hīnaḥ prājña puruṣa aupacayam vidyā vṛddha samyogam vā kurvīta
translated: If he is deficient in the power of counsel, he should increase the number of wise men, or associate with the learned.

analyzed: tathā hi sadyas śreyaḥ prāpnoti
translated: For in this way he quickly attains prosperity.

analyzed: prabhāva hīnaḥ prakṛti yogakṣema siddhau yateta
translated: If he is deficient in power, he should strive for the accomplishment of the acquisition and security of his own people.

analyzed: janapadaḥ sarva karmaṇām yoniḥ
translated: The country is the source of all activities.

analyzed: tatas prabhāvaḥ
translated: From it comes power.

analyzed: tasya sthānam ātmanaḥ ca āpadi durgam
translated: Its place is a fortress for oneself in times of danger.

analyzed: setubandhaḥ sasyānām yoniḥ
translated: The construction of embankments is the source of crops.

analyzed: nitya anuṣaktaḥ hi varṣa guṇa lābhaḥ setuvāpeṣu
translated: For, the benefits of rain are always associated with embankments.

analyzed: vaṇikpathaḥ para atisaṃdhānasya yoniḥ
translated: The trade route is the source of dealing with others.

original: vaṇik /pathena hi daṇḍa /gūḍha /puruṣa /atinayanaṃ śastra /āvaraṇa /yāna /vāhana /krayaś ca kriyate /
analyzed: vaṇikpathena hi daṇḍa gūḍha puruṣa atinayanam śastra āvaraṇa yāna vāhana krayaḥ ca kriyate
translated: For, through the trade route, spies disguised as traders can be brought in, and weapons, armor, vehicles, and conveyances can be purchased.

analyzed: praveśaḥ nirṇayanam ca  khaniḥ saṃgrāma aupakaraṇānām yoniḥ
translated: Entry and exit are also possible.🔽The mine is the source of war equipment.

analyzed: dravya vanam durga karmaṇām yāna rathayoḥ ca
translated: The forest of materials is for fortress work and for vehicles and chariots.

analyzed: hasti vanam hastinām
translated: The elephant forest is for elephants.

analyzed: gava aśva khara oṣṭrāṇām ca vrajaḥ
translated: And the pen is for cows, horses, donkeys, and camels.

analyzed: teṣām alābhe bandhu mitra kulebhyaḥ samārjanam
translated: In case of their non-availability, they should be obtained from relatives, friends, and families.

original: utsāha /hīnaḥ śreṇī /pravīra /puruṣāṇāṃ cora /gaṇa /āṭavika /mleccha /jātīnāṃ para /apakāriṇāṃ gūḍha /puruṣāṇāṃ ca yathā /lābbham upacayaṃ
analyzed: utsāha hīnaḥ śreṇī pravīra puruṣāṇām cora gaṇa āṭavika mleccha jātīnām para apakāriṇām gūḍha puruṣāṇām ca yathālābbham upacayam
translated: One should make provisions for those who lack enthusiasm, for the best men in the guilds, for groups of thieves, forest tribes, and barbarian castes, for those who harm others, and for hidden spies, as much as possible.

analyzed: kurvīta
translated: He should do this.

analyzed: para miśra apratīkāram ā balīyasam vā pareṣu prayuñjīta
translated: He should employ against the enemy the superior, the mixed, the inferior, or the most inferior kind of forces, as the case may be.

original: evaṃ pakṣeṇa mantreṇa dravyeṇa ca balena ca /
analyzed: evam pakṣeṇa mantreṇa dravyeṇa ca balena ca
translated: Thus, with a good ally, with good counsel, with good resources, and with good forces,

analyzed: sampannaḥ pratinirgacchet paraavagraham ātmanaḥ e
translated: he should march out to meet the enemy’s attack.

analyzed: vigṛhya auparodha hetavaḥ daṇḍa aupanata vṛttam
translated: The causes of war and the conduct of a conquered king

original: durbalo rājā balavatāabhiyuktas tad /viśiṣṭa /balam āśrayeta yam itaro mantra /śaktyā naatisaṃdadhyāt //
analyzed: durbalaḥ rājā balavatā abhiyuktaḥ tad viśiṣṭa balam āśrayeta yam itaraḥ mantra śaktyā na atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: A weak king, when attacked by a powerful king, should seek the protection of a king who is superior to the latter and whom the latter cannot overpower by the power of his counsel.

analyzed: tulya mantra śaktīnām āyatta sampadaḥ vṛddha samyogāt vā viśeṣaḥ
translated: If the power of counsel is equal, the difference is due to the possession of resources or to the connection with a powerful king.

original: viśiṣṭa /bala /abhāve sama /balais tulya /bala /saṃghair vā balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhed yān na mantra /prabhāva /śaktibhyām atisaṃdadhyāt
analyzed: viśiṣṭa bala abhāve sama balaiḥ tulya bala saṃghaiḥ vā balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhet yān na mantra prabhāva śaktibhyām atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: In the absence of a superior king, he should, in combination with kings of equal power or with a number of kings of equal power, stand by the side of a powerful king whom he cannot overpower by the power of his counsel or by the power of his resources.

analyzed: tulya mantra prabhāva śaktīnām vipula ārambhataḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: If the power of counsel and the power of resources are equal, the difference is due to the vastness of the preparations.

original: sama /bala /abhāve hīna /balaiḥ śucibhir utsāhibhiḥ pratyanīka /bhūtair balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhed yān na mantra /prabhāva /utsāha /śaktibhir 🔽atisaṃdadhyāt //🔽tulya /utsāha /śaktīnāṃ sva /yuddha /bhūmi /lābhād viśeṣaḥ //
analyzed: sama bala abhāve hīna balaiḥ śucibhiḥ utsāhibhiḥ pratyanīka bhūtaiḥ balavataḥ sambhūya tiṣṭhet yān na mantra prabhāva autsāha śaktibhiḥ  atisaṃdadhyāt  tulya autsāha śaktīnām sva yuddha bhūmi lābhāt viśeṣaḥ
translated: When there is no power equal to his, he should, in combination with weak but pure and energetic kings, stand against a powerful enemy, whom he cannot overpower by the strength of his own counsel, power, energy and resources.🔽When the energy and power of the allies are equal, the superiority is due to the acquisition of the battle-ground.

analyzed: tulya bhūmīnām sva yuddha kāla lābhāt viśeṣaḥ
translated: When the battle-ground is equal, the superiority is due to the acquisition of the time of battle.

analyzed: tulya deśa kālānām yugya śastra āvaraṇataḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: When the country and time are equal, the superiority is due to the possession of chariots, weapons and armour.

original: sahāya /abhāve durgam āśrayeta yatraamitraḥ prabhūta /sainyoapi bhakta /yavasa /indhana /udaka /uparodhaṃ na kuryāt svayaṃ ca kṣaya /vyayābhyāṃ 🔽yujyeta //
analyzed: sahāya abhāve durgam āśrayeta yatra amitraḥ prabhūta sainyaḥ api bhakta yava saindhana audaka auparodham na kuryāt svayam ca kṣaya vyayābhyām  yujyeta
translated: In the absence of allies, he should resort to a fortress where even a powerful enemy cannot obstruct the supply of food, fodder, fuel and water, and where he himself can be engaged in reducing his own strength and resources.

analyzed: tulya durgāṇām nicaya apasārataḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: When the fortresses are equal, the superiority is due to the possession of stores and the possibility of retreat.

original: nicaya /apasāra /sampannaṃ hi manuṣya /durgam icched iti kauṭilyaḥ //
analyzed: nicaya apasāra sampannam hi manuṣya durgam icchet iti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: For, says Kautilya, a fortress is a human fortress which is well-supplied with stores and the possibility of retreat.

original: tad ebhiḥ kārṇair āśrayeta pārṣṇi /grāham āsāraṃ madhyamam udāsīnaṃ vā pratipādayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: tat ebhiḥ kārṇaiḥ āśrayeta pārṣṇigrāham āsāram madhyamam udāsīnam vā pratipādayiṣyāmi
translated: For these reasons, he should resort to a fortress with the intention of destroying the enemy's rear, or of attacking an ally, or of attacking a madhyama king, or of attacking a neutral king.

original: sāmanta /āṭavika /tat /kulīna /aparuddhānām anyatamenaasya rājyaṃ hārayiṣyāmi ghātayiṣyāmi vā //
analyzed: sāmanta āṭavika tad kulīna aparuddhānām anyatamena asya rājyam hārayiṣyāmi ghātayiṣyāmi vā
translated: I shall cause his kingdom to be seized or destroyed by one of his neighbours, foresters, or kinsmen.

original: kṛtya /pakṣa /upagraheṇa vāasya durge rāṣṭre skandha /āvāre vā kopaṃ samutthāpayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: kṛtya pakṣa aupagraheṇa vā asya durge rāṣṭre skandhaāvāre vā kopam samutthāpayiṣyāmi
translated: Or, by taking up his side in a matter of dispute, I shall cause him to be angry with his fort, country, or army.

original: śastra /agni /rasa /praṇidhānair aupaniṣadikair vā yathā /iṣṭam āsannaṃ haniṣyāmi //
analyzed: śastra agni rasa praṇidhānaiḥ aupaniṣadikaiḥ vā yathā āiṣṭam āsannam haniṣyāmi
translated: Or, I shall kill him by means of weapons, fire, poison, or by any other means that may be suitable.

original: svayaṃ /adhiṣṭhitena vā yoga /praṇidhānena kṣaya /vyayam enam upaneṣyāmi /
analyzed: svayam adhiṣṭhitena vā yoga praṇidhānena kṣaya vyayam enam upaneṣyāmi
translated: Or, by myself taking up the command, I shall bring about his ruin and destruction.

original: kṣaya /vyaya /pravāsa /upatapte vāasya mitra /varge sainye vā krameṇaupajāpaṃ prāpsyāmi //🔽vīvadha /āsāra /prasāra /vadhena vāasya skandha /āvāra /avagrahaṃ kariṣyāmi /
analyzed: kṣaya vyaya pravāsa aupatapte vā aasya mitra varge sainye vā krameṇa aupajāpam prāpsyāmi  vīvadha āsāra prasāra vadhena vā asya skandha āvāra avagraham kariṣyāmi
translated: Or, when his friends, army, or camp are afflicted by loss, destruction, or exile, I shall gradually win over his men.🔽Or, by killing his army, I shall seize his camp.

original: daṇḍa /upanayena vāasya randhram utthāpya sarva /saṃdohena prahariṣyāmi /
analyzed: daṇḍaupanayena vā aasya randhram utthāpya sarvasaṃdohena prahariṣyāmi
translated: Or, by causing him to march out his army, I shall attack him with all my forces.

analyzed: pratihata autsāhena vā yathāiṣṭam saṃdhim avāpsyāmi
translated: Or, when his enthusiasm is damped, I shall make peace on my own terms.

original: mayi pratibaddhasya vā sarvataḥ kopāḥ samutthāsyanti //
analyzed: mayi pratibaddhasya vā sarvatas kopāḥ samutthāsyanti
translated: Or, when he is dependent on me, all his enemies will rise against him.

analyzed: nirāsāram vā asya mūlam mitra aṭavī daṇḍaiḥ uddhātayiṣyāmi
translated: or I shall destroy his root which is free from danger by means of my friends, forests and armies.

original: mahato vā deśasya yoga /kṣemam ihasthaḥ pālayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: mahataḥ vā deśasya yogakṣemam ihasthaḥ pālayiṣyāmi
translated: or I shall protect the welfare and security of a large country from here.

original: sva /vikṣiptaṃ mitra /vikṣiptaṃ vā me sainyam ihasthasyaekastham aviṣahyaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: sva vikṣiptam mitra vikṣiptam vā me sainyam ihasthasya ekastham aviṣahyam bhaviṣyati
translated: or my army which is scattered here and there or which is scattered by my enemies will become invincible when concentrated here.

original: nimna /khāta /rātri /yuddha /viśāradaṃ vā me sainyaṃ pathya /ābādha /muktam āsanne karma kariṣyati //
analyzed: nimna khāta rātri yuddha viśāradam vā me sainyam pathya ābādha muktam āsanne karma kariṣyati
translated: or my army which is skilled in fighting in low lands, trenches and at night and which is free from the troubles of the road will do the work near at hand.

original: viruddha /deśa /kālam iha /āgato vā svayam eva kṣaya /vyayābhyāṃ na bhaviṣyati /🔽mahā /kṣaya /vyaya /abhigamyoayaṃ deśo durga /aṭavy /apasāra /bāhulyāt //
analyzed: viruddha deśa kālam iha āgataḥ vā svayam eva kṣaya vyayābhyām na bhaviṣyati  mahā kṣaya vyaya abhigamyaḥ ayam deśaḥ durga aṭa vyapasāra bāhulyāt
translated: or having come here at a time and place unfavourable to my enemy, I shall not perish by destruction and loss, as I am here.🔽or this country is to be approached with great destruction and loss, as it is full of forts, forests and inaccessible places.

analyzed: pareṣām vyādhi prāyaḥ sainya vyāyāmānām alabdha bhaumaḥ ca
translated: or the army of the enemy is mostly diseased and has not obtained a foothold.

analyzed: tam āpad gataḥ pravekṣyati
translated: or I shall enter it when it is in a state of calamity.

analyzed: praviṣṭaḥ vā na nirgamiṣyati iti
translated: or having entered it, I shall not come out again.

original: kāraṇa /abhāve bala /samucchraye vā parasya durgam unmucyaapagacchet //
analyzed: kāraṇa abhāve bala samucchraye vā parasya durgam unmucya apagacchet
translated: or in the absence of such causes or when the enemy’s army is strong, I shall leave the fort and go away.

analyzed: agni pataṅga vat amitre vā praviśet
translated: or like fire and moths, I shall enter the enemy.

original: anyatara /siddhir hi tyakta /ātmano bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: anyatara siddhiḥ hi tyakta ātmanaḥ bhavati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: For, say the teachers, the success of one who has abandoned his own self belongs to another.

original: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //🔽saṃdheyatām ātmanaḥ parasya caupalabhya saṃdadhīta //
analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ  saṃdheya tām ātmanaḥ parasya ca aupalabhya saṃdadhīta
translated: Kautilya, however, says not so.🔽Having ascertained the possibility of making peace with himself as well as with his enemy, he shall make peace.

original: viparyaye vikrameṇa saṃdhim apasāraṃ vā lipseta //🔽saṃdheyasya vā dūtaṃ preṣayet //
analyzed: viparyaye vikrameṇa saṃdhim apasāram vā lipseta  saṃdheyasya vā dūtam preṣayet
translated: In the contrary case, he shall seek peace or separation by force.🔽Or he shall send an ambassador to the assailable enemy.

original: tena vā preṣitam artha /mānābhyāṃ satkṛtya brūyāt idaṃ rājñaḥ paṇya /agāram /
analyzed: tena vā preṣitam artha mānābhyām satkṛtya brūyāt idam rājñaḥ paṇyaagāram
translated: Having honoured the ambassador sent by the enemy with gifts and honours, he shall say This is the kings emporium.🔽This is the queens.

analyzed: idam devī kumārāṇām  devī kumāra vacanāt
translated: This is for the princes.

original: idaṃ rājyam ahaṃ ca tvad /arpaṇaḥ iti //
analyzed: idam rājyam aham ca tvad arpaṇaḥ iti
translated: This kingdom and I myself are at your disposal, at the command of the queen and the princes.

analyzed: labdha saṃśrayaḥ samayaācārika vat bhartari varteta
translated: Having obtained the protection of the king, he shall behave towards his master as if he were a servant under the rules of service.

original: durga /ādīni ca karmāṇi āvāha /vivāha /putra /abhiṣeka /aśva /paṇya /hasti /grahaṇa /sattra /yātrā /vihāra /gamanāni caanujñātaḥ kurvīta
analyzed: durga ādīni ca karmāṇi āvāha vivāha putra abhiṣeka aśva paṇya hasti grahaṇa sattra yātrā vihāra gamanāni ca anujñātaḥ kurvīta
translated: With the permission of the king, he shall do all acts such as the construction of forts and other works, the celebration of marriages and other ceremonies, the installation of his son, the acceptance of horses, elephants, and other presents, the holding of sacrifices, the celebration of festivals, and the going on pleasure trips.

original: sva /bhūmy /avasthita /prakṛti /saṃdhim upaghātam apasṛteṣu vā sarvam anujñātaḥ kurvīta //
analyzed: sva bhūmi avasthita prakṛti saṃdhim upaghātam apasṛteṣu vā sarvam anujñātaḥ kurvīta
translated: Having obtained the protection of the king, he shall do all acts such as the making of peace with his own people who are in a position to help him, and the destruction of those who have gone away from his allegiance.

original: duṣṭa /paura /jānapado vā nyāya /vṛttir anyāṃ bhūmiṃ yāceta //
analyzed: duṣṭa paura jānapadaḥ vā nyāya vṛttiḥ anyām bhūmim yāceta
translated: Or, if his citizens and people are disaffected, he shall, behaving justly, ask for another country.

analyzed: duṣya vat upāṃśu daṇḍena vā pratikurvīta
translated: Or he may punish him secretly like a thief.

original: ucitāṃ vā mitrād bhūmiṃ dīyamānāṃ na pratigṛhṇīyāt //
analyzed: ucitām vā mitrāt bhūmim dīyamānām na pratigṛhṇīyāt
translated: Or he may not accept the land offered by a friend, if it is not suitable.

analyzed: mantri purohita senāpati yuvarājānām anyatamam adṛśyamāne bhartari paśyet
translated: If the master is not seen, he should see one of the ministers, priest, general, or crown prince.

analyzed: yathāśakti ca upakuryāt
translated: And he should render help to the extent of his ability.

analyzed: daivata svastivācaneṣu tad parāḥ āśiṣaḥ vācayet
translated: At the recitation of prayers to the gods, he should utter blessings that are directed towards the master.

analyzed: sarvatra ātma nisargam guṇam brūyāt
translated: Everywhere he should speak of his own natural qualities.

analyzed: samyukta balavat sevī viruddhaḥ śaṅkita ādibhiḥ
translated: He should associate with those who are united, strong, and powerful, and be suspicious of those who are opposed.

analyzed: varteta daṇḍa aupanataḥ bhartari evam avasthitaḥ
translated: Thus, being under the control of the rod of punishment, he should conduct himself towards the master.

analyzed: daṇḍa aupanāyi vṛttam
translated: The Conduct of One Under the Control of the Rod of Punishment

original: anujñāta /saṃdhi /paṇa /udvega /karaṃ balavān vijigīṣamāṇo yataḥ sva /bhūmiḥ sva /ṛtu /vṛttiś ca sva /sainyānām /
analyzed: anujñāta saṃdhi paṇa audvega karam balavān vijigīṣamāṇaḥ yatas sva bhūmiḥ sva ṛtu vṛttiḥ ca sva sainyānām
translated: When a powerful conqueror, who has been permitted to make peace and receive tribute, wishes to march out from where his own land and the proper season for his own troops are,

original: adurga /apasāraḥ śatrur /apārṣṇir anāsāraś ca / tato yāyāt //
analyzed: a durga apasāraḥ śatruḥ apārṣṇiḥ an āsāraḥ ca tatas yāyāt
translated: from where his enemy has no fort or escape, no rear or supply, he should march out.

analyzed: viparyaye kṛta pratīkāraḥ yāyāt  sāma dānābhyām durbalān upanamayet
translated: If the opposite is the case, he should march out after making preparations.🔽He should bring the weak under his control through conciliation and gifts.

analyzed: bheda daṇḍābhyām balavataḥ
translated: The strong through dissension and punishment.

analyzed: niyoga vikalpa samuccayaiḥ ca aupāyānām anantara eka antarāḥ prakṛtīḥ sādhayet
translated: He should employ the expedients of negotiation, division, and conciliation, either simultaneously or in succession, to secure the services of the immediate and proximate allies.

original: grāma /araṇya /upajīvi /vraja /vaṇik /patha /anupālanam ujjhita /apasṛta /apakāriṇāṃ caarpaṇam iti sāntvam ācaret //
analyzed: grāma araṇya aupajīvi vraja vaṇikpatha anupālanam ujjhita apasṛta apakāriṇām ca arpaṇam iti sāntvam ācaret
translated: He should adopt the policy of conciliation by protecting the inhabitants of villages and forests, herdsmen and traders, and by handing over to the king those who have deserted him or who are inimical to him.

original: bhūmi /dravya /kanyā /dānam abhayasya caiti dānam ācaret //🔽sāmanta /āṭavika /tat /kulīna /aparuddhānām anyatama /upagraheṇa kośa /daṇḍa /bhūmi /dāya /yācanam iti bhedam ācaret //
analyzed: bhūmi dravya kanyā dānam abhayasya ca eti dānam ācaret  sāmanta āṭavika tad kulīna aparuddhānām anyatama aupagraheṇa kośa daṇḍa bhūmi dāya yācanam iti bhedam ācaret
translated: He should adopt the policy of gifts by giving land, wealth, and maidens, and by granting immunity from punishment.🔽He should adopt the policy of division by seeking to obtain the help of one of the enemy's neighbours, wild tribes, or his disaffected kinsmen.

analyzed: prakāśa kūṭa tūṣṇīm yuddha durga lambha aupāyaiḥ amitra pragrahaṇam iti daṇḍam ācaret
translated: He should adopt the policy of punishment by capturing the enemy by means of open war, by stratagem, by sudden attack, or by taking shelter in a fortress.

analyzed: evam utsāhavataḥ daṇḍa aupakāriṇaḥ sthāpayet
translated: Thus he should employ those who are energetic in the service of the army.

analyzed: sva prabhāvavataḥ kośa aupakāriṇaḥ
translated: Those who are powerful in the service of the treasury.

analyzed: prajñāvataḥ bhūmi upakāriṇaḥ
translated: And those who are wise in the service of the land.

original: teṣāṃ paṇya /pattana /grāma /khani /saṃjātena ratna /sāra /phalgu /kupyena dravya /hasti /vana /vraja /samutthena yāna /vāhanena vā yad bahuśa
analyzed: teṣām paṇya pattana grāma khani saṃjātena ratna sāra phalgu kupyena dravya hasti vana vraja samutthena yāna vāhanena vā yat bahuśas
translated: By means of the precious, valuable, and worthless articles produced from trading towns, villages, and mines, or by means of the conveyances and vehicles produced from elephant forests and herds, he should make gifts to them of whatever is most abundant.

analyzed: upakaroti tat citra bhogam
translated: That which helps with a variety of things is of varied enjoyment.

original: yad daṇḍena kośena vā mahad upakaroti tan mahā /bhogam //
analyzed: yat daṇḍena kośena vā mahat upakaroti tat mahā bhogam
translated: That which helps greatly with the army and treasury is of great enjoyment.

analyzed: yat daṇḍa kośa bhūmībhiḥ upakaroti tat sarva bhogam
translated: That which helps with the army, treasury, and land is of all enjoyment.

original: yad amitram ekataḥ pratikaroti tad ekato /bhogi //
analyzed: yat amitram ekatas pratikaroti tat ekatobhogi
translated: That which helps against an enemy on one side is of one-sided enjoyment.

original: yad amitram āsāraṃ caubhayataḥ pratikaroti tad ubhayato /bhogi //
analyzed: yat amitram āsāram ca aubhayatas pratikaroti tat ubhayatobhogi
translated: That which helps against an enemy and a supporter on both sides is of two-sided enjoyment.

original: yad amitra /āsāra /prativeśa /āṭavikān sarvataḥ pratikaroti tat sarvato /bhogi //
analyzed: yat amitra āsāra prativeśa āṭavikān sarvatas pratikaroti tat sarvatobhogi
translated: That which helps against an enemy, supporter, neighbor, and wild tribe on all sides is of all-sided enjoyment.

original: pārṣṇi /grāhaś caāṭavikaḥ śatru /mukhyaḥ śatrur vā bhūmi /dāna /sādhyaḥ kaścid āsādyeta /
analyzed: pārṣṇigrāhaḥ ca āṭavikaḥ śatru mukhyaḥ śatruḥ vā bhūmi dāna sādhyaḥ kaścid āsādyeta
translated: If an enemy, a wild tribe, a chief enemy, or an enemy who can be subdued by giving land should approach,

analyzed: nirguṇayā bhūmyā enam upagrāhayet  apratisambaddhayā durga stham
translated: he should be won over with land of poor quality.🔽If he is in a fortress, with land that is not connected.

analyzed: nirupajīvyayā āṭavikam  pratyādeyayā tad kulīnam śatroḥ
translated: If he is a wild tribe, with land that is not productive.🔽If he is of noble family, with land that is not to be taken back.

analyzed: apacchinnayā śatroḥ aparuddham nitya amitrayā śreṇī balam
translated: If he is an enemy who has been besieged, with land that is cut off. If it is a permanent enemy, with the army of a guild.

analyzed: balavat sāmantayā saṃhata balam
translated: If it is a united army, with land that is powerful in a neighboring region.

analyzed: ubhābhyām yuddhe pratilomam
translated: In a battle with both, the opposite.

analyzed: a labdha vyāyāmayā a utsāhinam
translated: If it is an energetic person, with land that is not used for exercise.

analyzed: śūyayā aripakṣīyam
translated: by the Suyya, the enemy;

analyzed: karśitayā aapavāhitam
translated: by the Karshiti, the defeated;

analyzed: mahā kṣaya vyaya niveśayā gata pratyāgatam
translated: by the Mahakshaya, Vyaya and Nivesha, the gone and returned;

analyzed: anapāśrayayā pratyapasṛtam
translated: by the Anapasraya, the retreated;

analyzed: pareṇa anadhivāsyayā svayam eva bhartāram upagrāhayet
translated: by the Parena Adhivasya, she should herself win over her husband.

original: teṣāṃ mahā /upakāraṃ nirvikāraṃ caanuvartayet //🔽pratilomam upāṃśunā sādhayet //🔽upakāriṇam upakāra /śaktyā toṣayet //
analyzed: teṣām mahā upakāram nirvikāram ca anuvartayet  pratilomam upāṃśunā sādhayet  upakāriṇam upakāra śaktyā toṣayet
translated: She should follow them with great help and without any change of heart.🔽She should accomplish the opposite by secret means.🔽She should satisfy those who have helped her to the best of her ability.

analyzed: prayāsataḥ ca artha mānau kuryāt
translated: And she should bestow wealth and honour on those who strive for her.

analyzed: vyasaneṣu ca anugraham
translated: And she should show favour to those in distress.

analyzed: svayam āgatānām yathā iṣṭa darśanam pratividhānam ca kuryāt
translated: She should show those who come to her of their own accord whatever sight they desire and provide for them.

analyzed: paribhava aupaghāta kutsa ativādān ca eṣu na prayuñjīta
translated: She should not use insults, violence, contempt or harsh words towards them.

analyzed: dattvā ca abhayam pitā iva anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: And having granted them protection, she should favour them like a father.

original: yaś caasyaapakuryāt tad doṣam abhivikhyāpya prakāśam enaṃ ghātayet //
analyzed: yaḥ ca asya apakuryāt tat doṣam abhivikhyāpya prakāśam enam ghātayet
translated: And if anyone should harm her, she should have him killed in public after proclaiming his crime.

analyzed: para audvega kāraṇāt vā dāṇḍa karmika vat ceṣṭeta
translated: Or, in order to cause alarm to the enemy, she should act like one who carries out the king's orders.

analyzed: na ca hatasya bhūmi dravya putra dārān abhimanyeta
translated: And she should not covet the land, wealth, sons or wives of one who has been killed.

original: kulyān apy asya sveṣu pātreṣu sthāpayet //
analyzed: kulyān api asya sveṣu pātreṣu sthāpayet
translated: He should also place his kinsmen in their own offices.

analyzed: karmaṇi mṛtasya putram rājye sthāpayet
translated: He should install the son of a king who dies while engaged in military operations on the throne.

analyzed: evam asya daṇḍa aupanatāḥ putra pautrān anuvartante
translated: Thus his enemies, conquered by him, will follow his sons and grandsons.

original: yas tuupanatān hatvā baddhvā vā bhūmi /dravya /putra /dārān abhimanyeta tasyaudvignaṃ maṇḍalam abhāvāyauttiṣṭhate //
analyzed: yaḥ tu upanatān hatvā baddhvā vā bhūmi dravya putra dārān abhimanyeta tasya audvignam maṇḍalam abhāvāya uttiṣṭhate
translated: But he who, having conquered or captured his enemies, appropriates their lands, wealth, sons, and wives, will find his circle of states alarmed and rising against him.

original: ye caasyaamātyāḥ sva /bhūmiṣv āyattās te caasyaudvignā maṇḍalam āśrayante //
analyzed: ye ca asya amātyāḥ sva bhūmiṣu āyattāḥ te ca asya audvignāḥ maṇḍalam āśrayante
translated: And those ministers of his who are dependent on their own lands will, being alarmed, seek the protection of his enemies.

analyzed: svayam vā rājyam prāṇān vā asya abhimanyante
translated: Or they will themselves appropriate his kingdom or his life.
