analyzed: deśavihāraḥ karma śramam avadhā artham alpam bhakṣayati bhakṣayitvā ca bhūyas karmasu yogam gacchati  rāja vihāraḥ tu svayam vallabhaiḥ ca svayaṃgrāha praṇaya paṇya agāra kārya aupagrahaiḥ pīḍayati iti
translated: The country is the source of the king’s livelihood, and the king is the protector of the country.🔽The country is the source of the king’s livelihood, and the king is the protector of the country.🔽The country is the source of the king’s livelihood, and the king is the protector of the country.🔽The country is the source of the king’s livelihood, and the king is the protector of the country.

original: subhagā /kumārayoḥ kumāraḥ svayaṃ vallabhaiś ca svayaṃ /grāha /praṇaya /paṇya /agāra /kārya /upagrahaiḥ pīḍayati /🔽subhagā vilāsa /upabhogena ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: subhagā kumārayoḥ kumāraḥ svayam vallabhaiḥ ca svayaṃgrāha praṇaya paṇya agāra kārya aupagrahaiḥ pīḍayati  subhagā vilāsa aupabhogena iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The country is the source of the king’s livelihood, and the king is the protector of the country.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: The country is the source of the

analyzed: śakyaḥ kumāraḥ mantri purohitābhyām vārayitum
translated: The prince can be restrained by the ministers and priests.

original: na subhagā bāliśyād anarthya /jana /samyogāc caiti //🔽śreṇī /mukhyayoḥ śreṇī bāhulyād anavagrahā steya /sāhasābhyāṃ pīḍayati /
analyzed: na subhagā bāliśyāt anarthya jana samyogāt ca eti  śreṇī mukhyayoḥ śreṇī bāhulyāt anavagrahā steya sāhasābhyām pīḍayati
translated: But the people are not fortunate because of their foolishness and association with undeserving people.🔽The teachers say that a guild is difficult to control because of its large numbers, and it oppresses by theft and violence.

analyzed: mukhyaḥ kārya anugraha vighātābhyām iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The chief oppresses by obstructing the granting of favors and by obstructing the performance of duties.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says, No.

analyzed: su vyāvartyā śreṇī samāna śīla vyasana tvāt
translated: A guild is easily controlled because of its uniform conduct and habits.

analyzed: śreṇī mukhya ekadeśa aupagraheṇa vā
translated: Or by winning over a part of the guild and its chief.

original: stambha /yukto mukhyaḥ para /prāṇa /dravya /upaghātābhyāṃ pīḍayatiiti //🔽samnidhātṛ /samāhartroḥ samnidhātā kṛta /vidūṣaṇa /atyayābhyāṃ pīḍayati /
analyzed: stambha yuktaḥ mukhyaḥ para prāṇa dravya aupaghātābhyām pīḍayati iti  samnidhātṛ samāhartroḥ samnidhātā kṛta vidūṣaṇa atyayābhyām pīḍayati
translated: The teachers say that a chief who is obstinate oppresses by injuring the life and property of others.

original: samāhartā karaṇa /adhiṣṭhitaḥ pradiṣṭa /phala /upabhogī bhavati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: samāhartā karaṇa adhiṣṭhitaḥ pradiṣṭa phala aupabhogī bhavati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teachers say that a collector oppresses by causing the waste and loss of what has been done, and that a superintendent who is in charge of the means of production enjoys the fruits that are prescribed.

original: naiti kauṭilyaḥ //🔽samnidhātā kṛta /avastham anyaiḥ kośa /praveśyaṃ pratigṛhṇāti /
analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ  samnidhātā kṛta avastham anyaiḥ kośa praveśyam pratigṛhṇāti
translated: Kautilya says, No.🔽The collector receives what is to be deposited in the treasury by others who have already done their work.

original: samāhartā tu pūrvam artham ātmanaḥ kṛtvā paścād rāja /arthaṃ karoti praṇāśayati vā /
analyzed: samāhartā tu pūrvam artham ātmanaḥ kṛtvā paścāt rāja artham karoti praṇāśayati vā
translated: But the superintendent first does the work himself and then does the kings work or causes it to be done.

original: para /sva /ādāne ca sva /pratyayaś caratiiti //🔽anta /pāla /vaidehakayor anta /pālaś cora /prasarga /deya /atyādānābhyāṃ vaṇik /pathaṃ pīḍayati /
analyzed: para sva ādāne ca sva pratyayaḥ carati iti  antapāla vaidehakayoḥ antapālaḥ cora prasarga deya atyādānābhyām vaṇikpatham pīḍayati
translated: and in the case of the seizure of another’s property, the king himself should personally supervise the investigation.🔽The teacher says that between the superintendent of a border-town and the lord of a country, the superintendent of a border-town oppresses the trade-route by letting thieves go free and by excessive taxation.

original: vaidehakās tu paṇya / /pratipaṇya /anugrahaiḥ prasādhayanti ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: vaidehakāḥ tu paṇya pratipaṇya anugrahaiḥ prasādhayanti iti ācāryāḥ
translated: But the lord of a country prospers by favouring the sale and purchase of merchandise.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says not so.

analyzed: antapālaḥ paṇya sampāta anugraheṇa vartayati
translated: The superintendent of a border-town prospers by favouring the sale and purchase of merchandise.

original: vaidehakās tu sambhūya paṇyānām utkarṣa /apakarṣaṃ kurvāṇāḥ paṇe paṇa /śataṃ kumbhe kumbha /śatam ity ājīvanti //
analyzed: vaidehakāḥ tu sambhūya paṇyānām utkarṣa apakarṣam kurvāṇāḥ paṇe paṇa śatam kumbhe kumbha śatam iti ājīvanti
translated: But the lord of a country, by combining together, increases and decreases the price of merchandise, and thus lives by exacting one pana for every hundred panas of merchandise and one kumbha for every hundred kumbhas of merchandise.🔽The teacher says that land which is occupied by the high-born is better than land occupied by herds of cattle.

original: abhijāta /uparuddhā bhūmiḥ paśu /vraja /uparuddhā vāiti abhijāta /uparuddhā bhūmiḥ mahā /phalāapy āyudhīya /upakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayituṃ
analyzed: abhijātā auparuddhā bhūmiḥ paśu vrajā auparuddhā vā iti abhijātā auparuddhā bhūmiḥ mahā phalā api āyudhīyā aupakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayitum
translated: But Kautilya says that land which is occupied by herds of cattle is better than land occupied by the high-born. Land occupied by the high-born, though productive of much revenue, is not fit to be taken away, as it is useful for the maintenance of the army.

analyzed: paśu vrajā auparuddhā tu kṛṣi yogyā kṣamā mokṣayitum
translated: But land occupied by herds of cattle is fit to be taken away, as it is fit for cultivation.

original: vivītaṃ hi kṣetreṇa bādhyate ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: vivītam hi kṣetreṇa bādhyate iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teacher says that a pasture-land is obstructed by a cultivated field.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says not so.

original: abhijāta /uparuddhā bhūmir atyanta /mahā /upakārāapi kṣamā mokṣayituṃ vyasana /ābādha /bhayāt /
analyzed: abhijātā auparuddhā bhūmiḥ atyanta mahā upakārā api kṣamā mokṣayitum vyasana ābādha bhayāt
translated: The land which is occupied by the aboriginals is very useful to the conqueror, but it is not proper to take it away from them, lest it should cause them to be disaffected.

original: paśu /vraja /uparuddhā tu kośa /vāhana /upakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayitum /
analyzed: paśu vrajā auparuddhā tu kośa vāhana aupakāriṇī na kṣamā mokṣayitum
translated: But the land which is occupied by herdsmen is useful to the conqueror in supplying him with fodder and conveyance; it is not proper to take it away from them.

analyzed: anyatra sasya vāpa auparodhāt iti
translated: Except when it is necessary to sow crops on it.

analyzed: pratirodhaka āṭavikayoḥ pratirodhakāḥ rātrisattra carāḥ śarīra ākramiṇaḥ
translated: The aboriginals who are hostile to the conqueror are those who move about at night, who live in forts, who attack the body of the conqueror,

original: nityāḥ śata /sahasra /ahapāriṇaḥ pradhāna /kopakāś ca vyavahitāḥ pratyantara /araṇya /carāś
analyzed: nityāḥ śata sahasra aha pāriṇaḥ pradhāna kopakāḥ ca vyavahitāḥ pratyantara araṇya carāḥ
translated: who are always ready to fight, who are able to fight for a hundred or a thousand days, who are able to cause great harm, who are scattered, who move about in the border forests,

analyzed: caāṭavikāḥ prakāśāḥ dṛsyāḥ caranti
translated: who are visible, and who move about in the open.

analyzed: eka deśa ghātakāḥ ca iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teachers say that they are to be destroyed in part.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says, No.

analyzed: pratirodhakāḥ
translated: The aboriginals destroy the conqueror who is careless.

original: alpāḥ kuṇṭhāḥ sukhā jñātuṃ grahītuṃ ca /
analyzed: alpāḥ kuṇṭhāḥ sukhāḥ jñātum grahītum ca
translated: They are few, crippled, and easy to be known and seized.

original: sva /deśasthāḥ prabhūtā vikrāntāś caāṭavikāḥ prakāśa /yodinoapahartāro hantāraś ca deśānāṃ rāja /sadharmāṇa iti //
analyzed: sva deśa sthāḥ prabhūtāḥ vikrāntāḥ ca āṭavikāḥ prakāśa yodinaḥ apahartāraḥ hantāraḥ ca deśānām rāja sadharmāṇaḥ iti
translated: The aboriginals who are numerous and powerful, who are in their own country, who are visible, who are able to fight in the open, who are able to plunder and destroy the country, and who are equal to the king in power, are to be destroyed.

original: mṛga /hasti /vanayoḥ mṛgāḥ prabhūtāḥ prabhūta /māṃsa /carma /upakāriṇo manda /grāsa /avakleśinaḥ suniyamyāś ca //
analyzed: mṛga hasti vanayoḥ mṛgāḥ prabhūtāḥ prabhūta māṃsa carma upakāriṇaḥ manda grāsa avakleśinaḥ su niyamyāḥ ca
translated: In the forest of deer and elephants, deer are more numerous, provide plenty of meat and hides, require little food and effort, and are easy to control.

original: viparītā hastino gṛhyamāṇā duṣṭāś ca deśa /vināśāyaiti //
analyzed: viparītāḥ hastinaḥ gṛhyamāṇāḥ duṣṭāḥ ca deśa vināśāya eti
translated: Elephants, on the other hand, are the opposite - when captured, they are harmful and lead to the destruction of the country.

original: sva /para /sthānīya /upakārayoḥ sva /sthānīya /upakāro dhānya /paśu /hiraṇya /kupya /upakāro jānapadānām āpady ātma /dhāraṇaḥ //
analyzed: sva para sthānīya aupakārayoḥ sva sthānīya aupakāraḥ dhānya paśu hiraṇya kupya aupakāraḥ jānapadānām āpadi ātma dhāraṇaḥ
translated: In providing help to one's own people and to others, helping one's own people is better, as it provides grain, cattle, gold, and other necessities to the people in times of difficulty.

analyzed: viparītaḥ para sthānīya aupakāraḥ
translated: Helping others is the opposite.

analyzed: iti pīḍanāni ābhyantaraḥ mukhya stambhaḥ bāhyaḥ amitra aṭavī stambhaḥ
translated: Thus, the internal main obstacles and the external obstacles of enemies and forests are the obstacles.

analyzed: iti stambha vargah
translated: This is the chapter on obstacles.

original: tābhyāṃ pīḍanair yathā /uktaiś ca pīḍitaḥ /🔽sakto mukhyeṣu /
analyzed: tābhyām pīḍanaiḥ yathā uktaiḥ ca pīḍitaḥ  saktaḥ mukhyeṣu
translated: He who is afflicted by these two kinds of afflictions and by the afflictions mentioned earlier,🔽is attached to the main ones,

analyzed: parihāra aupahataḥ  prakīrṇaḥ
translated: is afflicted by avoidance,🔽is scattered,

analyzed: mithyā saṃhṛtaḥ
translated: is wrongly united,

analyzed: sāmanta aṭavī hṛtaḥ iti kośa saṅga vargaḥ
translated: and is afflicted by neighboring forests - this is the chapter on the collection of the treasury.

analyzed: pīḍanānām anutpattau utpannānām ca vāraṇe
translated: In order to prevent the arising of afflictions and to ward off those that have arisen,

analyzed: yateta deśa vṛddhi artham nāśe ca stambha saṅgayoḥ
translated: one should strive for the growth of the country and for the destruction of obstacles and attachments.

analyzed: bala vyasana vargaḥ mitra vyasana vargaḥ
translated: The chapter on the calamities of the army and the calamities of allies.

analyzed: bala vyasanāni amānitam  vimānitam  abhṛtam
translated: The army's vices are: the disrespected,🔽the insulted,

analyzed: vyādhitam
translated: the unpaid,🔽the sick,

analyzed: nava āgatam
translated: the newly arrived,

analyzed: dūra āyātam  pariśrāntam  parikṣīṇam
translated: the long-distance come,🔽the exhausted,🔽the depleted,

analyzed: pratihatam
translated: the obstructed,

analyzed: hata agra vegam  an ṛtu prāptam  a bhūmi prāptam
translated: the lost momentum,🔽the out-of-season,🔽the out-of-place,

analyzed: āśānirvedi  parisṛptam
translated: the despairing of hope,🔽the scattered,

analyzed: kalatra garbhi
translated: the pregnant wife,

analyzed: antar śalyam  kupita mūlam
translated: the internal thorn,🔽the angry base,

analyzed: bhinna garbham  apasṛtam
translated: the broken womb,🔽the withdrawn,

analyzed: atikṣiptam  upaniviṣṭam
translated: the rejected,🔽the settled,

analyzed: samāptam  uparuddham
translated: the completed,🔽the obstructed,

analyzed: parikṣiptam
translated: the surrounded,

analyzed: chinna dhānya puruṣa vīvadham
translated: the cut off from grain, men, and supplies,

analyzed: sva vikṣiptam
translated: the self-scattered,

analyzed: mitra vikṣiptam  dūṣya yuktam
translated: the friend-scattered,🔽the corrupted,

analyzed: duṣṭa pārṣṇigrāham
translated: the hostile rear guard,

analyzed: śūnya mūlam
translated: the baseless,

analyzed: a svāmi saṃhatam
translated: the unowned alliance,

analyzed: bhinna kūṭam andham iti
translated: and the blind.

analyzed: teṣām amānita vimānita aniyatayoḥ amānitam kṛta artha mānam yudhyeta
translated: Of those, the disrespected and the insulted, the disrespected who has been honored with a reward should fight.

analyzed: na vimānitam antar kopam
translated: Not the insulted, who has internal anger.

analyzed: abhṛta vyādhitayoḥ abhṛtam tadātva kṛta vetanam yudhyeta
translated: Of the unpaid and the sick, the unpaid who has been paid for the moment should fight.

analyzed: na vyādhitam a karmaṇyam
translated: Not the sick, who is unfit for work.

original: nava /āgata /dūra /āyātayor nava /āgatam anyata upalabdha /deśam anava /miśraṃ yudhyeta /
analyzed: nava āgata dūra āyātayoḥ nava āgatam anyatas upalabdha deśam anavamiśram yudhyeta
translated: Of a newly arrived and a far-away army, he should fight with the newly arrived one, which is not yet mixed up with the local people.

analyzed: na dūra āyatam āyata gata parikleśam
translated: Not with the far-away one, which is exhausted by the long march.

analyzed: pariśrānta parikṣīṇayoḥ pariśrāntam snāna bhojana svapna labdha viśrāmam yudhyeta
translated: Of a tired and exhausted army, he should fight with the tired one, which has rested by bathing, eating, and sleeping.

analyzed: na parikṣīṇam anyatra āhave kṣīṇa yugya puruṣam
translated: Not with the exhausted one, except in a battle where the horses and men are exhausted.

analyzed: pratihata hata agra vegayoḥ pratihatam agra pāta bhagnam pravīra puruṣa saṃhatam yudhyeta
translated: Of an army whose front has been checked and whose front has been destroyed, he should fight with the one whose front has been checked, whose front has been broken, and whose best men have been killed.

analyzed: na hata agra vegam agra pāta hata vīram
translated: Not with the one whose front has been destroyed, whose best men have been killed.

analyzed: an ṛtva bhūmi prāptayoḥ an ṛtu prāptam yathā ṛtu yugya śastra āvaraṇam yudhyeta
translated: Of an army that has arrived at an unfavourable time and place, he should fight with the one that has arrived at an unfavourable time, whose horses, weapons, and armour are suitable for the season.

analyzed: na a bhūmi prāptam avaruddha prasāra vyāyāmam
translated: Not with the one that has arrived at an unfavourable place, which is confined, stretched out, and exhausted.

analyzed: āśā nirvedi parisṛptayoḥ āśā nirvedi labdha abhiprāyam yudhyeta
translated: Of an army that is hopeful, despondent, and retreating, he should fight with the one that is hopeful, whose purpose has been accomplished.

analyzed: na parisṛptam apasṛta mukhyam
translated: Not with the retreating one, whose leader has retreated.

analyzed: kalatra garbhi antaḥśalyayoḥ kalatra garbhi unmucya kalatram yudhyeta
translated: Of an army with women and pregnant women, and with internal dissension, he should fight with the one with women, having released the women.

analyzed: na antar śalyam antaramitram
translated: nor a friend who is a thorn in the side.

analyzed: kupita mūla bhinna garbhayoḥ kupita mūlam praśamita kopam sāma ādibhiḥ yudhyeta
translated: Of those whose root of enmity is excited and those whose root of enmity is split, he whose root of enmity is excited should be fought against after his excited enmity has been pacified by conciliation and other means.

analyzed: na bhinna garbham anyonyasmāt bhinnam
translated: But not he whose root of enmity is split, as he is split from both sides.

original: apasṛta /atikṣiptayor apasṛtam eka /rājya /atikrāntaṃ mantra /vyāyāmābhyāṃ sattra /mitra /apāśrayaṃ yudhyeta /
analyzed: apasṛta atikṣiptayoḥ apasṛtam eka rājya atikrāntam mantra vyāyāmābhyām sattra mitra apāśrayam yudhyeta
translated: Of those who have retired and those who have been expelled, he who has retired, having crossed over to another kingdom, should be fought against after having taken shelter with a neighbouring king and having made an alliance with him by means of counsel and exertion.

analyzed: na atikṣiptam aneka rājya atikrāntam bahu ābādha tvāt
translated: But not he who has been expelled, as he has crossed over to many kingdoms and is beset with many troubles.

analyzed: upaniviṣṭa samāptayoḥ upaniviṣṭam pṛthak yāna sthānam atisaṃdhāya arim yudhyeta
translated: Of those who have settled down and those who have been completely destroyed, he who has settled down, having a separate army and a separate place, should be fought against after having attacked the enemy.

analyzed: na samāptam ariṇā eka sthānayānam
translated: But not he who has been completely destroyed, as he has a common place and a common army with the enemy.

analyzed: uparuddha parikṣiptayoḥ uparuddham anyatas niṣkramya auparoddhāram pratiyudhyeta
translated: Of those who are besieged and those who are completely surrounded, he who is besieged should be fought against after having gone out from another place and having fought against the besiegers.

analyzed: na parikṣiptam sarvatas pratiruddham
translated: But not he who is completely surrounded, as he is obstructed on all sides.

original: chinna /dhānya /puruṣa /vīvadhayoḥ chinna /dhānyam anyato dhānyam ānīya jaṅgama /sthāvara /āhāraṃ vā yudhyeta /
analyzed: chinna dhānya puruṣa vīvadhayoḥ chinna dhānyam anyatas dhānyam ānīya jaṅgama sthāvara āhāram vā yudhyeta
translated: Of those whose supply of grain and men is cut off, he whose supply of grain is cut off should be fought against after having brought grain from another place or after having lived on mobile and immobile things.

analyzed: na chinna puruṣa vīvadham an abhisāram
translated: But not he whose supply of men is cut off, as he cannot be supplied with men.

original: sva /vikṣipta /mitra /vikṣiptayoḥ sva /vikṣiptaṃ sva /bhūmau vikṣiptaṃ sainyam āpadi śakyam āvāhayitum /
analyzed: sva vikṣipta mitra vikṣiptayoḥ sva vikṣiptam sva bhūmau vikṣiptam sainyam āpadi śakyam āvāhayitum
translated: Of the two, the army that is scattered by itself and the army that is scattered by the enemy, the army that is scattered by itself can be rallied in an emergency on one’s own ground.

analyzed: na mitra vikṣiptam viprakṛṣṭa deśa kāla tvāt
translated: Not the army that is scattered by the enemy, because it is far removed in place and time.

analyzed: dūṣya yukta duṣṭa pārṣṇigrāhayoḥ dūṣya yuktam āpta puruṣa adhiṣṭhitam asaṃhatam yudhyeta
translated: Of the two, the army that is corrupted and the army that is attacked by a treacherous enemy, one should fight with the army that is corrupted and is under the command of trusted officers, even if it is not fully equipped.

analyzed: na duṣṭa pārṣṇigrāham pṛṣṭha abhighāta trastam
translated: Not with the army that is attacked by a treacherous enemy, because it is frightened by the attack from the rear.

analyzed: śūnya mūla asvāmi saṃhatayoḥ śūnya mūlam kṛta paura jānapada ārakṣam sarva saṃdohena yudhyeta
translated: Of the two, the army that is without a base and the army that is without a leader, one should fight with the army that is without a base, after having made arrangements for the protection of the city and the countryside, with all available forces.

analyzed: na asvāmi saṃhatam rāja senāpati hīnam
translated: Not with the army that is without a leader, because it is without a commander and a general.

analyzed: bhinna kūṭa andhayoḥ bhinna kūṭam anya adhiṣṭhitam yudhyeta
translated: Of the two, the army that is divided and the army that is blind, one should fight with the army that is divided and is under the command of another.

analyzed: na andham adeśikam iti  doṣa śuddhiḥ bala āvāpaḥ sattra sthāna ati saṃhitam
translated: Not with the army that is blind, because it is without a guide.🔽The purification of faults, the reinforcement of the army, the establishment of a fortress, and the conclusion of peace,

analyzed: saṃdhiḥ ca auttarapakṣasya bala vyasana sādhanam
translated: and the means of acquiring strength and wealth for the future,

original: rakṣet sva /daṇḍaṃ vyasane śatrubhyo nityam utthitaḥ /
analyzed: rakṣet sva daṇḍam vyasane śatrubhyaḥ nityam utthitaḥ
translated: one should always be on guard against the vices of one’s own army and the enemy.

analyzed: praharet daṇḍa randhreṣu śatrūṇām nityam utthitaḥ
translated: and should always be ready to strike his enemies in their vulnerable points.

original: yato nimittaṃ vyasanaṃ prakṛtīnām avāpnuyāt /🔽prāg eva pratikurvīta tan nimittam atandritaḥ /
analyzed: yatas nimittam vyasanam prakṛtīnām avāpnuyāt  prāk eva pratikurvīta tat nimittam atandritaḥ
translated: From whatever cause the people may suffer,🔽he should, without delay, take steps to remove that cause.

analyzed: abhiyātam svayam mitram sambhūya anya vaśena vā
translated: He should attack his enemy who has come to his own country, or who has come in alliance with another, or who has come under the influence of another;

original: parityaktam aśaktyā vā lobhena praṇayena vā /🔽vikrītam abhiyuñjāne saṃgrāme vāapavartinā //🔽dvaidhī /bhāvena vāamitraṃ yāsyatā vāanyam anyataḥ /
analyzed: parityaktam aśaktyā vā lobhena praṇayena vā  vikrītam abhiyuñjāne saṃgrāme vā aapavartinā  dvaidhībhāvena vā amitram yāsyatā vā anyam anyatas
translated: or who has been abandoned by his own people either through incapacity, or through greed, or through affection;🔽or who has been sold by his own people, or who is engaged in fighting with another, or who is retreating from the battle;🔽or who is going to make peace with another through double-dealing, or who is going to another country;

analyzed: pṛthak vā sahayāne vā viśvāsena ati saṃhitam
translated: or who is separated from his own people, or who is marching with them, or who is too much trusted;

analyzed: bhaya avamāna ālasyaiḥ vā vyasanāt na pramokṣitam
translated: or who has not been released from danger or calamity through fear, contempt, or laziness;

original: avaruddhaṃ sva /bhūmibhyaḥ samīpād vā bhayād gatam //🔽ācchedanād adānād vā dattvā vāapy avamānitam /
analyzed: avaruddham sva bhūmibhyaḥ samīpāt vā bhayāt gatam  ācchedanāt adānāt vā dattvā vā api avamānitam
translated: or who has been confined to his own country or to its vicinity through fear;🔽or who has been abandoned through fear, or who has been given and taken back, or who has been insulted after being given;

original: atyāhāritam arthaṃ vā svayaṃ para /mukhena vā //🔽atibhāre niyuktaṃ vā bhaṅktvā param upasthitam /
analyzed: atyāhāritam artham vā svayam para mukhena vā  atibhāre niyuktam vā bhaṅktvā param upasthitam
translated: or who has been given more than he can bear, either by himself or through another;🔽or who has been employed in a heavy task, or who has broken his alliance with another and come to him;

analyzed: upekṣitam aśaktyā vā prārthayitvā virodhitam
translated: or who has been neglected through incapacity, or who has been opposed after being sought as an ally;

original: kṛcchreṇa sādhyate mitraṃ siddhaṃ caāśu virajyati /
analyzed: kṛcchreṇa sādhyate mitram siddham ca āśu virajyati
translated: A friend is difficult to win over, and when won, he soon becomes disaffected.

original: kṛta /prayāsaṃ mānyaṃ vā mohān mitram amānitam /
analyzed: kṛta prayāsam mānyam vā mohāt mitram a mānitam
translated: A friend, though tried and honoured, becomes disaffected through folly, or through want of honour.

original: mānitaṃ vā na sadṛśaṃ śaktito vā nivāritam //🔽mitra /upaghāta /trastaṃ vā śaṅkitaṃ vāari /saṃhitāt /
analyzed: mānitam vā na sadṛśam śaktitaḥ vā nivāritam  mitra aupaghāta trastam vā śaṅkitam vā ari saṃhitāt
translated: Or, though honoured, he does not behave as he should, or is restrained by his power.🔽Or, being afraid of the injury to his friend, or suspecting the combination of the enemy,

original: dūṣyair vā bhedituṃ mitraṃ sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ ca tiṣṭhati //
analyzed: dūṣyaiḥ vā bheditum mitram sādhyam siddham ca tiṣṭhati
translated: a friend, whether to be won over or already won over, is kept in good humour by the spies.

analyzed: tasmāt na autpādayet enān doṣān mitra aupaghātakān
translated: Therefore, one should not give rise to these faults that injure a friend,

analyzed: utpannān vā praśamayet guṇaiḥ doṣa aupaghātibhiḥ
translated: or, if they have arisen, one should pacify them with qualities that counteract the faults.

analyzed: śakti deśa kāla bala abala jnānam
translated: Knowledge of power, place, time, strength, weakness, the time for marching,

original: vijigīṣur ātmanaḥ parasya ca bala /abalaṃ śakti /deśa /kāla /yātrā /kāla /bala /samuddāna /kāla /paścāt /kopa /kṣaya /vyaya /lābha /āpadāṃ jñātvā
analyzed: vijigīṣuḥ ātmanaḥ parasya ca bala abalam śakti deśa kāla yātrā kāla bala samuddāna kāla paścāt kopa kṣaya vyaya lābha āpadām jñātvā
translated: The conqueror, having known his own and the enemy's strength, weakness, power, place, time, the time for marching, the time for assembling the army, the time for striking from behind, the loss, expenditure, gain, and danger of his own and the enemy,

analyzed: viśiṣṭa balaḥ yāyāt
translated: should march with a superior army.

analyzed: anyathā āsīta
translated: Otherwise, he should remain.

analyzed: utsāha prabhāvayoḥ utsāhaḥ śreyān
translated: Of enthusiasm and power, enthusiasm is better.

original: svayaṃ hi rājā śūro balavān arogaḥ kṛta /astro daṇḍa /dvitīyoapi śaktaḥ prabhāvavantaṃ rājānaṃ jetum //
analyzed: svayam hi rājā śūraḥ balavān arogaḥ kṛta astraḥ daṇḍa dvitīyaḥ api śaktaḥ prabhāvavantam rājānam jetum
translated: For a king who is himself brave, strong, healthy, and skilled in arms, even if he has only his army as his second, is capable of conquering a powerful king.

original: alpoapi caasya daṇḍas tejasā kṛtya /karo bhavati //
analyzed: alpaḥ api ca asya daṇḍaḥ tejasā kṛtya karaḥ bhavati
translated: And even a small army of his becomes effective through his energy.

original: nirutsāhas tu prabhāvavān rājā vikrama /abhipanno naśyati ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: nirutsāhaḥ tu prabhāvavān rājā vikrama abhipannaḥ naśyati iti ācāryāḥ
translated: But, say the teachers, a powerful king who is devoid of energy perishes when attacked by a powerful enemy.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

original: prabhāvavān utsāhavantaṃ rājānaṃ prabhāvenaatisaṃdhatte tad /viśiṣṭam anyaṃ rājānam āvāhya bhṛtvā krītvā pravīra /puruṣān //
analyzed: prabhāvavān utsāhavantam rājānam prabhāvena atisaṃdhatte tad viśiṣṭam anyam rājānam āvāhya bhṛtvā krītvā pravīra puruṣān
translated: for a powerful king, by his power, overpowers a king who is energetic, and, having brought in another king who is superior to the latter, he either employs him or buys him or purchases brave men from him.

analyzed: prabhūta prabhāva haya hasti ratha upakaraṇa sampannaḥ ca asya daṇḍaḥ sarvatra a pratihataḥ carati
translated: And his army, being well-supplied with abundant power, horses, elephants, chariots, and implements, moves everywhere unobstructed.

original: utsāhavataś ca prabhāvavanto jitvā krītvā ca striyo bālāḥ paṅgavoandhāś ca pṛthivīṃ jigyur iti //🔽prabhāva /mantrayoḥ prabhāvaḥ śreyān //
analyzed: utsāhavataḥ ca prabhāvavantaḥ jitvā krītvā ca striyaḥ bālāḥ ca pṛthivīm jigyuḥ iti  prabhāva mantrayoḥ prabhāvaḥ śreyān
translated: And those who are energetic have conquered and purchased the earth, having won over women, children, cripples, and blind men by their energy.🔽Of power and policy, power is better.

analyzed: mantra śakti sampannaḥ hi vandhya buddhiḥ aprabhāvaḥ bhavati
translated: For one who is endowed with the power of policy, though devoid of energy, becomes successful.

original: mantra /karma caasya niścitam aprabhāvo garbha /dhānyam avṛṣṭir ivaupahanti ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: mantra karma ca asya niścitam a prabhāvaḥ garbha dhānyam avṛṣṭiḥ iva aupahanti iti ācāryāḥ
translated: and his policy, if not effective, will destroy him, like unripe grain, or like a drought.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: No, says Kautilya,

original: mantra /śaktiḥ śreyasī //🔽prajñā /śāstra /cakṣur hi rājāalpenaapi prayatnena mantram ādhātuṃ śaktaḥ parān utsāha /prabhāvavataś ca sāma /ādibhir yoga /upaniṣadbhyāṃ
analyzed: mantra śaktiḥ śreyasī  prajñā śāstra cakṣuḥ hi rājā a alpena api prayatnena mantram ādhātum śaktaḥ parān utsāha prabhāvavataḥ ca sāma ādibhiḥ yoga aupaniṣadbhyām
translated: the power of policy is superior.

analyzed: ca atisaṃdhātum
translated: For a king, whose eyes are the science of polity, can, with little effort, adopt a policy; and he can, by means of conciliation and other strategic means, as well as by means of secret contrivances, overcome his enemies, however powerful and energetic they may be.

analyzed: evam utsāha prabhāva mantra śaktīnām uttara auttara adhikaḥ atisaṃdhatte
translated: Thus, he who possesses the power of energy, power, and policy, can overcome others, each of whom possesses only one of these powers.

analyzed: deśaḥ pṛthivī
translated: The country is the earth.

original: tasyāṃ himavat /samudra /antaram udīcīnaṃ yojana /sahasra /parimāṇaṃ tiryak cakra /varti /kṣetram //
analyzed: tasyām himavat samudra antaram udīcīnam yojana sahasra parimāṇam tiryak cakravarti kṣetram
translated: In it, the land between the Himalayas and the ocean, measuring a thousand yojanas from east to west, is a circular field.

original: tatraaraṇyo grāmyaḥ parvata audako bhaumaḥ samo viṣama iti viśeṣāḥ //
analyzed: tatra araṇyaḥ grāmyaḥ parvataḥ audakaḥ bhaumaḥ samaḥ viṣamaḥ iti viśeṣāḥ
translated: In it, the special kinds of land are the cultivated, the hilly, the marshy, the even, and the uneven.

analyzed: teṣu yathāsva bala vṛddhi karam karma prayuñjīta
translated: In these, he should employ such works as tend to increase his own strength.

analyzed: yatra ātmanaḥ sainya vyāyāmānām bhūmiḥ
translated: That is the best country where the land is suitable for his own army and exercises,

analyzed: abhūmiḥ parasya  saḥ uttamaḥ deśaḥ
translated: but unsuitable for his enemy.

analyzed: viparītaḥ adhamaḥ
translated: The reverse is the worst country.

analyzed: sādhāraṇaḥ madhyamaḥ  kālaḥ śīta auṣṇa varṣa ātmā
translated: The middle one is the average.🔽Time is of the nature of cold, hot, and rainy seasons.

original: tasya rātrir ahaḥ pakṣo māsa ṛtur ayanaṃ saṃvatsaro yugam iti viśeṣāḥ //
analyzed: tasya rātriḥ ahar pakṣaḥ māsaḥ ṛtuḥ ayanam saṃvatsaraḥ yugam iti viśeṣāḥ
translated: Its subdivisions are night, day, fortnight, month, season, solstice, and year.

analyzed: teṣu yathāsva bala vṛddhi karam karma prayuñjīta
translated: In these, one should employ the measures that enhance one's own strength.

analyzed: yatra ātmanaḥ sainya vyāyāmānām ṛtuḥ an ṛtuḥ parasya
translated: When the season is favorable for one's own army and exercises, but unfavorable for the enemy,

analyzed: saḥ uttamaḥ kālaḥ
translated: that is the best time.

analyzed: viparītaḥ adhamaḥ
translated: The opposite is the worst.

analyzed: sādhāraṇaḥ madhyamaḥ
translated: The average is the middle one.

original: śakti /deśa /kālānāṃ tu śaktiḥ śreyasī ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: śakti deśa kālānām tu śaktiḥ śreyasī iti ācāryāḥ
translated: But the teachers say that of power, place, and time, power is the best.

original: śaktimān hi nimna /sthalavato deśasya śīta /uṣṇa /varṣavataś ca kālasya śaktaḥ pratīkāre bhavati //
analyzed: śaktimān hi nimna sthalavataḥ deśasya śīta auṣṇa varṣavataḥ ca kālasya śaktaḥ pratīkāre bhavati
translated: For one who has power is able to remedy a place with low and high ground, and a time with cold, hot, and rainy seasons.

original: deśaḥ śreyān ity eke //🔽sthala /gato hi śvā nakraṃ vikarṣati /
analyzed: deśaḥ śreyān iti eke  sthala gataḥ hi śvā nakram vikarṣati
translated: Some say that place is better.🔽For a dog on dry land drags a crocodile,

analyzed: nimna gataḥ nakraḥ śvānam iti
translated: but a crocodile in the water drags a dog.

original: kālaḥ śreyān ity eke //🔽divā kākaḥ kauśikaṃ hanti /
analyzed: kālaḥ śreyān iti eke  divā kākaḥ kauśikam hanti
translated: Some say that time is better.🔽By day a crow kills a hawk,

analyzed: rātrau kauśikaḥ kākam iti
translated: but by night a hawk kills a crow.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says no.

analyzed: paraspara sādhakāḥ hi śakti deśa kālāḥ
translated: For power, place, and time are mutually complementary.

original: tair abhyuccitas tṛtīyaṃ caturthaṃ vā daṇḍasyaaṃśaṃ mūle pārṣṇyāṃ pratyanta /aṭavīṣu🔽ca rakṣā vidhāya kārya /sādhana /sahaṃ kośa /daṇḍaṃ caādāya kṣīṇa /purāṇa /bhaktam agṛhīta /nava /bhaktam
analyzed: taiḥ abhyuccitaḥ tṛtīyam caturtham vā daṇḍasya aṃśam mūle pārṣṇyām pratyanta aṭavīṣu  ca rakṣāḥ vidhāya kārya sādhana saham kośa daṇḍam ca ādāya kṣīṇa purāṇa bhaktam a gṛhīta nava bhaktam
translated: Having received from them the third or fourth part of the army, he should, after having made arrangements for the protection of the root, the rear, the frontier districts, and the forests,🔽take with him such portion of the army as is capable of accomplishing the object in view, and also the treasury and the army, and march against the enemy, who has not yet received the new harvest, and whose old supply of food has been exhausted,

original: asaṃskṛta /durgama /mitraṃ vārṣikaṃ caasya sasyaṃ haimanaṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ mārgaśīrṣīṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt //
analyzed: a saṃskṛta durgam amitram vārṣikam ca asya sasyam haimanam ca muṣṭim upahantum mārgaśīrṣīm yātrām yāyāt
translated: in the month of Mārgaśīrṣa, in order to destroy the autumn harvest and the winter supply of grain.

original: haimānaṃ caasya sasyaṃ vāsantikaṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ caitrīṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt //
analyzed: haimānam ca asya sasyam vāsantikam ca muṣṭim upahantum caitrīm yātrām yāyāt
translated: In the month of Caitra, he should march against the enemy in order to destroy the winter harvest and the spring supply of grain.

original: kṣīṇa /kṛṇa /kāṣṭha /udakam asaṃskṛta /durgama /mitraṃ vāsantikaṃ caasya sasyaṃ vārṣikīṃ ca muṣṭim upahantuṃ jyeṣṭhāmūlīyāṃ yātrāṃ🔽atyuṣṇam alpa /yavasa /indhana /udakaṃ vā deśaṃ hemante yāyāt //
analyzed: kṣīṇa kṛṇa kāṣṭha audakam a saṃskṛta durgama mitram vāsantikam ca asya sasyam vārṣikīm ca muṣṭim upahantum jyeṣṭhāmūlīyām yātrām  ati uṣṇam alpa yava saindhana audakam vā deśam hemante yāyāt
translated: In the month of Jyeṣṭha, he should march against the enemy in order to destroy the spring harvest and the summer supply of grain, whose fortifications are not yet completed, and who has not yet made friends.🔽In the winter, he should march against the enemy, whose country is very hot, and where fodder, fuel and water are scarce.

original: tuṣāra /durdinam agādha /nimna /prāyaṃ gahana /tṛṇa /vṛkṣaṃ vā deśaṃ grīṣme yāyāt //
analyzed: tuṣāra durdinam agādha nimna prāyam gahana tṛṇa vṛkṣam vā deśam grīṣme yāyāt
translated: In the summer, he should march against the enemy, whose country is full of snow and rain, and which is low and marshy, and abounds in thick grass and trees.

analyzed: sva sainya vyāyāma yogyam parasya ayogyam varṣati yāyāt
translated: In the rainy season, he should march against the enemy, whose country is fit for the exercise of his own army, but unfit for that of the enemy.

original: mārgaśīrṣīṃ taiṣīṃ caantareṇa dīrgha /kālāṃ yātrāṃ yāyāt /
analyzed: mārgaśīrṣīm taiṣīm ca antareṇa dīrgha kālām yātrām yāyāt
translated: He should undertake a long campaign between the months of Margashirsha and Phalguni.

analyzed: caitrīm vaiśākhīm ca antareṇa madhyamakālām
translated: He should undertake a medium campaign between the months of Chaitra and Vaishakha.

analyzed: jyeṣṭhāmūlīyām āṣāḍhīm ca antareṇa hrasvakālām
translated: He should undertake a short campaign between the months of Jyeshtha and Ashadha.

analyzed: upoṣiṣyan vyasane caturthīm  vyasana abhiyānam vigṛhyayāne vyākhyātam
translated: When he is going to fast, he should undertake a campaign on the fourth day of the lunar fortnight.🔽The conduct of a campaign in times of distress has been explained in the chapter on war with a strong enemy.

original: prāyaśaś caācāryāḥ para /vyasane yātavyam ity upadiśanti //
analyzed: prāyaśas ca ācāryāḥ para vyasane yātavyam iti upadiśanti
translated: Most of the teachers advise a campaign against an enemy in distress.

original: śakty /udaye yātavyam anaikānntikatvād vyasanānām iti kauṭilyaḥ //
analyzed: śakti udaye yātavyam an aikānntika tvāt vyasanānām iti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya says that a campaign should be undertaken when the enemy is in a position to do harm, because calamities are not always certain to happen.

original: yadā vā prayātaḥ karśayitum ucchetuṃ vā śaknuyād amitraṃ tadā yāyāt //
analyzed: yadā vā prayātaḥ karśayitum ucchetum vā śaknuyāt amitram tadā yāyāt
translated: Or when he is able to harass or destroy the enemy after having marched against him, then he should undertake a campaign.

analyzed: ati uṣṇa aupakṣīṇe kāle hasti bala prāyaḥ yāyāt
translated: When the season is very hot or when it is the end of the rainy season, he should undertake a campaign with an army consisting chiefly of elephants.

analyzed: hastinaḥ hi antar svedāḥ kuṣṭhinaḥ bhavanti
translated: For elephants, being perspiring within, become afflicted with leprosy.

analyzed: an avagāhamānāḥ toyam a pibantaḥ ca antaravakṣārāt ca andhībhavanti
translated: If they do not plunge into water and drink it, they become blind on account of the internal alkali.

original: tasmāt prabhūta /udake deśe varṣati ca hasti /bala /prāyo yāyāt //
analyzed: tasmāt prabhūta audake deśe varṣati ca hasti bala prāyaḥ yāyāt
translated: Therefore, he should undertake a campaign with an army consisting chiefly of elephants in a country where there is plenty of water and when it rains.

analyzed: viparyaye khara oṣṭra aśva bala prāyas deśam alpa varṣa paṅkam
translated: In the reverse, the country should be full of camels, mules and horses, and should have little rain and mud.

analyzed: varṣati maru prāyam catur aṅga balaḥ yāyāt
translated: When it rains, one should march with an army consisting of four divisions in a country which is mostly sandy.

analyzed: sama viṣama nimna sthala hrasva dīrgha vaśena vā adhvanaḥ yātrām vibhajet
translated: Or one should divide the march according to the even and uneven terrain, low and high ground, short and long distances.

original: sarvā vā hrasva /kālāḥ syur yātavyāḥ kārya /lāghavāt /
analyzed: sarvāḥ vā hrasva kālāḥ syuḥ yātavyāḥ kārya lāghavāt
translated: Or all the marches should be short, in order to lighten the work,

original: dīrghāḥ kārya /gurutvād vā varṣā /vāsaḥ paratra ca //E
analyzed: dīrghāḥ kārya guru tvāt vā varṣa āvāsaḥ paratra ca
translated: or long, in order to make the work heavy, and to spend the rainy season elsewhere.

analyzed: bala aupādāna kālāh samnāha guṇāh pratibala karma
translated: The times for procuring the army, the qualities of the army, the measures to be taken against the enemy,

analyzed: maula bhṛtaka śreṇī mitra amitra aṭavī balānām samuddāna kālāḥ
translated: and the times for assembling the main army, the hired army, the guilds, friends, enemies and wild tribes.

analyzed: mūla rakṣaṇāt atiriktam maula balam
translated: The main army is superior to the rest because it is protected by its roots.

analyzed: atyāvāpa yuktāḥ vā maulāḥ mūle vikurvīran
translated: Or the main army, if too much is taken, may be dispersed in the root.

analyzed: bahula anurakta maula balaḥ sāra balaḥ vā pratiyoddhā  vyāyāmena yoddhavyam
translated: The enemy who has a large and devoted main army or a strong army should be fought with exertion.

analyzed: prakṛṣṭeadhvani kāle vā kṣaya vyaya saha tvāt maulānām
translated: Because the main army can bear loss and expense for a long distance or a long time.

original: bahula /anurakta /sampāte ca yātavyasyaupajāpa /bhayād anya /sainyānāṃ bhṛta /ādīnām aviśvāse /
analyzed: bahula anurakta sampāte ca yātavyasya aupajāpa bhayāt anya sainyānām bhṛta ādīnām aviśvāse
translated: When the enemy's army is large, devoted, and united, and when there is fear of intrigue against the army of mercenaries and others, due to lack of confidence in the enemy's army,

analyzed: bala kṣaye vā sarva sainyānām iti maula bala kālaḥ
translated: or when there is a decrease in the strength of one's own army, this is the time for one's own army.

original: prabhūtaṃ me bhṛta /balam alpaṃ ca maula /balamṇ parasyaalpaṃ viraktaṃ vā maula /balam /
analyzed: prabhūtam me bhṛta balam alpam ca maula balam parasya alpam viraktam vā maula balam
translated: When one has a large army of mercenaries and a small army of one's own, or when the enemy has a small or disaffected army of his own,

original: phalgu /prāyam asāraṃ vā bhṛta /sainyamṇ mantreṇa yoddhavyam alpa /vyāyāmenaṇ hrasvo
analyzed: phalgu prāyam asāram vā bhṛta sainyam ṇ mantreṇa yoddhavyam alpa vyāyāmena aṇ hrasvaḥ
translated: and when the mercenary army is mostly weak and worthless, one should fight by means of counsel and with little exertion. When the country or time is short, with little loss or expense,

original: deśaḥ kālo vā tanu /kṣaya /vyayahṇ alpa /āvāpaṃ śānta /upajāpaṃ viśvastaṃ vā me sainyamṇ
analyzed: deśaḥ kālaḥ vā tanu kṣaya vyaya hṛd alpa āvāpam śānta aupajāpam viśvastam vā me sainyam
translated: and when one's own army is small, peaceful, and free from intrigue, or when one's own army is trustworthy,

analyzed: parasya alpaḥ prasāraḥ iti bhṛta bala kālaḥ
translated: and when the enemy's army is small and can be destroyed, this is the time for a mercenary army.

analyzed: prabhūtam me śreṇī balam
translated: When one has a large army of guilds,

original: śakyaṃ mūle yātrāyāṃ caādhātumṇ hrasvaḥ pravāsaḥ /🔽śreṇī /bala /prāyaḥ pratiyoddhā mantra /vyāyāmābhyāṃ pratiyoddhu /kāmaḥ /
analyzed: śakyam mūle yātrāyām ca ādhātum ṇ hrasvaḥ pravāsaḥ  śreṇī bala prāyaḥ pratiyoddhā mantra vyāyāmābhyām pratiyoddhu kāmaḥ
translated: and is able to maintain it at the base and on the march, and when the stay away from home is short,🔽and when the opponent is mostly an army of guilds, and is desirous of fighting by means of counsel and exertion,🔽this is the time for an army of guilds.

analyzed: daṇḍa bala vyavahāraḥ iti śreṇī bala kālaḥ
translated: The conduct of a punitive army is as follows:

original: prabhūtaṃ me mitra /balaṃ śakyaṃ mūle yātrāyāṃ caādhātumṇ alpaḥ pravāso🔽mantra /yuddhāc ca bhūyo vyāyāma /yuddhamṇ mitra /balena vā pūrvam aṭavīṃ nagara /sthānam
analyzed: prabhūtam me mitra balam śakyam mūle yātrāyām alpaḥ pravāsaḥ  mantra yuddhāt ca bhūyas mitra balena vā pūrvam aṭavīm nagara sthānam
translated: If he thinks: ‘I have many friends. I can employ them in my rear and in my march. My journey will be short.

original: āsāraṃ vā yodhayitvā paścāt sva /balena yoddhayiṣyāmiṇ mitra /sādhāraṇaṃ vā me kāryamṇ🔽mitra /āyattā vā me kārya /siddhihṇ āsannam anugrāhyaṃ vā me mitramṇ atyāvāpaṃ
analyzed: āsāram vā yodhayitvā paścāt sva balena mitra sādhāraṇam vā me  mitra āyattāḥ vā me āsannam anugrāhyam vā me atyāvāpam
translated: Warfare with an army is better than warfare with a minister. Or, having first fought with my friend’s army in the forest or in a city, I shall fight with my own army afterwards. Or, my work is common to my friend.

analyzed: vāasya sādayiṣyāmi
translated: Or, the success of my work depends on my friend. Or, my friend is near and deserves my favour. Or, I shall settle his excessive demand.

analyzed: iti mitra bala kālaḥ
translated: Thus, the time for the army of friends.

analyzed: prabhūtam me śatru balam
translated: If he thinks: ‘I have a large enemy’s army.

original: śatru /balena yodhayiṣyāmi nagara /sthānam aṭavīṃ vā /🔽tatra me śva /varāhayoḥ kalahe caṇḍālasyaivaanyatara /siddhir bhaviṣyatiṇ āsārāṇām
analyzed: śatru balena yodhayiṣyāmi nagara sthānam aṭavīm vā  tatra me śva varāhayoḥ kalahe caṇḍālasya eva anyatara siddhiḥ āsārāṇām
translated: I shall fight with the enemy’s army in a city or in a forest.

original: aṭavīnāṃ vā kaṇṭaka /mardanam etat kariṣyāmiṇ atyupacitaṃ vā kopa /bhayān nityam
analyzed: aṭavīnām vā kaṇṭaka mardanam etat ati upacitam vā kopa bhayāt nityam
translated: There, in the quarrel between a dog and a boar, the success of either will be due to the Candalas. Or, I shall crush the thorns of the forts or of the forests. Or, being excessively strong, I shall always keep my enemies at bay out of anger and fear.

analyzed: āsannam ari balam vāsayet
translated: Or, I shall keep the enemy’s army near me.

analyzed: anyatra abhyantara kopa śaṅkāyāḥ śatru yuddha avara yuddha kālaḥ ca
translated: except when there is suspicion of internal disaffection. And the time for war with an enemy is also the time for a subsidiary war.

analyzed: iti amitra bala kālaḥ
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the time for the army of an enemy.

analyzed: tena aṭavī bala kālaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this is explained the time for the army in the forest.

analyzed: mārgaādeśikam
translated: One who shows the way.

analyzed: para bhūmi yogyam
translated: One who is suitable for the land of the enemy.

analyzed: ari yuddha pratilomam
translated: One who is adverse to fighting with the enemy.

analyzed: aṭavī bala prāyaḥ śatruḥ vā
translated: One who has mostly the army of the forest, or who is an enemy.

original: bilvaṃ bilvena hanyatāmṇ alpaḥ prasāro hantavyaḥ ity aṭavī /bala /kālaḥ //
analyzed: bilvam bilvena hanyatām alpaḥ prasāraḥ hantavyaḥ iti aṭavī bala kālaḥ
translated: Let the Bilva tree be struck with the Bilva fruit. A small spread should be destroyed. Thus ends the time for the army in the forest.

original: sainyam anekam anekastham uktam anuktaṃ vā vilopa /arthaṃ yad uttiṣṭhati tad autsāhikaṃ abhakta /vetanaṃ vilopa /viṣṭi /pratāpa /karaṃ
analyzed: sainyam anekam aneka stham uktam anuktam vā vilopa artham yat uttiṣṭhati tat autsāhikam abhakta vetanam vilopa viṣṭi pratāpa karam
translated: An army which is many, stationed in many places, mentioned or not mentioned, which rises up for the purpose of plunder, which is enthusiastic, which is paid without regular rations, which causes plunder, forced labor, and oppression,

analyzed: bhedyam pareṣām
translated: is to be penetrated by the enemy.

analyzed: abhedyam tulya deśa jāti śilpa prāyam saṃhatam mahat
translated: But one which is unbreakable, consisting mostly of people of the same country, caste, and profession, united, and large, is to be avoided.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus ends the time for the acquisition of an army.

original: teṣāṃ kupya /bhṛtam amitra /aṭavī /balaṃ vilopa /bhṛtaṃ vā kuryāt //
analyzed: teṣām kupya bhṛtam amitra aṭavī balam vilopa bhṛtam vā kuryāt
translated: Of these, one should make the army of the enemy or the forest army paid in kind or paid in plunder.

original: amitrasya vā bala /kāle pratyutpanne śatru /balam avagṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: amitrasya vā bala kāle pratyutpanne śatru balam avagṛhṇīyāt
translated: Or, when the time for the army of the enemy has arrived, one should seize the army of the enemy.

analyzed: anyatra vā preṣayet
translated: Or one should send it elsewhere.

analyzed: aphalam vā kuryāt
translated: Or one should make it fruitless.

analyzed: vikṣiptam vā vāsayet  kāle vā a atikrānte visṛjet
translated: or he may keep them scattered;🔽or he may dismiss them when the proper time has elapsed.

analyzed: parasya ca etat bala samuddānam vighātayet
translated: He should also destroy the collection of the enemy’s army.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sampādayet
translated: He should accomplish his own.

original: pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ caeṣāṃ śreyaḥ samnāhayitum //🔽tad /bhāva /bhāvitvān nitya /satkāra /anugamāc ca maula /balaṃ bhṛta /balātśreyaḥ //
analyzed: pūrvam pūrvam ca eṣām śreyaḥ samnāhayitum  tad bhāva bhāvi tvāt nitya satkāra anugamāt ca maula balam bhṛta balāt śreyaḥ
translated: And it is better to prepare the former of these than the latter.🔽The army of the king himself is better than the hired army, because it is always available and can be treated with honour.

original: nitya /anantaraṃ kṣipra /utthāyi vaśyaṃ va bhṛta /balaṃ śreṇī /balātśreyaḥ //
analyzed: nitya anantaram kṣipra utthāyi vaśyam bhṛta balam śreṇī balāt śreyaḥ
translated: The army of the guilds is better than the hired army, because it is always available, is ready to rise quickly, and is obedient.

original: jānapadam eka /artha /upagataṃ tulya /saṃgharṣa /amarṣa /siddhi /lābhaṃ ca śreṇī /balaṃ mitra /balātśreyaḥ //
analyzed: jānapadam eka artha upagatam tulya saṃgharṣa amarṣa siddhi lābham ca śreṇī balam mitra balāt śreyaḥ
translated: The army of friends is better than the army of the guilds, because it is composed of the people of the country, is united in one cause, and is ready to endure hardships and to achieve success.

analyzed: aparimita deśa kālam eka artha aupagamāt ca mitra balam amitra balāt śreyaḥ
translated: The army of friends is better than the army of the enemy, because it is united in one cause for an unlimited time and place.

analyzed: ārya adhiṣṭhitam amitra balam aṭavī balāt śreyaḥ
translated: The army of the enemy is better than the army of the forest, because it is under the control of the king.

analyzed: tat ubhayam vilopa artham
translated: Both of these are for the purpose of plunder.

original: avilope vyasane ca tābhyām ahi /bhayaṃ syāt //
analyzed: avilope vyasane ca tābhyām ahi bhayam syāt
translated: In the absence of plunder, there may be danger from serpents due to the distress caused by them.

original: brāhmaṇa /kṣatriya /vaiśya /śūdra /sainyānāṃ tejaḥ /prādhānyāt pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ śreyaḥ samnāhayitum ity ācāryāḥ //
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kṣatriya vaiśya śūdra sainyānām tejaḥ prādhānyāt pūrvam pūrvam śreyaḥ samnāhayitum iti ācāryāḥ
translated: The teachers say that the army of Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, Shudras, and soldiers should be arrayed in order of their respective importance, beginning with the Brahmins, because of the predominance of their energy.

analyzed: na eti kauṭilyaḥ
translated: Kautilya, however, says, No.

analyzed: praṇipātena brāhmaṇa balam paroabhihārayet
translated: The enemy should be made to submit by the display of the army of Brahmins.

analyzed: praharaṇa vidyā vinītam tu kṣatriya balam śreyaḥ
translated: The army of Kshatriyas, which is trained in the use of weapons and in military science, is better.

analyzed: bahula sāram vā vaiśya śūdra balam iti
translated: Or the army of Vaishyas and Shudras, which is numerous and strong, is better.

analyzed: tasmāt evaṃbalaḥ paraḥ
translated: Therefore, the army of the enemy is of such and such a nature.

original: tasyaetat pratibalam iti bala /samuddānaṃ kuryāt //🔽hasti /yantra /śakaṭa /garbha /kunta /prāsa /hāṭaka /veṇu /śalyavad hasti /balasya pratibalam //
analyzed: tasya etat pratibalam iti bala samuddānam kuryāt  hasti yantra śakaṭa garbha kunta prāsa hāṭaka veṇu śalya vat hasti balasya pratibalam
translated: This is the counter-force to that. Thus the array of the army should be made.🔽The counter-force to the elephant force is that which consists of machines, chariots, and infantry armed with short javelins, long javelins, hatakas, bamboo poles, and darts.

analyzed: tat eva pāṣāṇa laguḍa āvaraṇa aṅkuśa kaca grahaṇī prāyam ratha balasya pratibalam
translated: The counter-force to the chariot force is that which consists of stones, clubs, shields, hooks, and weapons for seizing the hair, and is similar to the above.

analyzed: tat eva aśvānām pratibalam
translated: The same is the counter-force to the cavalry.

analyzed: varmiṇaḥ vā hastinaḥ aśvāḥ vā varmiṇaḥ
translated: Or the elephants may be armored, or the horses may be armored.

original: kavacino rathā āvaraṇinaḥ pattayaś ca catur /aṅga /balasya pratibalam //
analyzed: kavacinaḥ rathāḥ āvaraṇinaḥ pattayaḥ ca catur aṅga balasya pratibalam
translated: The counter-force to the four-fold army is that which consists of armored chariots, and infantry armed with shields.

analyzed: evam bala samuddānam para sainya nivāraṇam
translated: Thus the array of the army is the means of repelling the enemy's army.

analyzed: vibhavena sva sainyānām kuryāt aṅga vikalpaśaḥ
translated: and with his own army, he should make the necessary arrangements for the various parts of his army.

analyzed: paścāt kopa cintā bāhya abhyantara prakṛti kopa pratīkāraḥ
translated: Then, the consideration of rear troubles and the remedies for the anger of the internal and external people.

original: alpaḥ paścāt /kopo mahān purastāl /lābha iti alpaḥ paścāt /kopo garīyān //
analyzed: alpaḥ paścāt kopaḥ mahān purastāt lābhaḥ iti alpaḥ paścāt kopaḥ garīyān
translated: If the gain in the rear is small and the gain in the front is great, then the small rear trouble is more serious.

original: alpaṃ paścāt /kopaṃ prayātassya dūṣya /amitra /āṭavikā hi sarvataḥ samedhayanti /
analyzed: alpam paścāt kopam prayātassya dūṣya amitra āṭavikāḥ hi sarvatas samedhayanti
translated: If one goes with a small rear trouble, then the traitors, enemies, and foresters on all sides will be encouraged.

analyzed: prakṛti kopaḥ vā
translated: Or it may be the anger of the people.

original: labdham api ca mahāntaṃ purastāl /lāham evaṃ /bhūte bhṛtya /mitra /kṣaya /vyayā grasante //
analyzed: labdham api ca mahāntam purastāt lāham evaṃbhūte bhṛtya mitra kṣaya vyayāḥ grasante
translated: And even if one obtains a great gain in the front, in such a situation, the loss and destruction of servants and friends swallow it up.

original: tasmāt sahasra /ekīyaḥ purastāl /lābhasyaayogaḥ śata /ekīyo vā paścāt /kopa iti na yāyāt //
analyzed: tasmāt sahasra ekīyaḥ purastāt lābhasya ayogaḥ śata ekīyaḥ vā paścāt kopaḥ iti na yāyāt
translated: Therefore, the loss in the front should be one-thousandth or one-hundredth of the rear trouble. One should not go.

analyzed: sūcīmukhāḥ hi anarthāḥ iti loka pravādaḥ
translated: For it is a proverb that misfortunes come like needles.

original: paścāt /kope sāma /dāna /bheda /daṇḍān prayuñjīta //🔽purastāl /lābhe senā /patiṃ kumāraṃ vā daṇḍa /cāriṇaṃ kurvīta //
analyzed: paścāt kope sāma dāna bheda daṇḍān prayuñjīta  purastāt lābhe senāpatim kumāram vā daṇḍa cāriṇam kurvīta
translated: In rear trouble, one should employ conciliation, gifts, dissension, and punishment.🔽In front gain, one should make the commander or prince the leader of the army.

original: balavān vā rājā paścāt /kopa /avagraha /samarthaḥ purastāl /lābham ādātuṃ yāyāt //
analyzed: balavān vā rājā paścāt kopa avagraha samarthaḥ purastāt lābham ādātum yāyāt
translated: Or a powerful king who is able to suppress rear trouble and take front gain may go.

analyzed: abhyantara kopa śaṅkāyām śaṅkitān ādāya yāyāt
translated: When there is suspicion of internal trouble, he should march, taking with him those who are suspected.

analyzed: bāhya ka upaśaṅkāyām vā putra dāram eṣām
translated: Or, when there is suspicion of external trouble, he should leave his sons and wives with them.

original: abhyantara /avagrahaṃ kṛtvā śūnya /pālam aneka /bala /vargam aneka /mukhyaṃ ca sthāpayitvā yāyāt / na vā yāyāt //
analyzed: abhyantara avagraham kṛtvā śūnya pālam aneka bala vargam aneka mukhyam ca sthāpayitvā yāyāt na vā yāyāt
translated: Having created internal trouble, he should march, leaving behind a garrison with many divisions of troops and many chiefs, or he should not march.

original: abhyantara /kopo bāhya /kopāt pāpīyān ity uktaṃ purastāt //
analyzed: abhyantara kopaḥ bāhya kopāt pāpīyān iti uktam purastāt
translated: It has been said earlier that internal trouble is worse than external trouble.

analyzed: mantra purohita senāpati yuvarājānām anyatama kopaḥ abhyantara kopaḥ
translated: Internal trouble is the anger of any one of the minister, priest, commander, or crown prince.

analyzed: tam ātma doṣa tyāgena para śakti aparādha vaśena vā sādhayet
translated: He should pacify that by giving up his own faults or by the power of the enemy's offense.

original: mahā /aparādheapi purohite samrodhanam avasrāvaṇaṃ vā siddhiḥ /
analyzed: mahā aparādhe api purohite samrodhanam avasrāvaṇam vā siddhiḥ
translated: In the case of a great offense by the priest, the remedy is either to imprison him or to dismiss him.

original: yuva /rāje samrodhanaṃ nigraho vā guṇavaty anyasmin sati putre //
analyzed: yuvarāje samrodhanam nigrahaḥ vā guṇavati anyasmin sati putre
translated: In the case of the crown prince, the remedy is either to imprison him or to punish him, if there is a virtuous son.

original: putraṃ bhrātaram anyaṃ vā kulyaṃ rāja /grāhiṇam utsāhena sādhayet /
analyzed: putram bhrātaram anyam vā kulyam rāja grāhiṇam utsāhena sādhayet
translated: He should pacify a son, brother, or another kinsman who is inclined towards the king with enthusiasm.

analyzed: utsāha ap bhāve gṛhīta anuvartana saṃdhi karmabhyām ari saṃdhāna bhayāt
translated: In the absence of enthusiasm, he should pacify him by the policy of accepting what has been seized and by the policy of making peace, out of fear of making peace with the enemy.

original: anyebhyas tad /vidhebhyo vā bhūmi /dānair viśvāsayed enam //🔽tad /viśiṣṭaṃ svayaṃ /grāhaṃ daṇḍaṃ vā preṣayet /
analyzed: anyebhyaḥ tadvidhebhyaḥ vā bhūmi dānaiḥ viśvāsayet enam  tad viśiṣṭam svayaṃgrāham daṇḍam vā preṣayet
translated: or he may win over the enemy by means of other means of conciliation, such as the gift of land.🔽Or he may send against the enemy a force which is superior to that of the enemy and which is under his own control.

analyzed: sāmanta āṭavikān vā
translated: Or he may send against the enemy his feudatory kings and wild tribes.

analyzed: taiḥ vigṛhītam atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: When the enemy is attacked by these, he may destroy him completely.

analyzed: aparuddha ādānam pāragrāmikam vā yogam ātiṣṭhet
translated: Or he may seize the enemy by treachery or by laying siege to his capital.

analyzed: etena mantra senāpatī vyākhyātau
translated: By this rule the commander of the army and the minister are also explained.

analyzed: mantri ādi varjānām antaramātyānām anyatama kopaḥ antaramātya kopaḥ
translated: The anger of any one of the ministers who are not the chief ministers, except the minister, is called the anger of the internal ministers.

analyzed: tatra api yathāarham upāyān prayuñjīta
translated: In this case also he should employ the means as required.

analyzed: rāṣṭra mukhya antapāla āṭavika daṇḍa aupanatānām anyatama kopaḥ bāhya kopaḥ
translated: The anger of any one of the feudatory kings, the chief officers of the state, the frontier kings, the wild tribes, and the army is called the anger of the external officers.

analyzed: tam anyonyena avagrāhayet
translated: He should cause them to seize one another.

analyzed: ati durga pratiṣṭabdham vā sāmanta āṭavika tad kulīna aparuddhānām anyatamena avagrāhayet
translated: Or he may cause them to seize the enemy who is well entrenched in a fort by means of any one of the following, viz., his feudatory kings, wild tribes, his own kinsmen, and the princes whom he has kept in confinement.

analyzed: mitreṇa aupagrāhayet vā yathā na amitram gacchet
translated: Or he may cause him to be seized by a friend so that he may not go over to the enemy.

original: amitrād vā sattrī bhedayed enaṃ ayaṃ tvā yoga /puruṣaṃ manyamāno bhartary eva vikramayiṣyati /
analyzed: amitrāt vā sattrī bhedayet enam ayam tvā yoga puruṣam manyamānaḥ bhartari eva vikramayiṣyati
translated: Or a spy may cause disaffection among the enemy by saying, This king considers you a man of ability and will employ you against his master.

original: avāpta /artho daṇḍa /cāriṇam amitra /āṭavikeṣu kṛcchre vā prayāse yokṣyati /
analyzed: avāpta arthaḥ daṇḍa cāriṇam amitra āṭavikeṣu kṛcchre vā prayāse yokṣyati
translated: or when he is in trouble or difficulty with his enemies or wild tribes, he will employ the army of his enemy against him;

original: viputra /dāram ante vā vāsayiṣyati //🔽pratihata /vikramaṃ tvāṃ bhartary paṇyaṃ kariṣyati /
analyzed: viputra dāram ante vā vāsayiṣyati  pratihata vikramam tvām bhartari paṇyam kariṣyati
translated: or he will keep him in a place far away from his sons and wife;🔽or he will make you, whose prowess has been frustrated, a commodity to be bartered with his master;

original: tvayā vā saṃdhiṃ kṛtvā bhartāram eva prasādayiṣyati //
analyzed: tvayā vā saṃdhim kṛtvā bhartāram eva prasādayiṣyati
translated: or having made peace with you, he will propitiate his master;

analyzed: mitram upakṛṣṭam vā asya gacche iti
translated: or he will say to you, ‘Go to a friend of mine who is in a low condition.’

original: pratipannam iṣṭa /abhiprāyaiḥ pūjayet //🔽apratipannasya saṃśrayaṃ bhedayed asau te yoga /puruṣaḥ praṇihitaḥ iti //
analyzed: pratipannam iṣṭa abhiprāyaiḥ pūjayet  apratipannasya saṃśrayam bhedayet asau te yoga puruṣaḥ praṇihitaḥ iti
translated: If he accepts the proposal, he should be honoured by the king with the fulfilment of his desires.🔽If he does not accept the proposal, the king should break his alliance with him by saying, ‘This man is a spy sent by your enemy.’

analyzed: sattrī ca enam abhityakta śāsanaiḥ ghātayet
translated: A spy should then kill him by employing men who are ready to give up their lives.

analyzed: gūḍha puruṣaiḥ vā  saha prasthāyinaḥ vā asya pravīra puruṣān yathā abhiprāya karaṇena āvāhayet
translated: Or he should be killed by secret agents.🔽Or the king should invite the best men of the enemy by doing to them what they desire.

analyzed: tena praṇihitān sattrī brūyāt
translated: A spy should then tell the men who have been sent by the enemy,

analyzed: iti siddhiḥ  parasya ca enān kopān utthāpayet
translated: Thus success is achieved.🔽And he should also excite the anger of the enemy against the king.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ca śamayet
translated: And he should pacify the anger of his own men.

original: yaḥ kopaṃ kartuṃ śamayituṃ vā śaktas tatraupajāpaḥ kāryaḥ //
analyzed: yaḥ kopam kartum śamayitum vā śaktaḥ tatra aupajāpaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: In this matter, intrigue should be practised by one who is able to excite or pacify anger.

original: yaḥ satya /saṃdhaḥ śaktaḥ karmaṇi phala /avāptau caanugrahītuṃ vinipāte ca trātuṃ tatra pratijāpaḥ kāryaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ satya saṃdhaḥ śaktaḥ karmaṇi phala avāptau ca anugrahītum vinipāte ca trātum tatra pratijāpaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: If he is true to his promise, capable of helping in the acquisition of the fruit of the action, and of saving in case of failure, then a secret agreement should be made with him.

original: tarkayitavyaś ca kalyāṇa /buddhir utaaho śaṭha iti //
analyzed: tarkayitavyaḥ ca kalyāṇa buddhiḥ uta aho śaṭhaḥ iti
translated: And he should be tested whether he is of good intentions or a rogue.

original: śaṭho hi bāhyoabhyantaram evam upajapati bhartāraṃ cedd hatvā māṃ pratipādayiṣyati śatru /vadho bhūmi /lābhaś ca me dvividho
analyzed: śaṭhaḥ hi evam upajapati bhartāram ced hatvā mām pratipādayiṣyati śatru vadhaḥ bhūmi lābhaḥ ca me
translated: For a rogue, thinking thus, may approach the enemy: If he kills his master and hands me over, I will get twofold benefit, the destruction of the enemy and the acquisition of land.

original: atha vā śatrur enam āhaniṣyatiiti hata /bandhu /pakṣas tulya /doṣa /daṇḍenaudvignaś ca me bhūyān akṛtya /pakṣo bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: atha vā śatruḥ enam āhaniṣyati iti hata bandhu pakṣaḥ tulya doṣa daṇḍena audvignaḥ ca me bhūyān akṛtya pakṣaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Or else, the enemy will kill him. Thus, with a group of relatives killed, and with a group of criminals frightened by the punishment of equal offense, I will become more powerful.

analyzed: tadvidhe vā aanyasmin api śaṅkitaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Or, suspected in that matter or in another, he will become frightened.

analyzed: anyam anyam ca asya mukhyam
translated: And I will get him killed by another,

original: abhityakta /śāsanena ghātayiṣyāmi iti //🔽abhyantaro vā śaṭho bāhyam evam upajapati kośam asya hariṣyāmi /🔽daṇḍaṃ vāasya haniṣyāmi /
analyzed: abhityakta śāsanena ghātayiṣyāmi iti  abhyantaraḥ vā śaṭhaḥ bāhyam evam upajapati kośam asya hariṣyāmi  daṇḍam vā aasya haniṣyāmi
translated: by getting him to abandon his rule, thinking thus.🔽Or a rogue from within may approach the enemy thus: I will steal his treasury.🔽Or I will destroy his army.

analyzed: duṣṭam vā bhartāram anena ghātayiṣyāmi
translated: Or I will get him to kill his wicked master.

original: pratipannaṃ bāhyam amitra /āṭavikeṣu vikramayiṣyāmi cakram asya sajyatām /
analyzed: pratipannam bāhyam amitra āṭavikeṣu vikramayiṣyāmi cakram asya sajyatām
translated: I shall attack his enemies, the foreigners and the wild tribes, and shall make him victorious.

analyzed: vairam asya prasajyatām
translated: I shall create enmity between him and others.

analyzed: tatas sva adhīnaḥ me bhaviṣyati
translated: Then he will be dependent on me.

analyzed: tatas bhartāram eva prasādayiṣyāmi
translated: Then I shall please him, my master.

original: svayaṃ vā rājyaṃ grahīṣyāmiṇ baddhvā vā bāhya /bhūmiṃ
analyzed: svayam vā rājyam baddhvā vā bāhya bhūmim
translated: Or I shall myself take possession of the kingdom, or having captured the foreign territory,

analyzed: bhartṛ bhūmim ca aubhayam avāpsyāmi
translated: I shall obtain both the territory of my master and the foreign territory.

analyzed: viruddham vā āvāhayitvā bāhyam viśvastam ghātayiṣyāmi
translated: Or having invited his enemy, I shall cause him to be killed when he is confident.

analyzed: śūnyam vā aasya mūlam hariṣyāmi iti
translated: Or I shall seize his empty treasury.

analyzed: kalyāṇa buddhiḥ tu sahajīvī artham upajapati
translated: But one of good intentions, for the sake of his own life, plots against him.

analyzed: kalyāṇa buddhinā saṃdadhīta
translated: One should make an alliance with one of good intentions.

analyzed: śaṭham tathā iti pratigṛhya atisaṃdadhyāt iti
translated: Having accepted the deceitful one as he is, one should make an excessive alliance with him.

original: evam upalabhya pare parebhyaḥ sve svebhyaḥ sve parebhyaḥ svataḥ pare /
analyzed: evam upalabhya pare parebhyaḥ sve svebhyaḥ sve parebhyaḥ svatas pare
translated: Having thus understood the enemy from the enemies, one's own from one's own, one's own from the enemy, and the enemy from one's own,

original: rakṣyāḥ svebhyaḥ parebhyaś ca nityam ātmā vipaścitā //E
analyzed: rakṣyāḥ svebhyaḥ parebhyaḥ ca nityam ātmā vipaścitā e
translated: One's own should always be protected from one's own and from the enemy by the wise.

analyzed: kṣaya vyaya lābha viparimarśaḥ
translated: The examination of loss, expenditure, and gain,

analyzed: yugya puruṣa apacayaḥ kṣayaḥ
translated: The decrease of yoked men is loss.

analyzed: hiraṇya dhānya apacayaḥ vyayaḥ
translated: The decrease of gold and grain is expenditure.

analyzed: tābhyām bahu guṇa viśiṣṭe lābhe yāyāt
translated: he should go to the one who has a better prospect of success than the other.

original: ādeyaḥ pratyādeyaḥ prasādakaḥ prakopako hrasva /kālas tanu /kṣayoalpa /vyayo mahān vṛddhy /udayaḥ kalyo dharmyaḥ purogaś caiti lābha /sampat
analyzed: ādeyaḥ pratyādeyaḥ prasādakaḥ prakopakaḥ hrasva kālaḥ tanu kṣayaḥ alpa vyayaḥ mahān vṛddhi udayaḥ kalyaḥ dharmyaḥ purogaḥ ca eti lābha sampad
translated: The acquisition of wealth is said to be good when it is acceptable, not unacceptable, pleasing, not displeasing, of short duration, of small loss, of small expenditure, great, of increasing prosperity, timely, righteous, and leading.

analyzed: su prāpya anupālyaḥ pareṣām apratyādeyaḥ iti ādeyaḥ
translated: It is acceptable when it is easy to obtain and to maintain, and when it cannot be taken away by others.

analyzed: viparyaye pratyādeyaḥ
translated: It is unacceptable when it is the reverse.

original: tam ādadānas tatrastho vā vināśaṃ prāpnoti //
analyzed: tam ādadānaḥ tatrasthaḥ vā vināśam prāpnoti
translated: If one accepts it, or remains in possession of it, one will meet with destruction.

original: yadi vā paśyet pratyādeyam ādāya kośa /daṇḍa /nicaya /rakṣā /vidhānāny avasrāvayiṣyāmi /
analyzed: yadi vā paśyet pratyādeyam ādāya kośa daṇḍa nicaya rakṣā vidhānāni avasrāvayiṣyāmi
translated: Or if he thinks that by accepting the unacceptable wealth, he will be able to drain the treasury, the army, the accumulated wealth, and the means of defence of the enemy;

analyzed: khani dravya hasti vana setu bandha vaṇikpathān uddhṛta sārān kariṣyāmi
translated: he will be able to extract the essence from the mines, materials, elephants, forests, embankments, and trade routes of the enemy;

analyzed: prakṛtīḥ asya karśayiṣyāmi
translated: he will be able to weaken the people of the enemy;

analyzed: apavāhayiṣyāmi  āyogena ārādhayiṣyāmi vā  tāḥ param pratiyogena kopayiṣyati
translated: he will be able to drive them away;🔽he will be able to win them over by gifts;🔽he will be able to cause dissension among them by setting one against the other;

analyzed: pratipakṣe vā asya paṇyam enam kariṣyāmi
translated: or he will be able to make the enemy’s merchandise available to his adversary;

analyzed: mitram aparuddham vā aasya pratipādayiṣyāmi
translated: or he will be able to deliver to the enemy a friend who is in trouble;

original: mitrasya svasya vā deśasya pīḍām atrasthas taskarebhyaḥ parebhyaś ca pratikariṣyāmi /
analyzed: mitrasya svasya vā deśasya pīḍām atrasthaḥ taskarebhyaḥ parebhyaḥ ca pratikariṣyāmi
translated: or that he will be able to protect his own country from the troubles caused by thieves and enemies;

analyzed: mitram āśrayam vā aasya vaiguṇyam grāhayiṣyāmi
translated: or that he will be able to show the defects of his friend or of his own country;

analyzed: tat amitra viraktam tad kulīnam pratipatsyate
translated: or that his friend will be able to win over the disaffected and the disloyal of the enemy;

analyzed: satkṛtya vā aasmai bhūmim dāsyāmi iti
translated: or that he will be able to give land to his friend after honouring him;🔽or that he will be able to win over a friend who is in alliance with a third power and who will be his friend for a long time;

original: saṃhita /samutthitaṃ mitraṃ me cirāya bhaviṣyati iti pratyādeyam api lābham ādadīta //
analyzed: saṃhita samutthitam mitram me cirāya bhaviṣyati iti pratyādeyam api lābham ādadīta
translated: thus, even a loan that is to be repaid, he may take.

analyzed: iti ādeya pratyādeyau vyākhyātau
translated: Thus, the loan that is to be taken and that which is to be repaid have been explained.

original: adhārmikād dhārmikasya lābho labhyamānaḥ sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca prasādako bhavati //
analyzed: adhārmikāt dhārmikasya lābhaḥ labhyamānaḥ sveṣām pareṣām ca prasādakaḥ bhavati
translated: When a righteous king receives a loan from an unrighteous king, it causes satisfaction to his own people and to those of the enemy.

analyzed: viparītaḥ prakopakaḥ iti
translated: The reverse causes dissatisfaction.

original: mantriṇām upadeśāl lābhoalabhyamānaḥ kopako bhavati ayam asmābhiḥ kṣaya /vyayau grāhitaḥ iti //
analyzed: mantriṇām upadeśāt lābhaḥ alabhyamānaḥ kopakaḥ bhavati ayam asmābhiḥ kṣaya vyayau grāhitaḥ iti
translated: When a loan is not received from the ministers on the ground that it is to be repaid, it causes dissatisfaction, thinking that we have been made to incur an expenditure.

original: dūṣya /mantriṇām anādarāl lābho labhyamānaḥ kopako bhavati siddha /arthoayam asmān vināśayiṣyati iti //
analyzed: dūṣya mantriṇām anādarāt lābhaḥ labhyamānaḥ kopakaḥ bhavati siddhaarthaḥ ayam asmān vināśayiṣyati iti
translated: When a loan is received from the ministers who are disaffected, it causes dissatisfaction, thinking that he will destroy us after accomplishing his own purpose.

analyzed: viparītaḥ prasādakaḥ
translated: The reverse causes satisfaction.

analyzed: iti prasādaka kopakau vyākhyātau
translated: Thus, the causes of satisfaction and dissatisfaction have been explained.

analyzed: gamana mātra sādhya tvāt hrasva kālaḥ  mantra sādhya tvāt tanu kṣayaḥ
translated: It is of short duration because it is to be accomplished by mere going.🔽It is of little loss because it is to be accomplished by mantras.

analyzed: bhakta mātra vyaya tvāt alpa vyayaḥ
translated: It is of little expense because it is to be accomplished by mere devotion.

analyzed: tadātva vaipulyāt mahān
translated: It is great because it is extensive in the present.

analyzed: artha anubandhaka tvāt vṛddhi udayaḥ
translated: It is prosperity and rise because it is conducive to wealth.

analyzed: nirābādhaka tvāt kalyaḥ
translated: It is wholesome because it is unobstructed.

analyzed: praśasta aupādānāt dharmyaḥ
translated: It is righteous because it is taken by the praiseworthy.

analyzed: sāmavāyikānām a nirbandha gāmi tvāt purogaḥ iti
translated: It is foremost because it leads to the association of the uncontentious.

original: tulye lābhe deśa /kālau śakty /upāyau priya /apriyau java /ajavau sāmīpya /viprakarṣau
analyzed: tulye lābhe deśa kālau śakti upāyau priya apriyau java ajavau sāmīpya viprakarṣau
translated: In the case of equal gain, one should consider the country, time, ability, means, what is agreeable and disagreeable, speed and slowness, proximity and distance,

original: tadātva /anubandhau sāratva /sātatye bāhulya /bāhu /guṇye ca vimṛśya bahu /guṇa /yuktaṃ lābham ādadīta //
analyzed: tadātva anubandhau sāra tva sātatye bāhulya bāhuguṇye ca vimṛśya bahu guṇa yuktam lābham ādadīta
translated: present and future, essence and continuity, abundance and quality, and accept the gain endowed with many qualities.

original: lābha /vighnāḥ kāmaḥ kopaḥ sādhvasaṃ kāruṇyaṃ hrīr anārya /bhāvo mānaḥ
translated: The obstacles to gain are desire, anger, timidity, pity, shame, ignoble thoughts, pride,

original: sānukrośatā para /loka /apekṣā dhārmikatvam atyāgitvaṃ dainyam asūyā hasta /gata /avamāno
analyzed: sa anukrośa tā para loka apekṣā dhārmika tvam a tyāgi tvam dainyam asūyā hasta gata avamānaḥ
translated: compassion, regard for the next world, righteousness, non-abandonment, dejection, envy, contempt for what is in the hand,

original: daurātmyam aviśvāso bhayam apratīkāraḥ śīta /uṣṇa /varṣāṇām ākṣamyaṃ maṅgala /tithi /nakṣatra /iṣṭitvam iti //
analyzed: daurātmyam aviśvāsaḥ bhayam apratīkāraḥ śīta auṣṇa varṣāṇām ākṣamyam maṅgala tithi nakṣatra eṣṭi tvam iti
translated: The evils are: wickedness, distrust, fear, lack of remedy, inability to bear cold, heat, and rain, and the belief that one's desires are fulfilled by the auspicious lunar days and constellations.

analyzed: nakṣatram ati pṛcchantam bālam
translated: Wealth passes by the fool who asks too much about the stars.

original: artho hy arthasya nakṣatraṃ kiṃ kariṣyanti tārakāḥ //
analyzed: arthaḥ hi arthasya nakṣatram kim kariṣyanti tārakāḥ
translated: Wealth is the star of wealth. What will the stars do?

original: naadhanāḥ prāpnuvanty arthān narā yatna /śatair api /
analyzed: na adhanāḥ prāpnuvanti arthān narāḥ yatna śataiḥ api
translated: Even with a hundred efforts, the poor do not obtain wealth.

original: arthair arthā prabadhyante gajāḥ prajigajair iva //E
analyzed: arthaiḥ arthā prabadhyante gajāḥ prajigajaiḥ iva e
translated: Wealth is bound by wealth, like elephants by other elephants.

analyzed: bāhya abhyantarāḥ ca āpadah
translated: External and internal calamities

analyzed: saṃdhyā ādīnām ayathā uddeśa avasthāpanam apanayaḥ
translated: The removal of the arrangement of the conjunctions etc. in a different order.

analyzed: tasmāt āpadaḥ sambhavanti
translated: Therefore, calamities arise.🔽External origination and internal intrigue.

analyzed: bāhyā autpattiḥ bāhya pratijāpā
translated: Internal origination and external intrigue.🔽External origination and external intrigue.

analyzed: iti āpadaḥ
translated: Internal origination and internal intrigue - these are calamities.

analyzed: yatra
translated: Where outsiders intrigue with insiders,

analyzed: abhyantarā vā bāhyān
translated: or insiders with outsiders,

analyzed: tatra aubhaya yoge pratijapataḥ siddhiḥ viśeṣavatī
translated: there, when both are united and intrigue, success is especially assured.

analyzed: su vyājāḥ hi pratijapitāraḥ bhavanti
translated: For those who are instigated are easy to win over,

analyzed: na aupajapitāraḥ  teṣu praśānteṣu na anyān śaknuyuḥ upajapitum upajapitāraḥ
translated: but not those who instigate others.🔽When the instigators have been pacified, the instigated will not be able to instigate others.

original: kṛcchra /upajāpā hi bāhyānām abhyantarās teṣām itare vā //
analyzed: kṛcchra aupajāpāḥ hi bāhyānām abhyantarāḥ teṣām itare vā
translated: For it is difficult for outsiders to instigate those who are already instigated, or for those who are already instigated to instigate others.

analyzed: mahataḥ ca prayatnasya vadhaḥ pareṣām
translated: It is a great effort to kill the enemy,

analyzed: artha anubandhaḥ ca ātmanaḥ iti
translated: and it brings benefit to oneself.

analyzed: abhyantareṣu pratijapatsu sāma dāne prayuñjīta
translated: When those within are instigated, one should employ conciliation and gifts.

analyzed: sthāna māna karma sāntvam
translated: Conciliation is the bestowal of rank, honor, and office.

analyzed: anugraha parihārau karmasu āyogaḥ vā dānam
translated: Gifts are the bestowal of rewards or the granting of favors.

analyzed: bāhyeṣu pratijapatsu bheda daṇḍau prayuñjīta
translated: When those outside are instigated, one should employ dissension and punishment.

original: sattriṇo mitra /vyañjanā vā bāhyānāṃ cāram eṣāṃ brūyuḥ ayaṃ vo rājā dūṣya /vyañjanair atisaṃdhātu /kāmaḥ /
analyzed: sattriṇaḥ mitra vyañjanāḥ vā bāhyānām cāram eṣām brūyuḥ ayam vaḥ rājā dūṣya vyañjanaiḥ atisaṃdhātu kāmaḥ
translated: Spies or friends of the enemy should tell the outsiders, This king, through his corrupt agents, desires to destroy you.

original: budhyadhvam iti //🔽dūṣyeṣu vā dūṣya /vyañjanāḥ praṇihitā dūṣyān bāhyair bhedayeyuḥ /
analyzed: budhyadhvam iti  dūṣyeṣu vā dūṣya vyañjanāḥ praṇihitāḥ dūṣyān bāhyaiḥ bhedayeyuḥ
translated: Be aware of this.🔽Or corrupt agents sent to the corrupt should cause the outsiders to be divided by the corrupt.

analyzed: bāhyān vā dūṣyaiḥ
translated: Or the corrupt should be caused to be divided by the outsiders.

original: dūṣyān anupraviṣṭā vā tīkṣṇāḥ śastra /rasābhyāṃ hanyuḥ //
analyzed: dūṣyān anupraviṣṭāḥ vā tīkṣṇāḥ śastra rasābhyām hanyuḥ
translated: Or sharp spies, having entered the corrupt, should kill them with weapons or poison.

analyzed: āhūya vā bāhyān ghātayeyuḥ
translated: Or having summoned the outsiders, they should be killed.

analyzed: yatra bāhyāḥ bāhyān upajapanti
translated: Where outsiders intrigue against outsiders,

analyzed: abhyantarān abhyantarā vā
translated: or insiders against insiders,

analyzed: tatra ekānta yoge upajapituḥ siddhiḥ viśeṣavatī
translated: there the single-minded intriguer is very successful.

analyzed: doṣa śuddhau hi dūṣyāḥ na vidyante
translated: For when the object of intrigue is purified of faults, there are no more objects of intrigue.

original: dūṣya /śuddhau hi doṣaḥ punar anyān dūṣayati //
analyzed: dūṣya śuddhau hi doṣaḥ punar anyān dūṣayati
translated: But when the object of intrigue is purified, the intriguer contaminates others again.

analyzed: tasmāt bāhyeṣu upajapatsu bheda daṇḍau prayuñjīta
