original: paṇyaṃ viprakāraṃ vāapadiśya hiraṇyam antaḥ /sāra /balaṃ ca preṣaya yasyaenam arpayema baddhaṃ pravāsitaṃ vā iti //
analyzed: paṇyam viprakāram vā apadiśya hiraṇyam antaḥsāra balam ca preṣaya yasya enam arpayema baddham pravāsitam vā iti
translated: or, under the pretext of the deterioration of the merchandise, he may send to the enemy gold and a part of his army, saying, “We shall deliver to you the bound or exiled person.”

original: pratipanne hiraṇyaṃ sāra /balaṃ caādadīta //🔽anta /pālo vā durga /sampradāne bala /eka /deśam atinīya viśvastaṃ ghātayet //
analyzed: pratipanne hiraṇyam sāra balam ca ādadīta  antapālaḥ vā durga sampradāne bala eka deśam atinīya viśvastam ghātayet
translated: When the enemy accepts the gold and the army, the Kautilyas Arthashastra 0 king may seize them.🔽Or the commander of the border army may, under the pretext of handing over the fort, lead the enemys army to a place where he may kill the enemy when the latter is off his guard.

original: jana /padam ekasthaṃ vā ghātayitum amitra /anīkam āvāhayet //
analyzed: janapadam ekastham vā ghātayitum amitra anīkam āvāhayet
translated: Or he may invite the enemys army to destroy the enemy who is staying in one place.

analyzed: tat avaruddha deśam atinīya viśvastam ghātayet
translated: Or, under the pretext of handing over the fort, he may lead the enemys army to a place where he may kill the enemy when the latter is off his guard.

original: mitra /vyañjano vā bāhyasya preṣayet kṣīṇam asmin durge dhānyaṃ snehāḥ kṣāro lavaṇaṃ vā /
analyzed: mitra vyañjanaḥ vā bāhyasya preṣayet kṣīṇam asmin durge dhānyam snehāḥ kṣāraḥ lavaṇam vā
translated: Or an enemy, under the guise of a friend, may send to the enemy the information that the fort of the latter is short of foodgrains, oil, salt and alkaline substances,

original: tad amuṣmin deśe kāle ca pravekṣyati /
analyzed: tat amuṣmin deśe kāle ca pravekṣyati
translated: and that they will be supplied from a certain place at a certain time.

analyzed: tat upagṛhāṇa iti
translated: You may receive them.

original: tato rasa /viddhaṃ dhānyaṃ snehaṃ kṣāraṃ lavaṇaṃ vā dūṣya /amitra /āṭavikāḥ praveśayeyuḥ /
analyzed: tatas rasa viddham dhānyam sneham kṣāram lavaṇam vā dūṣya amitra āṭavikāḥ praveśayeyuḥ
translated: Then the enemy may cause his spies, enemies and wild tribes to introduce into the fort foodgrains, oil, alkaline substances and salt mixed with poison.

analyzed: anye vā a abhityaktāḥ
translated: Or others who are in distress may do it.

analyzed: tena sarva bhāṇḍa vīvadha grahaṇam vyākhyātam
translated: This explains the seizure of all the merchandise and the arrest of all the merchants.

original: saṃdhiṃ vā kṛtvā hiraṇya /eka /deśam asmai dadyāt /
analyzed: saṃdhim vā kṛtvā hiraṇya eka deśam asmai dadyāt
translated: Or having made peace, he may give to the enemy a part of the gold.

analyzed: vilambamānaḥ śeṣam
translated: and when he is delayed, he should go to the remaining one.

analyzed: tatas rakṣā vidhānāni avasrāvayet
translated: Then he should get out the means of defence.

analyzed: agni rasa śastraiḥ vā praharet
translated: Or he should strike with fire, poison or weapons.

original: hiraṇya /pratigrāhiṇo vāasya vallabhān anugṛhṇīyāt //🔽parikṣīṇo vāasmai durgaṃ dattvā nirgacchet //
analyzed: hiraṇya pratigrāhiṇaḥ vā asya vallabhān anugṛhṇīyāt  parikṣīṇaḥ vā asmai durgam dattvā nirgacchet
translated: Or he should favour the favourites of the enemy who receive gold from him.🔽Or when he is exhausted, he should give the enemy a fort and go out.

analyzed: suruṅgayā kukṣi pradareṇa vā prākāra bhedena nirgacchet
translated: Or he should go out by a tunnel, or by piercing the belly of the fort, or by breaking through the rampart.

original: rātrāv avaskandaṃ dattvā siddhas tiṣṭhet /🔽asiddhaḥ pārśvenaapagacchet //🔽pāṣaṇḍac /chadmanā manda /parivāro nirgacchet //
analyzed: rātrau avaskandam dattvā siddhaḥ tiṣṭhet  asiddhaḥ pārśvena apagacchet  pāṣaṇḍa chadmanā manda parivāraḥ nirgacchet
translated: Having given an attack by night, he should remain there if he is successful.🔽If he is not successful, he should go away by the side.🔽Or he should go out disguised as a heretic with a small retinue.

analyzed: preta vyañjanaḥ vā gūḍhaiḥ nihriyeta
translated: Or he should be carried out by spies disguised as dead bodies.

analyzed: strī veṣa dhārī vā pretam anugacchet
translated: Or he should go out disguised as a woman following a dead body.

analyzed: daivata aupahāra śrāddha prahavaṇeṣu vā rasa viddham anna pānam avasṛjya
translated: Or he should let loose poisoned food and drink at the offerings to gods, at funeral ceremonies, and at festivals.

analyzed: kṛta aupajāpaḥ dūṣya vyañjanaiḥ niṣpatya gūḍha sainyaḥ abhihanyāt
translated: Having made an agreement with the spies, he should go out with a concealed army and strike.

original: evaṃ gṛhīta /durgo vā prāśya /prāśaṃ caityam upasthāpya daivata /pratimāc /chidraṃ praviśyaāsīta /
analyzed: evam gṛhīta durgaḥ vā prāśya prāśam caityam upasthāpya daivata pratimā chidram praviśya āsīta
translated: Or having taken possession of a fort, having eaten the food offered to the deity of the fort, and having entered the hollow of an image of the deity, he should remain there.

analyzed: gūḍha bhittim vā
translated: Or in a concealed wall.

analyzed: daivata pratimā yuktam vā bhūmigṛham
translated: or a house on the ground, which is fitted with images of gods.

original: vismṛte suruṅgayā rātrau rāja /āvāsam anupraviśya suptam amitraṃ hanyāt //
analyzed: vismṛte suruṅgayā rātrau rāja āvāsam anupraviśya suptam amitram hanyāt
translated: When the enemy is asleep, having entered his palace at night through a tunnel, which has been forgotten, he should be killed.

analyzed: yantra viśleṣaṇam vā viśleṣya adhastāt avapātayet
translated: Or, having loosened the machinery, he should be made to fall down.

original: rasa /agni /yogenaavaliptaṃ gṛhaṃ jatu /gṛhaṃ vāadhiśayānam amitram ādīpayet //
analyzed: rasa agni yogena avaliptam gṛham jatu gṛham vā adhiśayānam amitram ādīpayet
translated: Or, having smeared the house or a house made of lac with poison and fire, he should set fire to the house when the enemy is asleep.

original: pramada /vana /vihārāṇām anyatame vā vihāra /sthāne pramattaṃ bhūmi /gṛha /suruṅgā /gūḍha /bhitti /praviṣṭās tīkṣṇā hanyuḥ /
analyzed: pramada vana vihārāṇām anyatame vā vihāra sthāne pramattam bhūmigṛha suruṅgā gūḍha bhitti praviṣṭāḥ tīkṣṇāḥ hanyuḥ
translated: Or, when the enemy is careless in any place of pleasure, such as a pleasure garden, sharp men, having entered through a tunnel or a secret passage in the wall of the house on the ground, should kill him.

analyzed: gūḍha praṇihitāḥ vā rasena
translated: Or, having been secretly employed, they should kill him with poison.

original: svapato vā niruddhe deśe gūḍhāḥ striyaḥ sarpa /rasa /agni /dhūmān upari muñceyuḥ //
analyzed: svapataḥ vā niruddhe deśe gūḍhāḥ striyaḥ sarpa rasa agni dhūmān upari muñceyuḥ
translated: Or, when he is asleep in a confined place, women, who have been secretly employed, should let loose a serpent, poison, fire or smoke from above.

original: pratyutpanne vā kāraṇe yad yad upapadyeta tat tad amitreantaḥ /pura /gate gūḍha /saṃcāraḥ prayuñjīta //
analyzed: pratyutpanne vā kāraṇe yat yat upapadyeta tat tat amitre antaḥpura gate gūḍha saṃcāraḥ prayuñjīta
translated: Or, when an occasion presents itself, he should employ any of these means when the enemy has entered the harem.

analyzed: tatas gūḍham eva apagacchet
translated: Then he should secretly go away.

analyzed: sva jana saṃjñām ca prarūpayet
translated: And he should proclaim the name of his own people.

analyzed: dvāhsthān varṣadharān ca anyān nigūḍha aupahitān pare
translated: Others, who are employed as doorkeepers, rain-makers and others, are secretly employed by the enemy.

analyzed: āhūya dviṣat śeṣāṇi ghātayet
translated: Having summoned the enemy's people by the name of musical instruments, he should cause the rest of the enemy to be killed.

analyzed: upajāpah
translated: Sowing Discord

original: vijigīṣuḥ para /grāmam avāptu /kāmaḥ sarvajña /daivata /samyoga /khyāpanābhyāṃ sva /pakṣam uddharṣayet /
analyzed: vijigīṣuḥ para grāmam avāptu kāmaḥ sarvajña daivata samyoga khyāpanābhyām sva pakṣam uddharṣayet
translated: The conqueror, desiring to seize the enemy's village, should encourage his own side by proclaiming his connection with the omniscient deity,

analyzed: parapakṣam ca audvejayet
translated: and frighten the enemy's side.

analyzed: sarvajña khyāpanam tu gṛha guhya pravṛtti jñānena pratyādeśaḥ mukhyānām
translated: As for proclaiming omniscience, it is by knowing the secret activities in the house, and by punishing the chief people.

analyzed: kaṇṭaka śodhana apasarpa avagamena prakāśanam rāja dviṣṭa kāriṇām
translated: It is by proclaiming the discovery of the evildoers who have been removed after being punished for their crimes.

analyzed: vijñāpya aupāyana khyāpanam adṛṣṭa saṃsarga vidyā saṃjñā ādibhiḥ
translated: It is by proclaiming the gifts given to the messengers, and by the knowledge of those who have had secret intercourse, and by the knowledge of those who have been recognized by their marks.

original: videśa /pravṛtti /jñānaṃ tad ahar eva gṛha /kapotena mudrā /samyuktena //
analyzed: videśa pravṛtti jñānam tat ahar eva gṛha kapotena mudrā samyuktena
translated: The knowledge of the activities in a foreign country is by a house pigeon that very day, together with a seal.

analyzed: daivata samyoga khyāpanam tu suruṅgā mukhena agni caitya daivata pratimā chidrān anupraviṣṭaiḥ agni caitya daivata vyañjanaiḥ
translated: As for proclaiming the connection with the deity, it is by those who enter through the openings in the fire, the caitya, and the images of the deities through the mouth of a tunnel, and who proclaim their connection with the fire, the caitya, and the deities.

analyzed: sambhāṣaṇam pūjanam ca
translated: It is by conversing with them and worshipping them.

original: udakād utthitair vā nāga /varuṇa /vyañjanaiḥ sambhāṣaṇaṃ pūjanaṃ ca /
analyzed: udakāt utthitaiḥ vā nāga varuṇa vyañjanaiḥ sambhāṣaṇam pūjanam ca
translated: Or it is by those who emerge from the water, and who proclaim their connection with the naga and Varuna, and by conversing with them and worshipping them.

analyzed: rātrau antar udake samudra vālukā kośam praṇidhāya agni mālā darśanam
translated: At night, in water, in the ocean, having placed a bag of sand, a rosary of fire, and a vision.

analyzed: śilā śikya avagṛhīte plavake sthānam
translated: In a raft held by a stone sling, one should stand.

analyzed: udakabastinā
translated: With a water bag,

original: jarāyuṇā vā śiroavagūḍha /nāsaḥ pṛṣata /antra /kulīra /nakra /śiṃśumāra /udravasābhir vā śata /pākyaṃ tailaṃ nastaḥ prayogaḥ //
analyzed: jarāyuṇā vā śiraḥ avagūḍha nāsaḥ pṛṣata antra kulīra nakra śiṃśumāra audra vasābhiḥ vā śatapākyam tailam nastas prayogaḥ
translated: or with the afterbirth, the head covered, the nose, with the entrails of a spotted deer, a cuckoo, a crocodile, or an otter, or with the fat of an otter, oil cooked a hundred times should be used as a nasal medication.

analyzed: tena rātri gaṇaḥ carati
translated: By that, one passes the night.

analyzed: iti udaka caraṇāni
translated: Thus, the water practices.

analyzed: taiḥ varuṇa nāga kanyā vākya kriyā sambhāṣaṇam ca
translated: By them, one should carry out the words of Varuna, the Nagas, and the daughters, and speak with them.

analyzed: kopa sthāneṣu mukhāt agni dhūma autsargaḥ
translated: In places of anger, one should emit fire and smoke from the mouth.

original: tad asya sva /viṣaye kārtāntika /naimittika /mauhūrtika /paurāṇika /ikṣaṇika /gūḍha /puruṣāḥ sācivya /karās tad /darśinaś ca prakāśayeyuḥ
analyzed: tat asya sva viṣaye kārtāntika naimittika mauhūrtika paurāṇika aikṣaṇika gūḍha puruṣāḥ sācivya karāḥ tad darśinaḥ ca prakāśayeyuḥ
translated: In his own realm, his astrologers, diviners, time-keepers, historians, physiognomists, and secret agents should proclaim that, and those who see it.

original: parasya viṣaye daivata /darśanaṃ divya /kośa /daṇḍa /utpattiṃ caasya brūyuḥ //
analyzed: parasya viṣaye daivata darśanam divya kośa daṇḍa autpattim ca asya brūyuḥ
translated: In the realm of another, they should say that he sees the gods, and that his treasury and army are increasing.

analyzed: daivata praśna nimitta vāyasa aṅga vidyā svapna mṛga pakṣi vyāhāreṣu ca asya vijayam brūyuḥ
translated: In the questions of the gods, in the omens of birds' limbs, in the knowledge of dreams, and in the cries of deer and birds, they should say that he is victorious.

original: viparītam amitrasya //🔽sadundubhim ulkāṃ ca parasya nakṣatre darśayeyuḥ //
analyzed: viparītam amitrasya  sa dundubhim ulkām ca parasya nakṣatre darśayeyuḥ
translated: The opposite of this is to be done to the enemy.🔽They should show the enemy the comet along with the sound of drums in the constellation of the enemy.

original: parasya mukhyān mitratvenaupadiśanto dūta /vyañjanāḥ svāmi /satkāraṃ brūyuḥ /
analyzed: parasya mukhyān mitra tvena aupadiśantaḥ dūta vyañjanāḥ svāmi satkāram brūyuḥ
translated: Under the guise of messengers, they should inform the chief men of the enemy that they are being treated well by their master.

original: sva /pakṣa /bala /ādhānaṃ para /pakṣa /pratighātaṃ ca //🔽tulya /yoga /kṣemam amātyānām āyudhīyānāṃ ca kathayeyuḥ //
analyzed: sva pakṣa bala ādhānam para pakṣa pratighātam ca  tulya yogakṣemam amātyānām āyudhīyānām ca kathayeyuḥ
translated: They should also tell them about the strengthening of their own forces and the destruction of the enemy's forces.🔽They should tell the ministers and soldiers that their welfare and security are the same as that of their own.

analyzed: teṣu vyasana abhyudaya avekṣaṇam apatya pūjanam ca prayuñjīta
translated: He should employ spies to watch for calamities and prosperity among them, and to honor their children.

analyzed: tena para pakṣam utsāhayet yathā uktam purastāt
translated: He should encourage the enemy's party as described earlier.

analyzed: bhūyas ca vakṣyāmaḥ  sādhāraṇagardabhena dakṣān  lakuṭa śākhā hananābhyām daṇḍa cāriṇaḥ
translated: And we shall speak of it again.🔽With a common donkey, the skillful.🔽With the beating of a stick and a branch, those who wander with a staff.

analyzed: kula eḍakena ca audvignān
translated: With a family ewe, the anxious.

analyzed: aśani varṣeṇa vimānitān
translated: With a shower of thunderbolts, the insulted.

original: vidulenaavakeśinā vāyasa /piṇḍena kaitavaja /meghenaiti vihata /āśān durbhaga /alaṃkāreṇa dveṣiṇāiti pūjā /phalān /
analyzed: vidulena avakeśinā vāyasa piṇḍena kaitava ja meghena eti vihata āśān durbhaga alaṃkāreṇa dveṣiṇā aiti pūjā phalān
translated: With a vidula, a shaven-headed person, a crow's ball, a deceitful cloud, those whose hopes are dashed, with an inauspicious ornament, the hateful - thus the fruits of worship.

analyzed: vyāghra carmaṇā mṛtyukūṭena ca aupahitān
translated: With a tiger skin, a death-trap, those who are attacked.

analyzed: pīlu vikhādanena karakayā uṣṭrayā gardabhī kṣīra abhimanthanena eti
translated: By eating jujube fruits, by the use of a water-pot, by the use of a camel, by the use of a she-ass, by the use of milk, by churning -

analyzed: dhruva aupakāriṇaḥ iti  pratipannān artha mānābhyām yojayet
translated: thus, O Dhruva, are the benefactors.🔽Having gained their confidence, he should win them over by gifts of wealth and honour.

analyzed: dravya bhakta chidreṣu ca enān dravya bhakta dānaiḥ anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: And in matters of property, food, and clothing, he should favour them with gifts of property and food.

original: apratigṛhṇatāṃ strī /kumāra /alaṃkārān abhihareyuḥ //🔽durbhikṣa /stena /aṭavy /upaghāteṣu ca paura /jānapadān utsāhayantaḥ sattriṇo brūyuḥ rājānam anugrahaṃ yācāmahe niranugrahāḥ paratra
analyzed: a pratigṛhṇatām strī kumāra alaṃkārān abhihareyuḥ  durbhikṣa stena aṭavī upaghāteṣu ca paura jānapadān utsāhayantaḥ sattriṇaḥ brūyuḥ rājānam anugraham yācāmahe niranugrahāḥ paratra
translated: If they do not accept, they should be given ornaments for women and children.

analyzed: gacchāmaḥ iti  tathā iti pratipanneṣu dravya dhānyāni a parigrahaiḥ
translated: In times of famine, theft, and forest fires, spies, inciting the citizens and country people, should say, We request the king's favour. Without favour, we will go elsewhere.🔽If they agree, saying So be it, they should be given property and grain without taking anything in return.

original: sācivyaṃ kāryam ity etad upajāpād bhūtaṃ mahat //E
analyzed: sācivyam kāryam iti etat upajāpāt bhūtam mahat e
translated: This is the great secret of gaining their confidence.

analyzed: yogavāmanam
translated: The method of the dwarf-like yogi

original: muṇḍo jaṭilo vā parvata /guha /āvāsī catur /varṣa /śata /āyur bruvāṇaḥ prabhūta /jaṭila /ante /vāsī nagara /abhyāśe tiṣṭhet //
analyzed: muṇḍaḥ jaṭilaḥ vā parvata guhā āvāsī catur varṣa śata āyuḥ bruvāṇaḥ prabhūta jaṭila antevāsī nagara abhyāśe tiṣṭhet
translated: Either shaven-headed or with matted hair, living in a mountain cave, claiming to be four hundred years old, with many matted-haired followers, he should stay near the city.

original: śiṣyāś caasya mūla /phala /upagamanair amātyān rājānaṃ ca bhagavad /darśanāya yojayeyuḥ //
analyzed: śiṣyāḥ ca asya mūla phala aupagamanaiḥ amātyān rājānam ca bhagavat darśanāya yojayeyuḥ
translated: And his disciples, by offering him roots and fruits, should engage the ministers and the king to visit the sage.

analyzed: samāgatāḥ ca rājñā pūrva rāja deśa abhijñānāni kathayet
translated: And when they have come, the sage should tell them the stories of the past kings and their countries.

original: śate śate ca varṣāṇāṃ pūrṇeaham agniṃ praviśya punar bālo bhavāmi /
analyzed: śate śate ca varṣāṇām pūrṇe aham agnim praviśya punar bālaḥ bhavāmi
translated: Every hundred years, I enter the fire and become a child again.

original: tad iha bhavat samīpe caturtham agniṃ pravekṣyāmi /
analyzed: tat iha bhavat samīpe caturtham agnim pravekṣyāmi
translated: Now, I will enter the fourth fire here in your presence.

analyzed: avaśyam me bhavān mānayitavyaḥ
translated: You must certainly honor me.

analyzed: trīn varān iti
translated: Choose three boons from me, O sage.

original: pratipannaṃ brūyāt sapta /rātram iha saputra /dāreṇa prekṣā /prahavaṇa /pūrvaṃ vastavyam iti //
analyzed: pratipannam brūyāt sapta rātram iha sa putra dāreṇa prekṣā prahavaṇa pūrvam vastavyam iti
translated: If he agrees, he should say, You must stay here for seven nights with your sons and wives, watching and dancing first.

analyzed: vasantam avaskandeta
translated: And he should attack him while he is staying there.

original: muṇḍo vā jaṭilo vā sthānika /vyañjanaḥ prabhūta /jaṭila /ante /vāsī vasta /śoṇita /digdhāṃ
analyzed: muṇḍaḥ vā jaṭilaḥ vā sthānika vyañjanaḥ prabhūta jaṭila antevāsī
translated: Either shaven-headed or with matted hair, disguised as a local man, with a large number of men with matted hair as his followers, he should smear a bamboo stick with the fat and blood of a corpse,

analyzed: veṇu śalākām suvarṇa cūrṇena avalipya valmīke nidadhyāt upajihvika anusaraṇa artham
translated: cover it with gold dust, and bury it in an anthill to attract a tongue-eating worm.

analyzed: svarṇa nālikām vā
translated: Or a golden tube.

original: tataḥ sattrī rājñaḥ kathayet asau siddhaḥ puṣpitaṃ nidhiṃ jānāti iti //🔽sa rājñā pṛṣṭhaḥ tathā iti brūyāt /
analyzed: tatas sattrī rājñaḥ kathayet asau siddhaḥ puṣpitam nidhim jānāti iti  sa rājñā pṛṣṭhaḥ tathā iti brūyāt
translated: Then the spy should tell the king, “This man, who is a master of the science of treasure, knows about a flowering treasure.”🔽When questioned by the king, he should say, “Yes.”

analyzed: tat ca abhijñānam darśayet
translated: And he should show the king the sign.

analyzed: bhūyaḥ vā hiraṇyam antarādhāya
translated: Or he should bury more gold.

original: brūyāc caenaṃ nāga /rakṣitoayaṃ nidhiḥ praṇipāta /sādhyaḥ iti //
analyzed: brūyāt ca enam nāga rakṣitaḥ ayam nidhiḥ praṇipāta sādhyaḥ iti
translated: And he should tell the king, “This treasure is guarded by a serpent and can be obtained only by bowing down to it.”

analyzed: pratipannam brūyāt sapta rātram iti samānam
translated: When the king agrees, he should say, “For seven nights.” The rest is the same as before.

original: sthānika /vyañjanaṃ vā rātrau tejana /agni /yuktam ekānte tiṣṭhantaṃ sattriṇaḥ krama /abhīnītaṃ rājñaḥ kathayeyuḥ asau siddhaḥ sāmedhikaḥ
analyzed: sthānika vyañjanam vā rātrau tejana agni yuktam ekānte tiṣṭhantam sattriṇaḥ krama abhīnītam rājñaḥ kathayeyuḥ asau siddhaḥ sāmedhikaḥ
translated: Or a spy, disguised as a local man, should stand alone at night with a torch and a fire, and the spies should inform the king, “This man is a master of the science of treasure.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.🔽🔽

original: taṃ rājā yam arthaṃ yāceta tam asya kariṣyamāṇaḥ sapta /rātram iti samānam //
analyzed: tam rājā yam artham yāceta tam asya kariṣyamāṇaḥ sapta rātram iti samānam
translated: When the king asks him for something, he should say, “I will do it for you if you give me seven nights.” The rest is the same as before.

analyzed: siddha vyañjanaḥ vā rājānam jambhaka vidyābhiḥ pralobhayet
translated: Or a man, disguised as a master of the science of treasure, should tempt the king with the magic of the spell of Jambhaka.

analyzed: tam rājā aiti samānam
translated: When the king agrees, the rest is the same as before.

original: siddha /vyañjano vā deśa /devatām abhyarhitām āśritya prahavaṇair abhīkṣṇaṃ prakṛti /mukhyān abhisaṃvāsya krameṇa rājānam atisaṃdadhyāt🔽jaṭila /vyañjanam antar /udaka /vāsinaṃ vā sarva /śvetaṃ taṭa /suruṅgā /bhūmi /gṛha /apasaraṇaṃ varuṇaṃ nāga /rājaṃ vā sattriṇaḥ krama /abhinītaṃ
analyzed: siddha vyañjanaḥ vā deśa devatām abhyarhitām āśritya prahavaṇaiḥ abhīkṣṇam prakṛti mukhyān abhisaṃvāsya krameṇa rājānam atisaṃdadhyāt  jaṭila vyañjanam antar udaka vāsinam vā sarva śvetam taṭa suruṅgā bhūmigṛha apasaraṇam varuṇam nāga rājam vā sattriṇaḥ krama abhinītam
translated: Or a spy, under the guise of a siddha, may, after having secured the favour of the presiding deity of the country, frequently invite the chief men of the people to sacrificial performances and gradually win over the king.

analyzed: rājñaḥ kathayeyuḥ
translated: Or spies, under the guise of ascetics with matted locks on their head, or of waterdwellers, or of all white men, or of those who can enter the earth through a hole, or of those who can enter the ground through a tunnel, or of those who can enter the house through a hole, or of Varuna, the king of serpents, may, after having been introduced by a spy, inform the king.

analyzed: tam rājā aiti samānam
translated: The rest is the same as before.

original: jana /pada /ante /vāsī siddha /vyañjano vā rājānaṃ śatru /darśanāya yojayet //
analyzed: janapada antevāsī siddha vyañjanaḥ vā rājānam śatru darśanāya yojayet
translated: Or a spy, under the guise of a siddha, living in the border country, may induce the king to see his enemy.

original: pratipannaṃ bimbaṃ kṛtvā śatrum āvāhayitvā niruddhe deśe ghātayet //
analyzed: pratipannam bimbam kṛtvā śatrum āvāhayitvā niruddhe deśe ghātayet
translated: When the king agrees to it, the spy may make an image of the enemy, invoke the spirit of the enemy into the image, and kill the image in a secluded place.

original: aśva /paṇya /upayātā vaidehaka /vyañjanāḥ paṇya /upāyana /nimittam āhūya rājānaṃ paṇya /parīkṣāyām āsaktam aśva /vyatikīrṇaṃ vā hanyuḥ /
analyzed: aśva paṇya aupayātāḥ vaidehaka vyañjanāḥ paṇya aupāyana nimittam āhūya rājānam paṇya parīkṣāyām āsaktam aśva vyatikīrṇam vā hanyuḥ
translated: Spies, under the guise of Vaidehaka traders, may invite the king to inspect the merchandise brought by them. When the king is engaged in inspecting the merchandise, they may kill him, or kill him while he is surrounded by the horses.

analyzed: aśvaiḥ ca prahareyuḥ
translated: And they may strike him with the horses.

original: nagara /abhyāśe vā caityam āruhya rātrau tīkṣṇāḥ kumbheṣu nālīn vā vidulāni dhamantaḥ svāmino mukhyānāṃ vā māṃsāni bhakṣayiṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: nagara abhyāśe vā caityam āruhya rātrau tīkṣṇāḥ kumbheṣu nālīn vā vidulāni dhamantaḥ svāminaḥ mukhyānām vā māṃsāni bhakṣayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: or, having climbed a caitya near the city, they may blow at night sharp bamboo tubes or reeds into the mouths of pitchers and say, We shall eat the flesh of the king and his chief officers.

original: pūjā no vartatām ity avyaktaṃ brūyuḥ //
analyzed: pūjā naḥ vartatām iti avyaktam brūyuḥ
translated: Let our worship be performed. They may say this indistinctly.

analyzed: tat eṣām naimittika mauhūrtika vyañjanāḥ khyāpayeyuḥ
translated: Their spies under the guise of astrologers and diviners may proclaim this.

original: maṅgalye vā hrade taṭāka /madhye vā rātrau tejana /taila /abhyaktā nāga /rūpiṇaḥ śakti /musalāny ayomayāni niṣpeṣayantas tathaiva brūyuḥ
analyzed: maṅgalye vā hrade taṭāka madhye vā rātrau tejana taila abhyaktāḥ nāga rūpiṇaḥ śakti musalāni ayaḥ mayāni niṣpeṣayantaḥ tathā eva brūyuḥ
translated: Or, in a sacred lake or in the middle of a pond, at night, they may smear their bodies with oil extracted from the sesamum plant, assume the form of serpents, and grind iron spears and pestles, and say the same thing.

original: ṛkṣa /carma /kañcukino vāagni /dhūma /utsarga /yuktā rakṣo /rūpaṃ vahantas trir apasavyaṃ nagaraṃ kurvāṇāḥ śva /sṛgāla /vāśita /antareṣu
analyzed: ṛkṣa carma kañcukinaḥ vā agni dhūma autsarga yuktāḥ rakṣaḥ rūpam vahantaḥ tris apasavyam nagaram kurvāṇāḥ śva sṛgāla vāśita antareṣu
translated: Or, wearing the skin of a bear and a coat of mail, emitting smoke from their bodies, assuming the form of demons, going thrice round the city from right to left, and howling like dogs and jackals,

analyzed: tathā eva brūyuḥ
translated: they may say the same thing.

original: caitya /daivata /pratimāṃ vā tejana /tailenaabhra /paṭalac /channenaagninā vā rātrau prajvālya tathaiva brūyuḥ //
analyzed: caitya daivata pratimām vā tejana tailena abhra paṭala channena agninā vā rātrau prajvālya tathā eva brūyuḥ
translated: Or, having set fire at night to the image of a caitya or a deity with oil extracted from the sesamum plant and with fire covered by a sheet of clouds, they may say the same thing.

analyzed: tat anye khyāpayeyuḥ
translated: Others may proclaim this.

original: daivata /pratimānām abhyarhitānāṃ vā śoṇitena prasrāvam atimātraṃ kuryuḥ //
analyzed: daivata pratimānām abhyarhitānām vā śoṇitena prasrāvam atimātram kuryuḥ
translated: If the images of gods or the images of the king are bathed with blood in excess,

original: tad anye deva /rudhira /saṃsrāve saṃgrāme parājayaṃ brūyuḥ //
analyzed: tat anye deva rudhira saṃsrāve saṃgrāme parājayam brūyuḥ
translated: If the images of the gods or the sacrificial posts bleed excessively, others should say that the king will be defeated in a battle where the blood of the gods is shed.

original: saṃdhi /rātriṣu śmaśāna /pramukhe vā caityam ūrdhva /bhakṣitair manuṣyaiḥ prarūpayeyuḥ //
analyzed: saṃdhi rātriṣu śmaśāna pramukhe vā caityam ūrdhva bhakṣitaiḥ manuṣyaiḥ prarūpayeyuḥ
translated: On the nights of the lunar conjunctions, they should cause a caitya to be seen in the cremation ground by men who have died of starvation.

analyzed: tatas rakṣaḥ rūpī manuṣyakam yāceta
translated: Then a man in the form of a demon should ask for another man.

original: yaś caatra śūra /vādikoanyatamo vā draṣṭum āgacchet tam anye loha /musalair hanyuḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ca atra śūra vādikaḥ anyatamaḥ vā draṣṭum āgacchet tam anye loha musalaiḥ hanyuḥ
translated: And whoever comes to see it, whether he is a hero or someone else, others should kill him with iron clubs.

analyzed: yathā rakṣobhiḥ hataḥ iti jñāyeta
translated: So that it is known that he was killed by demons.

original: tad adbhutaṃ rājñas tad /darśinaḥ sattriṇaś ca kathayeyuḥ //
analyzed: tat adbhutam rājñaḥ tad darśinaḥ sattriṇaḥ ca kathayeyuḥ
translated: That wonder should be told to the king, to those who saw it, and to the spies.

original: tato naimititka /mauhūrtika /vyañjanāḥ śāntiṃ prāyaś /cittaṃ brūyuḥ anyathā mahad akuśalaṃ rājño deśasya ca iti //
analyzed: tatas naimititka mauhūrtika vyañjanāḥ śāntim prāyaścittam brūyuḥ anyathā mahat akuśalam rājñaḥ deśasya ca iti
translated: Then those who pretend to be astrologers and diviners should say that a peace-offering and expiation are necessary, otherwise there will be great misfortune for the king and the country.

original: pratipannaṃ eteṣu sapta /rātram eka /eka /mantra /bali /homaṃ svayaṃ rājñā kartavyam iti brūyuḥ //
analyzed: pratipannam eteṣu sapta rātram eka eka mantra bali homam svayam rājñā kartavyam iti brūyuḥ
translated: And they should say that the king himself should perform the mantra, bali, and homa rituals for seven nights, one by one.

analyzed: tatas samānam
translated: Then it is the same as before.

original: etān vā yogān ātmani darśayitvā pratikurvīta pareṣām upadeśa /artham //
analyzed: etān vā yogān ātmani darśayitvā pratikurvīta pareṣām upadeśa artham
translated: Having thus shown these methods to himself, he should apply them to others for their instruction.

analyzed: tatas prayojayet yogān
translated: Then he should employ these methods.

analyzed: yoga darśana pratīkāreṇa vā kośa abhisaṃharaṇam kuryāt
translated: Or, by showing the methods of yoga and counteracting them, he should seize the enemy's treasury.

original: hasti /kāmaṃ vā nāga /vana /pālā hastinā lakṣaṇyena pralobhayeyuḥ //🔽pratipannaṃ gahanam eka /ayanaṃ vāatinīya ghātayeyuḥ /
analyzed: hasti kāmam vā nāga vana pālāḥ hastinā lakṣaṇyena pralobhayeyuḥ  pratipannam gahanam eka ayanam vā aatinīya ghātayeyuḥ
translated: Or, those who desire elephants should be tempted by the keepers of elephant forests with an elephant having auspicious marks.🔽Having accepted it, they should be led to a deep forest or a one-way path and killed.

analyzed: baddhvā vā a apahareyuḥ
translated: Or, having captured it, they should be taken away.

analyzed: tena mṛgayā kāmaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the desire for hunting is explained.

original: dravya /strī /lolupam āḍhya /vidhavābhir vā parama /rūpa /yauvanābhiḥ strībhir dāya /nikṣepa /artham upanītābhiḥ sattriṇaḥ pralobhayeyuḥ
analyzed: dravya strī lolupam āḍhya vidhavābhiḥ vā parama rūpa yauvanābhiḥ strībhiḥ dāya nikṣepa artham upanītābhiḥ sattriṇaḥ pralobhayeyuḥ
translated: Or, those who are greedy for wealth and women should be tempted by wealthy widows or women of supreme beauty and youth with wealth and deposits brought for them by spies.

original: pratipannaṃ rātrau sattrac /channāḥ samāgame śastra /rasābhyāṃ ghātayeyuḥ //
analyzed: pratipannam rātrau sattra channāḥ samāgame śastra rasābhyām ghātayeyuḥ
translated: Having accepted it, they should be killed by weapons and poison in a rendezvous at night by spies hidden in the house.

original: siddha /pravrajita /caitya /stūpa /daivata /pratimānām abhīkṣṇa /abhigamaneṣu vā bhūmi /gṛha /suruṅga /ārūḍha /bhitti /praviṣṭās tīkṣṇāḥ param 🔽abhihanyuḥ //
analyzed: siddha pravrajita caitya stūpa daivata pratimānām abhīkṣṇa abhigamaneṣu vā bhūmigṛha suruṅga ārūḍha bhitti praviṣṭāḥ tīkṣṇāḥ param 🔽abhihanyuḥ
translated: Or, in frequent visits to the temples, stupas, and images of accomplished ascetics, deities, and stupas, sharp spies entering through underground tunnels, houses, and walls should strike the enemy.

original: yeṣu deśeṣu yāḥ prekṣāḥ prekṣate pārthivaḥ svayam /
analyzed: yeṣu deśeṣu yāḥ prekṣāḥ prekṣate pārthivaḥ svayam
translated: In those places where the king himself observes the customs,

analyzed: yātrā vihāre ramate yatra krīḍati vā ambhasi
translated: where he enjoys excursions and sports, or plays in the water,

analyzed: dhik ukti ādiṣu sarveṣu yajña prahavaṇeṣu vā
translated: in all cases of censure and so on, or in sacrifices and assemblies,

analyzed: sūtikā preta rogeṣu prīti śoka bhayeṣu vā
translated: in cases of childbirth, death, and disease, in joy, sorrow, and fear,

original: pramādaṃ yāti yasmin vā viśvāsāt sva /jana /utsave //
analyzed: pramādam yāti yasmin vā viśvāsāt sva jana otsave
translated: where he becomes negligent due to trust in the festivities of his own people,

analyzed: yatra asya ārakṣi saṃcāraḥ durdine saṃkuleṣu vā
translated: where his spies move about in bad weather or in crowded places,

original: vipra /sthāne pradīpte vā praviṣṭe nirjaneapi vā /
analyzed: vipra sthāne pradīpte vā praviṣṭe nirjane api vā
translated: in a temple that is on fire, or even when it is deserted,

original: vastra /ābharaṇa /mālyānāṃ phelābhiḥ śayana /āsanaiḥ //🔽madya /bhojana /phelābhis tūryair vāabhigatāḥ saha /
analyzed: vastra ābharaṇa mālyānām phelābhiḥ śayana āsanaiḥ  madya bhojana phelābhiḥ tūryaiḥ vā abhigatāḥ saha
translated: with baskets of clothes, ornaments, and garlands, with beds and seats,

analyzed: prahareyuḥ arim tīkṣṇāḥ pūrva praṇihitaiḥ saha ā
translated: with baskets of wine and food, or with musical instruments, they should attack the enemy together with previously appointed [spies].

analyzed: yathā eva praviśeyuḥ ca dviṣataḥ sattra hetubhiḥ
translated: Just as they would enter the enemies for the purpose of an ambush,

analyzed: tathā eva ca apagaccheyuḥ iti uktam yogavāmanam  apasarpa praṇidhi h
translated: in the same way they should depart, this is said to be the yoga-dwarf [method of espionage].🔽The spy-messenger

analyzed: śreṇīmukhyam āptam niṣpātayet
translated: should send out a trusted leader of a group.

original: sa param āśrtya pakṣa /apadeśena sva /viṣayāt sācivya /kara /sahāya /upādānaṃ kurvīta //
analyzed: sa param āśrtya pakṣa apadeśena sva viṣayāt sācivya kara sahāya aupādānam kurvīta
translated: Having taken refuge with the enemy, he may, under the pretext of some other business, take the help of the enemy in the form of an army to attack his own master.

original: kṛta /apasarpa /upacayo vā param anumānya svāmino dūṣya /grāmaṃ vīta /hasty /aśvaṃ dūṣya /amātyaṃ daṇḍam ākrandaṃ vā hatvā parasya preṣayet
analyzed: kṛta apasarpa aupacayaḥ vā param anumānya svāminaḥ dūṣya grāmam vīta hasti aśvam dūṣya amātyam daṇḍam ākrandam vā hatvā parasya preṣayet
translated: Or having made peace with the enemy, he may, with the permission of his master, attack the enemys villages which are disaffected, which are without elephants and horses, or which are under the command of a disaffected minister, or which are in the border country, and send the booty to the enemy.

original: jana /pada /eka /deśaṃ śreṇīm aṭavīṃ vā sahāya /upādāna /arthaṃ saṃśrayeta //
analyzed: janapada eka deśam śreṇīm aṭavīm vā sahāya aupādāna artham saṃśrayeta
translated: Or he may take shelter in a part of the country, in a guild, or in a forest, for the purpose of getting help.

analyzed: viśvāsam upagataḥ svāminaḥ preṣayet
translated: Having gained the confidence of his master, he may send a messenger to the enemy.

original: tataḥ svāmī hasti /bandhanam aṭavī /ghātaṃ vāapadiśya gūḍham eva praharet //
analyzed: tatas svāmī hasti bandhanam aṭavī ghātam vā apadiśya gūḍham eva praharet
translated: Then the master may, under the pretext of destroying the elephants or the forest, secretly attack the enemy.

analyzed: etena amātya aṭavikāḥ vyākhyātāḥ  śatruṇā maitrīm kṛtvā amātyān avakṣipet
translated: This is the method of dealing with the ministers and the foresters.🔽Having made peace with the enemy, he may cause the ministers to be dismissed.

original: te tat /śatroḥ preṣayeyuḥ bhartāraṃ naḥ prasādaya iti //
analyzed: te tad śatroḥ preṣayeyuḥ bhartāram naḥ prasādaya iti
translated: They may send a messenger to the enemy, saying, Please favour our master.

analyzed: sa yam dūtam preṣayet
translated: The master may send a messenger to the minister.

original: tam upālabheta bhartā te mām amātyair bhedayati /
analyzed: tam upālabheta bhartā te mām amātyaiḥ bhedayati
translated: The minister may reproach the messenger, saying, My master is trying to sow dissension between you and me.

analyzed: na ca punar iha āgantavyam iti
translated: You need not come here again.

analyzed: atha ekam amātyam niṣpātayet
translated: Then he may cause one of the ministers to be dismissed.

original: sa param āśritya yoga /apasarpa /aparakta /dūṣyān aśaktimataḥ stenaāṭavikān ubhaya /upaghātakān vā parasyaupaharet //🔽āpta /bhāva /upagataḥ pravīra /puruṣa /upaghātam asyaupahared anta /pālam āṭavikaṃ daṇḍa /cāriṇaṃ vā dṛḍham asau caasau ca te śatruṇā
analyzed: sa param āśritya yoga apasarpa aparakta dūṣyān aśaktimataḥ stena āṭavikān ubhaya aupaghātakān vā parasya aupaharet  āpta bhāva aupagataḥ pravīra puruṣa aupaghātam asya aupaharet antapālam āṭavikam daṇḍa cāriṇam vā dṛḍham asau ca asau ca te śatruṇā
translated: He may, with the help of the enemy, cause the enemy to be attacked by the enemy’s own spies, deserters, or enemies who are not related to the enemy, or by thieves and wild tribes who are incapable of doing any harm to the enemy, or by those who are inimical to both the enemy and the conqueror.

analyzed: saṃdhatte iti
translated: Having gained the confidence of the enemy, he may cause the enemy to be attacked by the enemy’s own commander, or by the commander of the wild tribes, or by the commander of the army, or by a strong man, saying, “So and so and so and so are conspiring with your enemy.”

analyzed: atha paścāt abhityakta śāsanaiḥ enān ghātayet
translated: Then, when the enemy has been induced to put them to death, he may cause them to be killed by his own men who have been sent to the enemy under the pretext of carrying out the order of the enemy.

analyzed: daṇḍa bala vyavahāreṇa vā śatrum udyojya ghātayet
translated: Or, he may cause the enemy to be killed by employing the army of the enemy in a battle with another enemy.

original: kṛtya /pakṣa /upagraheṇa vā parasya /amitraṃ rājānam ātmany apakārayitvāabhiyuñjīta //
analyzed: kṛtya pakṣa aupagraheṇa vā parasya amitram rājānam ātmani apakārayitvā abhiyuñjīta
translated: Or, having caused the enemy’s enemy to attack his own kingdom, he may cause the enemy to be killed by the enemy’s army.

original: tataḥ parasya preṣayet asau te vairī mamaapakaroti /
analyzed: tatas parasya preṣayet asau te vairī mama apakaroti
translated: Then he may send a message to the enemy, saying, “This your enemy is doing me harm.

analyzed: tam ehi sambhūya haniṣyāvaḥ
translated: Come, let us kill him together.

original: bhūmau hiraṇye vā te parigrahaḥ iti //
analyzed: bhūmau hiraṇye vā te parigrahaḥ iti
translated: I shall give you land or gold.”

original: pratipannam abhisatkṛtyaāgatam avaskandena prakāśayuddhena vā śatruṇā ghātayet //
analyzed: pratipannam abhisatkṛtya āgatam avaskandena prakāśa yuddhena vā śatruṇā ghātayet
translated: When the enemy comes, having been honoured by the conqueror, he may be killed by the enemy with the help of the conqueror’s own men, under the pretext of an attack or an open battle.

analyzed: abhiviśvāsana artham bhūmi dāna putra abhiṣeka rakṣā apadeśena vā grāhayet
translated: or by giving him land, or by giving him his daughter in marriage, or by consecrating him as heir apparent, or by giving him protection, or by some pretext, he may win him over.

analyzed: aviṣahyam upāṃśu daṇḍena vā ghātayet
translated: If he is not to be won over, he may be killed by the king himself, or by a secret punishment.

original: sa ced daṇḍaṃ dadyān na svayam āgacchet tam asya vairiṇā ghātayet //
analyzed: sa ced daṇḍam dadyāt na svayam āgacchet tam asya vairiṇā ghātayet
translated: If he is to be punished, but does not come himself, he may be killed by the enemy of the king.

original: daṇḍena vā prayātum icchen na vijigīṣuṇā tathāapy enam ubhayataḥ /sampīḍanena ghātayet //
analyzed: daṇḍena vā prayātum icchet na vijigīṣuṇā tathā api enam ubhayatas sampīḍanena ghātayet
translated: If he wishes to march against the conqueror with an army, but not to conquer him, he may be killed by the conqueror by attacking him on both sides.

original: aviśvasto vā pratyekaśo yātum icched rājya /eka /deśaṃ vā yātavyasyaādātu /kāmaḥ /
analyzed: a viśvastaḥ vā pratyekaśas yātum icchet rājya eka deśam vā yātavyasya ādātu kāmaḥ
translated: If he wishes to march against the conqueror separately, or to seize a part of the enemy’s kingdom,

original: tathāapy enaṃ vairiṇā sarva /saṃdohena vā ghātayet //
analyzed: tathā api enam vairiṇā sarvasaṃdohena vā ghātayet
translated: he may be killed by the conqueror by the combined attack of the enemy and the conqueror himself.

original: vairiṇā vā saktasya daṇḍa /upanayena mūlam anyato hārayet //🔽śatru /bhūmyā vā mitraṃ paṇeta /
analyzed: vairiṇā vā saktasya daṇḍa aupanayena mūlam anyatas hārayet  śatru bhūmyāḥ vā mitram paṇeta
translated: Or, if he is engaged with the enemy, the conqueror may take away his root of operations by a sudden attack.🔽Or, he may make peace with a friend on the condition of getting the land of the enemy.

analyzed: mitra bhūmyā vā śatrum
translated: Or, he may make peace with the enemy on the condition of getting the land of a friend.

original: tataḥ śatru /bhūmi /lipsāyāṃ mitreṇaātmany apakārayitvāabhiyuñjīta iti samānāḥ pūrveṇa sarva eva yogāḥ //
analyzed: tatas śatru bhūmi lipsāyām mitreṇa ātmani apakārayitvā abhiyuñjīta iti samānāḥ pūrveṇa sarve eva yogāḥ
translated: Then, when he wishes to get the land of the enemy, he may attack the enemy after causing him to be injured by his friend. All these are similar to the preceding ones.

analyzed: śatrum vā mitra bhūmi lipsāyām pratipannam daṇḍena anugṛhṇīyāt
translated: Or, if the enemy is engaged in getting the land of a friend, he may be helped by the conqueror with an army.

analyzed: tatas mitra gatam atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: Then he should attack his friend who has gone over to the enemy.

original: kṛta /pratividhāno vā vyasanam ātmano darśayitvā mitreṇaamitram utsāhayitvāātmānam abhiyojayet //
analyzed: kṛta pratividhānaḥ vā vyasanam ātmanaḥ darśayitvā mitreṇa amitram utsāhayitvā ātmānam abhiyojayet
translated: Or having taken countermeasures, he should show his own distress, and having encouraged his friend to attack the enemy, he should himself join the attack.

analyzed: tatas sampīḍanena ghātayet
translated: Then he should destroy the enemy by pressure.

analyzed: jīva grāheṇa vā rājya vinimayam kārayet
translated: Or he should make an exchange of kingdoms with his friend by capturing him alive.

original: mitreṇaāśritaś cetśatrur agrāhye sthātum icchet sāmanta /ādibhir mūlam asya hārayet //
analyzed: mitreṇa āśritaḥ ced śatruḥ agrāhye sthātum icchet sāmanta ādibhiḥ mūlam asya hārayet
translated: If the enemy, having sought the protection of a friend, wishes to remain in an unconquerable place, he should have the root of the enemy cut off by the feudatories and others.

original: daṇḍena vā trātum ichet tam asya ghātayet //
analyzed: daṇḍena vā trātum ichet tam asya ghātayet
translated: Or if he wishes to be saved by force, he should have him killed.

original: tau cen na bhidyeyātāṃ prakāśam evaanyonya /bhūmyā paṇeta //
analyzed: tau ced na bhidyeyātām prakāśam eva anyonya bhūmyā paṇeta
translated: If the two do not quarrel, he should openly demand the land of the other.

original: tataḥ parasparaṃ mitra /vyañjanā vā ubhaya /vetanā vā dūtān preṣayeyuḥ ayaṃ te rājā bhūmiṃ lipsate śatru /saṃhitaḥ iti //
analyzed: tatas parasparam mitra vyañjanāḥ vā ubhaya vetanāḥ vā dūtān preṣayeyuḥ ayam te rājā bhūmim lipsate śatru saṃhitaḥ iti
translated: Then spies, disguised as friends or paid by both, should be sent to them with the message: “This king of yours desires your land and is allied with your enemy.”

analyzed: tayoḥ anyataraḥ jāta āśaṅkā āroṣaḥ
translated: One of them, suspecting or being angry,

analyzed: pūrvavat ceṣteta
translated: should act as before.

analyzed: durga rāṣṭra daṇḍa mukhyān vā kṛtya pakṣa hetubhiḥ abhivikhyāpya pravrājayet
translated: Or he should proclaim the chief officers of the fort, country, and army, along with the partisans and reasons for the action, and banish them.

analyzed: te yuddha avaskanda avarodha vyasaneṣu śatrum atisaṃdadhyuḥ
translated: They may attack the enemy in battle, in a surprise attack, or in a calamity.

analyzed: bhedam vā asya sva vargebhyaḥ kuryuḥ
translated: Or they may cause dissension between the enemy and his own men.

original: abhityakta /śāsanaiḥ pratisamānayeyuḥ //🔽lubdhaka /vyañjanā vā māṃsa /vikrayeṇa dvāhsthā dauvārika /apāśrayāś cora /abhyāgamaṃ🔽parasya dvis trir iti nivedya labdha /pratyayā bhartur anīkaṃ dvidhā niveśya grāma /vadheavaskande
analyzed: abhityakta śāsanaiḥ pratisamānayeyuḥ  lubdhaka vyañjanāḥ vā māṃsa vikrayeṇa dvāhsthāḥ dauvārika apāśrayāḥ cora abhyāgamam  parasya dvis tris iti nivedya labdha pratyayā bhartuḥ anīkam dvidhā niveśya grāma vadhe avaskande
translated: Or they may cause the enemy to be attacked by those who have been abandoned by the king.🔽Or spies, disguised as hunters, may, through the sale of meat, get into the confidence of the gatekeepers and the doorkeepers of the enemy, and inform the latter twice or thrice that a band of thieves is approaching.

analyzed: ca dviṣataḥ brūyuḥ āsannaḥ ca ura gaṇaḥ
translated: Having obtained their confidence, they may divide the army of the enemy into two parts, and tell the commander of the army that a band of thieves is approaching to plunder the villages and to attack the army.🔽They may say to the enemy, “A large band of thieves is near.

analyzed: mahān ca ākrandaḥ
translated: There is a great uproar.

analyzed: prabhūtam sainyam āgacchatu iti
translated: Let a large army come.”

original: tad arpayitvā grāma /ghāta /daṇḍasya sainyam itarad ādāya rātrau durga /dvāreṣu brūyuḥ hataś cora /gaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tat arpayitvā grāma ghāta daṇḍasya sainyam itarat ādāya rātrau durga dvāreṣu brūyuḥ hataḥ cora gaṇaḥ
translated: Having thus deceived the army, they may take away the army that was sent to punish the plunderers of the villages, and at night, at the gates of the fort, they may say, “The band of thieves has been killed.

analyzed: siddha yātram idam sainyam āgatam
translated: This army has come back successful.

analyzed: dvāram apāvriyatām iti
translated: Open the gates.”

analyzed: pūrva praṇihitāḥ vā dvārāṇi dadyuḥ
translated: Or those who have been previously employed may open the gates.

analyzed: taiḥ saha prahareyuḥ
translated: They may strike with them.

analyzed: kāru śilpi pāṣaṇḍa kuśīlava vaidehaka vyañjanān āyudhīyān vā para durge praṇidadhyāt
translated: He may also employ spies under the guise of artisans, heretics, bards, and traders, or as soldiers, in the enemy’s fort.

analyzed: teṣām gṛhapatika vyañjanāḥ kāṣṭha tṛṇa dhānya paṇya śakaṭaiḥ praharaṇa āvaraṇāni abhihareyuḥ
translated: Spies under the guise of householders may carry weapons and armour under the pretext of carrying timber, grass, grain, merchandise, and other goods.

analyzed: deva dhvaja pratimābhiḥ vā
translated: Or they may carry weapons under the guise of the images of gods and banners.

original: tatas tad /vyañjanāḥ pramatta /vadham avaskanda /pratigraham abhipraharaṇaṃ pṛṣṭhataḥ śaṅkha /dundubhi /śabdena vā praviṣṭam ity āvedayeyuḥ
analyzed: tatas tad vyañjanāḥ pramatta vadham avaskanda pratigraham abhipraharaṇam pṛṣṭhatas śaṅkha dundubhi śabdena vā praviṣṭam iti āvedayeyuḥ
translated: Then spies under the guise of those people may inform the king that the enemy is careless, that he is surrounded by traitors, that he is attacked, or that he has entered the fort, under the pretext of the sound of conches and drums.

analyzed: prākāra dvāra aṭṭālaka dānam anīka bhedam ghātam vā kuryuḥ
translated: They may also give the enemy’s fort, gates, and watch towers, cause dissension in his army, or kill him.🔽Spies living in caravans, as guides, as carriers of maidens, as traders in horses and other goods, as carriers of equipment, as buyers and sellers of grain, or as ascetics,

original: sārtha /gaṇa /vāsibhir ātivāhikaiḥ kanyā /vāhikair aśva /paṇya /vyavahāribhir upakaraṇa /hārakair dhānya /kretṛ /vikretṛbhir vā pravrajita /liṅgibhir 🔽dūtaiś ca daṇaḍ /atinayanam /
analyzed: sārtha gaṇa vāsibhiḥ ātivāhikaiḥ kanyā vāhikaiḥ aśva paṇya vyavahāribhiḥ upakaraṇa hārakaiḥ dhānya kretṛ vikretṛbhiḥ vā pravrajita liṅgibhiḥ  dūtaiḥ ca daṇa ḍati nayanam
translated: may bring about the capture of the enemy’s army by the use of spies.

analyzed: saṃdhi karma viśvāsana artham
translated: This is for the purpose of creating confidence in the work of peace.

analyzed: iti rāja apasarpāḥ
translated: Thus end the royal spies.

analyzed: ete eva aṭavīnām apasarpāḥ kaṇṭaka śodhana uktāḥ ca
translated: These same spies, as well as those mentioned in the section on the removal of thorns, may be employed in the forests.

original: vrajam aṭavy /āsannam apasarpāḥ sārthaṃ vā corair ghātayeyuḥ //🔽kṛta /saṃketam anna /pānaṃ caatra madana /rasa /viddhaṃ vā kṛtvāapagaccheyuḥ //
analyzed: vrajam aṭavī āsannam apasarpāḥ sārtham vā coraiḥ ghātayeyuḥ  kṛta saṃketam anna pānam ca atra madana rasa viddham vā kṛtvā apagaccheyuḥ
translated: Spies may cause the robbers to kill the people of the forest or the people of the neighbouring villages, or the caravan of merchants.🔽Having made an appointment with the people of the forest or the neighbouring villages, the spies may go away after having mixed with their food and drink the juice of madana plant.

original: go /pālaka /vaidehakāś ca tataś corān gṛhīta /loptra /bhārān madana /rasa /vikāra /kāleavaskandayeyuḥ //
analyzed: gopālaka vaidehakāḥ ca tatas corān gṛhīta loptra bhārān madana rasa vikāra kāle avaskandayeyuḥ
translated: The cowherds and the merchants may attack the robbers when they are carrying away the booty and are under the influence of the juice of madana plant.

analyzed: saṃkarṣaṇa daivatīyaḥ vā muṇḍa jaṭila vyañjanaḥ prahavaṇa karmaṇā madana rasa yogena atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: Or a spy under the guise of a religious mendicant with shaven head or matted hair, and in league with the enemy, may kill the robbers by administering the juice of madana plant under the pretext of a religious sacrifice.

analyzed: atha avaskandam dadyāt
translated: Then he may give the signal for attack.

original: śauṇḍika /vyañjano vā daivata /preta /kārya /utsava /samājeṣv āṭavikān surā /vikraya /upāyana /nimittaṃ madana /rasa /yogenaatisaṃdadhyāt
analyzed: śauṇḍika vyañjanaḥ vā daivata pretakārya autsava samājeṣu āṭavikān surā vikraya upāyana nimittam madana rasa yogena atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: Or a spy under the guise of a liquorseller may kill the foresters by administering the juice of madana plant under the pretext of selling liquor at the time of religious festivals, obsequies, and social gatherings.

analyzed: atha avaskandam dadyāt
translated: Then he may give the signal for attack.

analyzed: grāma ghāta praviṣṭām vā vikṣipya bahudhā aṭavīm
translated: Or having scattered the foresters in various directions, he may cause them to be killed.

original: ghātayed iti corāṇām apasarpāḥ prakīrtitāḥ //E🔽paryupāsana /karma avamardah
analyzed: ghātayet iti corāṇām apasarpāḥ prakīrtitāḥ  paryupāsana karma
translated: Thus have the spies been described as the means of destroying the robbers.🔽The work of surrounding the enemy is called avamarda.

analyzed: karśana pūrvam paryupāsana karma
translated: The work of surrounding the enemy is preceded by the work of harassing the enemy.

analyzed: janapadam yathā niviṣṭam abhaye sthāpayet
translated: He should establish the people of the country in a place free from danger, as they are settled.

analyzed: utthitam anugraha parihārābhyām niveṣayet
translated: If they rise up, he should settle them by favour and punishment,

analyzed: anyatra apasarataḥ
translated: except those who flee to another place.

analyzed: saṃgrāmāt anyasyām bhūmau niveśayet
translated: He should settle them in a place other than the battlefield.

analyzed: ekasyām vā vāsayet
translated: Or he should keep them in one place.

original: na hy ajano jana /pado rājyam ajana /padaṃ vā bhavatiiti kauṭilyaḥ //🔽viṣamasthasya muṣṭiṃ sasyaṃ vā hanyād /🔽vīvadha /prasārau ca //
analyzed: na hi a janaḥ janapadaḥ rājyam a janapadam vā bhavati iti kauṭilyaḥ  viṣama sthasya muṣṭim sasyam vā hanyāt  vīvadha prasārau ca
translated: For, says Kautilya, a country without people or a country with people is not a kingdom.🔽When the enemy is in a difficult situation, he should destroy his crops or his fist.🔽And he should destroy his supply and spread.

analyzed: prasāra vīvadha chedāt muṣṭi sasya vadhāt api
translated: From the destruction of the spread, supply, and fist, and from the destruction of the crops,

analyzed: vamanāt gūḍha ghātāt ca jāyate prakṛti kṣayaḥ
translated: from vomiting and secret killing, the destruction of the people arises.
When he is bound by many good qualities,🔽my army is complete with other weapons, machines, armour, and provisions, and with iron.

original: anya /kupya /yantra /śastra /āvaraṇa /viṣṭir aśmi /samagraṃ me sainyam /🔽ṛtuś ca purastāt /
analyzed: anya kupya yantra śastra āvaraṇa viṣṭiḥ aśmi samagram me sainyam  ṛtuḥ ca purastāt
translated: And the season is favourable for me.

analyzed: a partuḥ parasya
translated: But for the enemy it is unfavourable.

original: vyādhi /durbhikṣa /nicaya /rakṣā /kṣayaḥ krīta /bala /nirvedo mitra /bala /nirvedaś ca iti paryupāsīta //
analyzed: vyādhi durbhikṣa nicaya rakṣā kṣayaḥ krīta bala nirvedaḥ mitra bala nirvedaḥ ca iti paryupāsīta
translated: He should wait, considering the protection of his stores, the destruction of his army by disease and famine, the disaffection of his hired army, and the disaffection of his friendly army.

original: kṛtvā skandha /āvārasya rakṣāṃ vīvadha /āsārayoḥ pathaś ca /
analyzed: kṛtvā skandha āvārasya rakṣām vīvadha āsārayoḥ pathaḥ ca
translated: Having made the protection of the baggage train, of the supply and spread, and of the road,

analyzed: parikṣipya durgam khāta sālābhyām
translated: Having dug a trench around the fort, he should fill it with sharp pointed spikes.

analyzed: dūṣayitvā udakam  avasrāvya parikhāḥ sampūrayitvā vā
translated: Having poisoned the water,🔽he should let out the water of the moat, or fill it up.

analyzed: suruṅgā bala kuṭikābhyām vapra prākārau hārayet  dāram ca guḍena
translated: He should destroy the rampart and the wall by means of a tunnel, an army, or a hut.🔽And he should destroy the gate with molasses.

analyzed: nimnam vā pāṃsu mālayā ācchādayet
translated: Or he should cover the low-lying areas with a mound of sand.

analyzed: bahulaārakṣam yantraiḥ ghātayet
translated: He should destroy the fort with many guards by means of machines.

analyzed: niṣkirāt upaniṣkṛṣya aśvaiḥ ca prahareyuḥ
translated: And they should strike with horses, having drawn out the fort from the unassailable position.

original: vikrama /antareṣu ca niyoga /vikalpa /samuccayaiś caupāyānāṃ siddhiṃ lipseta //
analyzed: vikrama antareṣu ca niyoga vikalpa samuccayaiḥ ca aupāyānām siddhim lipseta
translated: And he should seek success of the expedients by means of appointment, option, and combination in the intervals of valor.

original: durga /vāsinaḥ śyena /kāka /naptṛ /bhāsa /śuka /sārika /ulūka /kapotān grāhayitvā puccheṣv agni /yoga /yuktān para /durge visṛjet //
analyzed: durga vāsinaḥ śyena kāka naptṛ bhāsa śuka sārikā aulūka kapotān grāhayitvā puccheṣu agni yoga yuktān para durge visṛjet
translated: Having made hawks, crows, owls, peacocks, parrots, mynas, owls, and pigeons carry fire-sticks attached to their tails, he should release them in the enemy's fort.

original: apakṛṣṭa /skandha /āvārād ucchrita /dhvaja /dhanva /ārakṣo vā mānuṣeṇaagninā para /durgam ādīpayet //
analyzed: apakṛṣṭa skandha āvārāt ucchrita dhvaja dhanva ārakṣaḥ vā mānuṣeṇa agninā para durgam ādīpayet
translated: Or having removed the troops from the shoulders, with the protection of raised flags and bows, he should set fire to the enemy's fort with human fire.

original: gūḍha /purṣāś caantar /durga /pālakā nakula /vānara /biḍāla /śunāṃ puccheṣv agni /yogam ādhāya kāṇḍa /nicaya /rakṣā /vidhāna /veśmasu visṛjeyuḥ
analyzed: gūḍha purṣāḥ ca antar durga pālakāḥ nakula vānara biḍāla śunām puccheṣu agni yogam ādhāya kāṇḍa nicaya rakṣā vidhāna veśmasu visṛjeyuḥ
translated: Spies, who are the protectors of the inner fort, shall place fire in the tails of mongooses, monkeys, cats, and dogs, and set them free in the houses where the collection of arrows and other things are kept for the protection of the fort.

original: śuṣka /matsyānām udareṣv agnim ādhāya vallūre vā vāyasa /upahāreṇa vayobhir hārayeyuḥ //
analyzed: śuṣka matsyānām udareṣu agnim ādhāya vallūre vā vāyasa upahāreṇa vayobhiḥ hārayeyuḥ
translated: Having placed fire in the bellies of dried fish, or in the dung of asses, camels, goats, and sheep, they shall be carried away by crows as an offering.

original: sarala /deva /dāru /pūti /tṛṇa /guggulu /śrī /veṣṭakasarjarasalākṣāgulikāḥ khara /uṣṭra /ajāvīnāṃ leṇḍaṃ caagni /dhāraṇam //🔽priyāla /cūrṇam avalgu /jamaṣī /madhu /ucchiṣṭam aśva /khara /uṣṭra /go /leṇḍam ity eṣa kṣepyoagni /yogaḥ //
analyzed: sarala devadāru pūtitṛṇa guggulu śrīveṣṭaka sarjarasa lākṣā gulikāḥ khara oṣṭra aja avīnām leṇḍam ca agni dhāraṇam  priyāla cūrṇam avalguja maṣī madhu ucchiṣṭam aśva khara oṣṭra go leṇḍam iti eṣa kṣepyaḥ agni yogaḥ
translated: Sarala, Deva, Daru, Putti, Trina, Guggula, Shriveshtaka, Sarjarasa, and Laksha are the fire-holding substances.🔽The powder of Priyala, the dung of a cow, honey, the residue of honey, and the dung of horses, asses, camels, and cows are the fire-throwing substances.

original: sarva /loha /cūrṇam agni /varṇaṃ vā kumbhī /sīsa /trapu /cūrṇaṃ vā pāribhadraka /palāśa /puṣpa /keśa /maṣī /taila /madhu /ucchiṣṭaka /śrī /veṣṭaka /yuktoagni /yogo
analyzed: sarva loha cūrṇam agni varṇam vā kumbhī sīsa trapu cūrṇam vā pāribhadraka palāśa puṣpa keśa maṣī taila madhu ucchiṣṭaka śrīveṣṭaka yuktaḥ agni yogaḥ
translated: The powder of all metals, or the powder of Kumbhi, lead, and tin, mixed with the ink of Paribhadda, Palasha, Pushpa, and Kesha, oil, honey, the residue of honey, and Shriveshtaka, is the fire-holding substance.

analyzed: viśvāsa ghātī vā
translated: Or it destroys trust.

analyzed: tena avaliptaḥ śaṇa trapusa valka veṣṭitaḥ bāṇaḥ iti agni yogaḥ
translated: Smeared with that, wrapped in the bark of Shana and Trapusa, it is an arrow-like fire-holding substance.

original: na tv eva vidyamāne parākrameagnim avasṛjet //
analyzed: na tu eva vidyamāne parākrame agnim avasṛjet
translated: but not if he has the power to do so.

analyzed: a viśvāsyaḥ hi agniḥ daiva pīḍanam ca
translated: For fire is untrustworthy, and it causes divine displeasure.

analyzed: a pratisaṃkhyāta prāṇi dhānya paśu hiraṇya kupya dravya kṣaya karaḥ
translated: It causes the destruction of living beings, grains, cattle, gold, and other valuable goods without any consideration.

original: kṣīṇa /nicayaṃ caavāptam api rājyaṃ kṣayāyaeva bhavati //🔽iti paryupāsana /karma
analyzed: kṣīṇa nicayam ca avāptam api rājyam kṣayāya eva bhavati  iti paryupāsana karma
translated: A kingdom, even if acquired, becomes a cause of destruction if its resources are exhausted.🔽Thus ends the chapter on the time for conquest, the sixth in the first book of the Arthashastra.

analyzed: sarva ārambha aupakaraṇa viṣṭi sampannaḥ asmi
translated: I am well-supplied with the means and labour for all undertakings.

analyzed: vyādhitaḥ paraḥ upadhā viruddha prakṛtiḥ akṛta durga karma nicayaḥ vā
translated: My enemy is afflicted with disease, or has a disaffected population, or has not built forts or accumulated resources.

original: nirāsāraḥ sāsāro vā purā mitraiḥ saṃdhatte ity avamarda /kālaḥ //
analyzed: nirāsāraḥ sa āsāraḥ vā purā mitraiḥ saṃdhatte iti avamarda kālaḥ
translated: Whether he has or has not a strong army, I shall make peace with my allies and then attack him. This is the time for conquest.

original: svayam agnau jāte samutthāpite vā prahavaṇe prekṣā /anīka /darśana /saṅga /saurika /kalaheṣu
analyzed: svayam agnau jāte samutthāpite vā prahavaṇe prekṣā anīka darśana saṅga saurika kalaheṣu
translated: When a fire has broken out by itself or has been set on purpose, or when there is a festival, or when people are watching a military parade or a battle, or when there is a quarrel over a prostitute or wine,

analyzed: nitya yuddha śrānta bale bahula yuddha pratividdha preta puruṣe jāgaraṇa klānta supta jane
translated: when the army is tired from constant fighting, when many soldiers have been killed or have deserted, when the people are exhausted from keeping awake at night, or when they are sleeping,

analyzed: durdine nadī vege vā nīhāra samplave vā avamṛdnīyāt
translated: or when it is a bad day, or when the river is in spate, or when there is a thick fog, then is the time to attack.

original: skandha /āvāram utsṛjya vā vana /gūḍhaḥ śatruṃ niṣkrāntaṃ ghātayet //
analyzed: skandha āvāram utsṛjya vā vana gūḍhaḥ śatrum niṣkrāntam ghātayet
translated: Or, having abandoned the siege, he may kill the enemy who has come out, while the latter is in the forest.

original: mitra /āsāra /mukhya /vyañjano vā samruddhena maitrīṃ kṛtvā dūtam abhityaktaṃ preṣayet idaṃ te chidram /
analyzed: mitra āsāra mukhya vyañjanaḥ vā samruddhena maitrīm kṛtvā dūtam abhityaktam preṣayet idam te chidram
translated: Or, under the guise of a friend or a chief of a tribe, he may make peace with the besieged king and send an envoy to him, saying, This is your weak point.

analyzed: ime dūṣyāḥ samroddhuḥ vā chidram
translated: These are the traitors. The besieger will destroy you.

analyzed: ayam te kṛtya pakṣaḥ iti
translated: This is your party for the accomplishment of your object.

original: taṃ pratidūtam ādāya nirgacchantaṃ vijigīṣur gṛhītvā doṣam abhivikhyāpya pravāsya apagacchet //
analyzed: tam pratidūtam ādāya nirgacchantam vijigīṣuḥ gṛhītvā doṣam abhivikhyāpya pravāsya apagacchet
translated: When the envoy of the besieged king comes out to meet the conqueror, the latter may seize him, proclaim his guilt, banish him, and go away.

original: tato mitra /āsāra /vyañjano vā samruddhaṃ brūyāt māṃ trātum upanirgaccha /
analyzed: tatas mitra āsāra vyañjanaḥ vā samruddham brūyāt mām trātum upanirgaccha
translated: Or, under the guise of a friend or a chief of a tribe, he may say to the besieged king, Come out to save me.

original: mayā vā saha samroddhāraṃ jahi iti //
analyzed: mayā vā saha samroddhāram jahi iti
translated: Or, with me, kill the besieger.

analyzed: pratipannam ubhayatas sampīḍanena ghātayet
translated: When the besieged king agrees to the proposal, the conqueror may kill him by attacking him on both sides.

analyzed: jīva grāheṇa vā rājya vinimayam kārayet
translated: Or, having captured him alive, he may make an agreement of peace with the king.

analyzed: nagaram vā aasya pramṛdnīyāt
translated: Or, he may destroy the city of the besieged king.

analyzed: sāra balam vā asya vamayitvā abhihanyāt
translated: Or, having caused the strong army of the besieged king to come out, he may kill it.

analyzed: tena daṇḍa aupanata āṭavikāḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: By this, the conquered king and the wild tribes are explained.

original: daṇḍa /upanata /āṭavikayor anyataro vā samruddhasya preṣayet ayaṃ samroddhā vyādhitaḥ /
analyzed: daṇḍa aupanata āṭavikayoḥ anyataraḥ vā samruddhasya preṣayet ayam samroddhā vyādhitaḥ
translated: Or a person sent by the enemy, or a forest tribe, or one of the two, may inform the besieged king that the besieger is sick,

analyzed: pārṣṇigrāheṇa abhiyuktaḥ
translated: or that he is attacked by an enemy in his rear,

analyzed: chidram anyat utthitam
translated: or that some other danger has arisen,

analyzed: anyasyām bhūmau apayātu kāmaḥ iti
translated: or that he may go to another place, if he likes.

analyzed: pratipanne samroddhā skandha āvāram ādīpya apayāyāt
translated: When the besieger accepts the proposal, the besieged king may set fire to the besieger’s army and run away.

original: tataḥ pūrvavad ācaret //🔽paṇya /sampātaṃ vā kṛtvā paṇyenaenaṃ rasa /viddhenaatisaṃdadhyāt //
analyzed: tatas pūrvavat ācaret  paṇya sampātam vā kṛtvā paṇyena enam rasa viddhena atisaṃdadhyāt
translated: Then he may act as before.🔽Or having made a market, he may sell to the besieger poison mixed with merchandise.

original: āsāra /vyañjano vā samruddhasya dūtaṃ preṣayet mayā bāhyam abhihatam upanirgacchaabhihantum iti //
analyzed: āsāra vyañjanaḥ vā samruddhasya dūtam preṣayet mayā bāhyam abhihatam upanirgaccha abhihantum iti
translated: Or a person under the guise of a friend may send a messenger to the besieged king, saying, “I have attacked the enemy outside. Come out to attack him.”

analyzed: pratipannam pūrvavat ācaret
translated: When the besieged king accepts the proposal, he may act as before.

original: mitraṃ bandhuṃ vāapadiśya yoga /puruṣāḥ śāsana /mudrā /hastāḥ praviśya durgaṃ grāhayeyuḥ //
analyzed: mitram bandhum vā apadiśya yoga puruṣāḥ śāsana mudrā hastāḥ praviśya durgam grāhayeyuḥ
translated: Or under the guise of a friend or a relative, spies with forged orders and seals may enter the fort and seize it.

original: āsāra /vyañjñano vā samruddhasya preṣayet amuṣmin deśe kāle ca skandha /āvāram abhihaniṣyāmi /
analyzed: āsāra vyañjñanaḥ vā samruddhasya preṣayet amuṣmin deśe kāle ca skandhaāvāram abhihaniṣyāmi
translated: Or a person under the guise of a friend may send a messenger to the besieged king, saying, “I shall attack the besieger’s army in such and such a place and at such and such a time.

analyzed: yuṣmābhiḥ api yoddhavyam iti
translated: You too should fight.”

original: pratipannaṃ yathā /uktam abhyāghāta /saṃkulaṃ darśayitvā rātrau durgān niṣkrāntaṃ ghātayet //
analyzed: pratipannam yathā uktam abhyāghāta saṃkulam darśayitvā rātrau durgāt niṣkrāntam ghātayet
translated: Or, having shown him the danger of being attacked and surrounded, he may cause him to be killed at night when he comes out of his fort.

original: yad vā mitram āvāhayed āṭavvikaṃ vā /
analyzed: yat vā mitram āvāhayet āṭavvikam vā
translated: Or he may invite a friend or a wild chief.

original: tam utsāhayet vikramya samruddhe bhūmim asya pratipadyasva iti //🔽vikrāntaṃ prakṛtibhir dūṣya /mukhya /upagraheṇa vā ghātayet /
analyzed: tam utsāhayet vikramya samruddhe bhūmim asya pratipadyasva iti  vikrāntam prakṛtibhiḥ dūṣya mukhya aupagraheṇa vā ghātayet
translated: And he may encourage him, saying, “Having shown your prowess, take possession of his land when he is surrounded.”🔽When the latter has shown his prowess, the conqueror may cause him to be killed by his own subjects or by the chief of the traitors.

original: svayaṃ vā rasena mitra /ghātakoayam ity avāpta /arthaḥ //🔽vikramitu /kāmaṃ vā mitra /vyañjanaḥ parasyaabhiśaṃset //🔽āpta /bhāva /upagataḥ pravīra /puruṣānasyaupaghātayet //
analyzed: svayam vā rasena mitra ghātakaḥ ayam iti avāpta arthaḥ  vikramitu kāmam vā mitra vyañjanaḥ parasya abhiśaṃset  āpta bhāva aupagataḥ pravīra puruṣān asya aupaghātayet
translated: Or, having gained his object, he may cause him to be killed by poison, saying, “He is a friend’s murderer.”🔽Or, when the friend is desirous of showing his prowess, he may be denounced by a friend’s messenger to the enemy.🔽Or, having gained his confidence, he may cause the enemy’s best men to be killed.

original: saṃdhiṃ vā kṛtvā jana /padam enaṃ niveśayet //
analyzed: saṃdhim vā kṛtvā janapadam enam niveśayet
translated: Or, having made peace with him, he may settle his people in the enemy’s country.

analyzed: niviṣṭam asya janapadam a vijñātaḥ hanyāt
translated: When his people are settled there, he may secretly kill them.

original: apakārayitvā dūṣya /āṭavikeṣu vā bala /eka /deśam atinīya durgam avaskandena hārayet //
analyzed: apakārayitvā dūṣya āṭavikeṣu vā bala eka deśam atinīya durgam avaskandena hārayet
translated: Or, having caused the enemy to be attacked by the traitors and wild chiefs, he may cause him to be killed by a surprise attack when he goes out with a part of his army.

original: dūṣya /amitra /āṭavika /dveṣya /pratyapasṛtāś ca kṛta /artha /māna /saṃjñā /cihnāḥ para /durgam avaskandeyuḥ //🔽para /durgam avaskandya skandha /āvāraṃ vā patita /parān /mukha /abhipannam ukta /keśa /śastra /bhaya /virūpebhyaś caabhayam ayudhyamānebhyaś 🔽ca dadyuḥ //
analyzed: dūṣya amitra āṭavika dveṣya pratyapasṛtāḥ ca kṛta artha māna saṃjñā cihnāḥ para durgam avaskandeyuḥ  para durgam avaskandya skandha āvāram vā patita parānmukha abhipannam ukta keśa śastra bhaya virūpebhyaḥ ca abhayam ayudhyamānebhyaḥ  ca dadyuḥ
translated: and those who are disaffected, inimical, wild, hated, and who have fled to the enemy, should, after having been honoured and marked with badges, be employed in the work of capturing the enemy’s fort.🔽Having captured the enemy’s fort, they should grant safety to those who have fallen into the hands of the enemy, to those who have turned their faces against the enemy, to those whose hair has been cut off, to those who have laid down their arms, to those who are frightened, and to those who are deformed, and to those who do not fight.

original: para /durgam avāpya viśuddha /śatru /pakṣaṃ kṛta /upāṃśu /daṇḍa /pratīkāram antar /bahiś ca praviśet //
analyzed: para durgam avāpya viśuddha śatru pakṣam kṛta aupāṃśu daṇḍa pratīkāram antar bahis ca praviśet
translated: Having captured the enemy’s fort, and having cleared the country of the enemy’s partisans, and having made arrangements for the collection of revenue and for the protection of the people, he should enter into the country both by the main road and by the byroads.

original: evaṃ vijigīṣur amitra /bhūmiṃ labdhvā madhyamaṃ lipseta /🔽tat /siddhāv udāsīnam //
analyzed: evam vijigīṣuḥ amitra bhūmim labdhvā madhyamam lipseta  tad siddhau udāsīnam
translated: Having thus captured the enemy’s country, the conqueror should next try to win over a madhyama king.🔽If he succeeds in winning over the madhyama king, he should then try to win over the neutral king.

analyzed: eṣa prathamaḥ mārgaḥ pṛthivīm jetum
translated: This is the first way of conquering the earth.

analyzed: sādhayet
translated: In the absence of a madhyama and a neutral king, the conqueror should try to win over the partisans of the enemy by superior merits.

analyzed: tatas uttarāḥ prakṛtīḥ
translated: Then he should try to win over the other partisans of the enemy.

analyzed: eṣa dvitīyaḥ mārgaḥ
translated: This is the second way.

original: maṇḍalasyaabhāve śatruṇā mitraṃ mitreṇa vā śatrum ubhayataḥ /sampīḍanena sādhayet //
analyzed: maṇḍalasya abhāve śatruṇā mitram mitreṇa vā śatrum ubhayatas sampīḍanena sādhayet
translated: In the absence of a circle of states, the conqueror should try to win over a friend by the help of an enemy, or an enemy by the help of a friend, by the process of ubhāyatoblīya.

analyzed: eṣa tṛtīyaḥ mārgaḥ
translated: This is the third way.

analyzed: śakyam ekam vā sāmantam sādhayet
translated: Or he may try to win over one of the neighbouring kings.

analyzed: tena dviguṇaḥ dvitīyam
translated: By doubling the amount he may win over the second.

analyzed: triguṇaḥ tṛtīyam
translated: By tripling the amount he may win over the third.

analyzed: eṣa caturthaḥ mārgaḥ pṛthivīm jetum
translated: This is the fourth way of conquering the earth.

original: jitvā ca pṛthivīṃ vibhakta /varṇa /āśramāṃ sva /dharmeṇa bhuñjīta //🔽upajāpoapasarpaś ca vāmanaṃ paryupāsanam /
analyzed: jitvā ca pṛthivīm vibhakta varṇa āśramām svadharmeṇa bhuñjīta  upajāpaḥ apasarpaḥ ca vāmanam paryupāsanam
translated: And having conquered the earth, he should enjoy it according to his own duty, with the castes and the orders of life duly distinguished.

analyzed: avamardaḥ ca pañca ete durga lambhasya hetavaḥ
translated: Sowing dissension, retreat, dwarfing, attendance, and humiliation—these five are the means of acquiring a fortress.

analyzed: labdha praśamanam
translated: The pacification of what has been acquired

original: dvividhaṃ vijigīṣoḥ samutthānaṃ aṭavy /ādikam eka /grāma /ādikaṃ ca //
analyzed: dvividham vijigīṣoḥ samutthānam aṭavī ādikam eka grāma ādikam ca
translated: The rise of an ambitious king is of two kinds—one from the forest, and the other from a single village.

analyzed: trividhaḥ ca asya lambhaḥ
translated: And his acquisition is of three kinds—new,

analyzed: bhūta pūrvaḥ pitryaḥ iti
translated: hereditary, and paternal.

original: navam avāpya lābhaṃ para /doṣān sva /guṇaiś chādayet /
analyzed: navam avāpya lābham para doṣān sva guṇaiḥ chādayet
translated: Having acquired a new acquisition, he should conceal the faults of others with his own virtues.

analyzed: guṇān guṇa dvaiguṇyena
translated: And his virtues with the virtues of others, by doubling them.

analyzed: svadharma karma anugraha parihāra dāna māna karmabhiḥ ca prakṛti priya hitāni anuvarteta
translated: And he should follow the inclinations of his subjects, by favouring and avoiding those who are dear and beneficial to them, by gifts and honours, and by acts of righteousness.

analyzed: yathā sambhāṣitam ca kṛtya pakṣam upagrāhayet
translated: And he should win over to his side those who are favourably disposed, according to their conversation.

analyzed: bhūyas ca kṛta prayāsam
translated: And those who have already exerted themselves, again and again.

original: aviśvāso hi visaṃvādakaḥ sveṣāṃ pareṣāṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: aviśvāsaḥ hi visaṃvādakaḥ sveṣām pareṣām ca bhavati
translated: For distrust causes one to be deceived by one’s own men as well as by the enemy.

analyzed: prakṛti viruddha ācāraḥ ca
translated: And one whose conduct is contrary to the nature of the people is also deceived.

analyzed: tasmāt samāna śīla veṣa bhāṣā ācāra tām upagacchet
translated: Therefore, one should adopt the same conduct, dress, language and behaviour as the people.

analyzed: deśa daivata smāja otsava vihāreṣu ca bhaktim anuvarteta
translated: One should also show devotion to the local deities, assemblies and festivals.

original: deśa /grāma /jāti /saṃgha /mukhyeṣu caabhīkṣṇaṃ sattriṇaḥ parasyaapacāraṃ darśayeyuḥ /🔽māhābhāgyaṃ bhaktiṃ ca teṣu svāminaḥ /
analyzed: deśa grāma jāti saṃgha mukhyeṣu ca abhīkṣṇam sattriṇaḥ parasya apacāram darśayeyuḥ  māhābhāgyam bhaktim ca teṣu svāminaḥ
translated: Spies should frequently show the misconduct of the enemy to the chiefs of the country, village, caste and association.🔽And the king should show his greatness and devotion to them.

analyzed: svāmi satkāram ca vidyamānam
translated: And the king should show his respect to them.

analyzed: ucitaiḥ ca enān bhoga parihāra rakṣā avekṣaṇaiḥ bhuñjīta
translated: And he should enjoy them with proper pleasures, gifts, protection and supervision.

original: sarva /devatā /āśrama /pūjanaṃ ca vidyā /vākya /dharma /śūra /puruṣāṇāṃ ca bhūmi /dravya /dāna /parihārān kārayet /
analyzed: sarva devatā āśrama pūjanam ca vidyā vākya dharma śūra puruṣāṇām ca bhūmi dravya dāna parihārān kārayet
translated: And he should make gifts of land and wealth to those who are learned, eloquent and brave in accordance with the scriptures and the law.

analyzed: sarva bandhana mokṣaṇam anugraham dīna anātha vyādhitānām ca
translated: And he should release all prisoners, favour the poor, helpless and sick,

analyzed: cāturmāsyeṣu ardhamāsikam a ghātam
translated: and have a half-monthly holiday during the four months of the rainy season.

analyzed: paurṇamāsīṣu ca cātūrātrikam rāja deśa nakṣatreṣu aikarātrikam
translated: And a four-day holiday on the full moon days, and a one-day holiday on the king’s days and on the days of the lunar mansions.

analyzed: yoni bāla vadham puṃstva aupaghātam ca pratiṣedhayet
translated: He shall prohibit the killing of children in the womb and the injuring of manhood.

original: yac ca kośa /daṇḍa /upaghātakam adharmiṣṭhaṃ vā caritraṃ manyeta tad apanīya dharmya /vyavahāraṃ sthāpayet //
analyzed: yat ca kośa daṇḍa aupaghātakam adharmiṣṭham vā caritram manyeta tat apanīya dharmya vyavahāram sthāpayet
translated: And whatever he considers to be a sinful or unrighteous act that injures the treasury and the army, that he shall abolish and establish righteous conduct.

original: cora /prakṛtīnāṃ mleccha /jātīnāṃ ca sthāna /viparyāsam anekasthaṃ kārayet /
analyzed: cora prakṛtīnām mleccha jātīnām ca sthāna viparyāsam aneka stham kārayet
translated: He shall cause the places of thieves, of the disaffected, and of the Mlechchhas to be changed frequently.

analyzed: durga rāṣṭra daṇḍa mukhyānām ca
translated: And also the places of the commanders of forts, of the country, and of the army.

original: parā /upagṛhītānāṃ ca mantri /purohitānāṃ parasya pratyanteṣv anekasthaṃ vāsaṃ kārayet //
analyzed: ca mantri purohitānām parasya pratyanteṣu anekastham vāsam kārayet
translated: And the ministers and priests of the enemy who have been won over, he shall cause to reside in different places on the borders of the enemy's country.

original: apakāra /samarthān anukṣiyato vā bhartṛ /vināśam upāṃśu /daṇḍena praśamayet //
analyzed: apakāra samarthān anukṣiyataḥ vā bhartṛ vināśam upāṃśu daṇḍena praśamayet
translated: Those who are able to injure or who are being destroyed by their master, he shall appease by secret punishment.

original: sva /deśīyān vā pareṇa vāaparuddhān apavāhita /sthāneṣu sthāpayet //
analyzed: sva deśīyān vā pareṇa vā a aparuddhān apavāhita sthāneṣu sthāpayet
translated: Or those of his own country who have been captured by the enemy, he shall cause to be settled in places other than those from which they were carried away.

original: yaś ca tat /kulīnaḥ pratyādeyam ādātuṃ śaktaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ca tad kulīnaḥ pratyādeyam ādātum śaktaḥ
translated: And he who is of noble birth and is able to take back what has been seized,

analyzed: pratyanta aṭavī sthaḥ vā prabādhitum abhijātaḥ
