translated: White mustard seeds soaked for seven nights in the urine of a white goat.

original: marka / /kṣīra /lavaṇaṃ dhānyaṃ ca pakṣa /sthito yogaḥ śvetī /karaṇam //
analyzed: marka kṣīra lavaṇam dhānyam ca pakṣa sthitaḥ yogaḥ śvetīkaraṇam
translated: White mustard seeds soaked for seven nights in the urine of a white goat, mixed with the milk and salt of a white cow, and kept in a grain container for a fortnight, this preparation causes whitening.

original: kaṭuka /alābau valī /gate gataṃ /ardha /māsa /sthitaṃ gaura /sarṣapa /piṣṭaṃ romṇāṃ śvetī /karaṇam //
analyzed: kaṭuka alābau valī gate gatam ardha māsa sthitam gaurasarṣapa piṣṭam romṇām śvetīkaraṇam
translated: In a bitter gourd, when a wrinkle appears, half a month old white mustard paste is applied to the hair, causing them to become white.

original: alojuneti yaḥ kīṭaḥ śvetā ca gṛha /golikā /
analyzed: alojunā iti yaḥ kīṭaḥ śvetā ca gṛhagolikā
translated: The insect called alojuna and the white house-lizard,

analyzed: etena piṣtena abhyaktāḥ keśāḥ syuḥ śaṅkha pāṇḍarāḥ
translated: the hair anointed with a paste made from these becomes the color of conch shells.

original: gomayena tinduka /ariṣṭa /kalkena vā mardita /aṅgasya bhallātaka /rasa /anuliptasya māsikaḥ kuṣṭha /yogaḥ //
analyzed: gomayena tinduka ariṣṭa kalkena vā mardita aṅgasya bhallātaka rasa anuliptasya māsikaḥ kuṣṭha yogaḥ
translated: The body is massaged with a paste of cow dung or tinduka and arishta, and smeared with the juice of bhallataka. This is a monthly kushtha preparation.

original: kṛṣṇa /sarpa /mukhe gṛha /golikā /mukhe vā sapta /rātra /uṣitā gujjāḥ kuṣṭha /yogaḥ //🔽śuka /pitta /aṇḍa /rasa /abhyaṅgaḥ kuṣṭha /yogaḥ //
analyzed: kṛṣṇasarpa mukhe gṛhagolikā mukhe vā sapta rātra uṣitāḥ gujjāḥ kuṣṭha yogaḥ
translated: Gujja soaked for seven nights in the mouth of a black cobra or a house-lizard is a kushtha preparation.🔽Anointing with the juice of parrot bile and eggs is a kushtha preparation.
A paste and decoction of kushtha and priyala is the remedy.
One who eats a diet of chicken eggs, atasi,

analyzed: śatāvarī mūla yuktam āhārayamāṇaḥ māsena gauraḥ bhavati
translated: and shatavari roots becomes fair in a month.

analyzed: bhavati
translated: One who has bathed with a decoction of banyan tree, and has smeared his body with a paste of sahacara, becomes black.

analyzed: śakuna kaṇgu taila yuktāḥ haritāla manaḥśilāḥ śyāmīkaraṇam
translated: Harita, tala, and manahshila mixed with the oil of shakun and kangugu are used for darkening.

original: kha /dyota /cūrṇaṃ sarṣapa /taila /yuktaṃ rātrau jvalati //🔽kha /dyota /gaṇḍū /pada /cūrṇaṃ samudra /jantūnāṃ bhṛṅga /kapālānāṃ khadira /karṇikārāṇāṃ puṣpa /cūrṇaṃ vā śakuna /kaṅgu /taila /yuktaṃ tejana /cūrṇam
analyzed: khadyota cūrṇam sarṣapa taila yuktam rātrau jvalati  khadyota gaṇḍūpada cūrṇam samudrajantūnām bhṛṅga kapālānām khadira karṇikārāṇām puṣpa cūrṇam vā śakuna kaṅgu taila yuktam tejana cūrṇam
translated: A powder of khadrota mixed with mustard oil burns at night.🔽A powder of khadrota, gandupada, and sea creatures, or a powder of bhringa, skull, khadira, and karnikara flowers mixed with the oil of shakun and kangugu is a burning powder.

original: pāribhadraka /tvan /maṣī maṇḍūka /vasayā yuktā gātra /prajvālanam agninā //🔽paribhadraka /tvak /tila /kalka /pradigdhaṃ śarīram agninā jvalati //
analyzed: paribhadraka tvac tila kalka pradigdham śarīram agninā jvalati
translated: Ink made from the bark of paribhadraka mixed with the fat of a frog causes the body to burn with fire.🔽The body smeared with a paste of paribhadraka bark and sesame seeds burns with fire.

analyzed: pīlu tvat maṣī mayaḥ piṇḍaḥ haste jvalati
translated: A ball made of the ink of pilu bark burns in the hand.

analyzed: maṇḍūka vasā digdhaḥ agninā jvalati
translated: Smeared with the fat of a frog, it burns with fire.

original: tena pradigdham aṅgaṃ kuśa /āmra /phala /taila /siktaṃ samudra /maṇḍūkī /phenaka /sarja /rasa /cūrṇa /yuktaṃ vā jvalati //
analyzed: tena pradigdham aṅgam kuśa āmra phala taila siktam samudramaṇḍūkī phenaka sarja rasa cūrṇa yuktam vā jvalati
translated: The body smeared with that, sprinkled with the oil of kusha and mango fruits, or mixed with the powder of sea foam, manduki, and sarja resin, burns.

original: maṇḍūka /kulīra /ādīnāṃ vasayā sama /bhāgaṃ tailaṃ siddham abhyaṅgaṃ gātrāṇām agni /prajvālanam //🔽veṇu /mūla /śaivala /liptam aṅgaṃ maṇḍūka /vasā /digdham agninā jvalati //
analyzed: maṇḍūka kulīra ādīnām vasayā sama bhāgam tailam siddham abhyaṅgam gātrāṇām agni prajvālanam  veṇu mūla śaivala liptam aṅgam maṇḍūka vasā digdham agninā jvalati
translated: Oil cooked with the fat of frogs, cuckoos, etc., in equal parts, when applied as an unguent, sets the body on fire.🔽The body smeared with the paste of bamboo roots and moss, anointed with frog fat, catches fire.

analyzed: pāribhadra kappatibalā vañjula vajra kadala mūla kalkena maṇḍūka vasā siddhena tailena abhyakta pādaḥ aṅgāreṣu gacchati
translated: With the paste of the roots of Paribhadraka, Pratibala, Vanjula, Vajra, and Kadali, cooked with frog fat, the feet anointed with oil, one walks on hot coals.

original: upa /udakā pratibalā vañjulaḥ pāribhadrakaḥ /🔽eteṣāṃ mūla /kalkena maṇḍūka /vasayā saha //
analyzed: eteṣām mūla kalkena maṇḍūka vasayā saha
translated: Pratibala is the Vanjula, Paribhadraka, and Kadali.🔽With the paste of their roots, along with frog fat,

original: sādhayet tailam etena pādāv abhyajya nirmalau /
analyzed: sādhayet tailam etena pādau abhyajya nirmalau
translated: one should cook oil. Having anointed the feet with this, they become clean.

analyzed: aṅgāra rāśau vicaret yathā kusuma saṃcaye
translated: One can walk on a heap of hot coals as if on a heap of flowers.

original: haṃsa /krauñca /mayūrāṇām anyeṣāṃ vā mahā /śakunīnām udaka /plavānāṃ puccheṣu baddhā nala /dīpikā rātrāv ulkā /darśanam //
analyzed: haṃsa krauñca mayūrāṇām anyeṣām vā mahā śakunīnām udaka plavānām puccheṣu baddhā nala dīpikā rātrau ulkā darśanam
translated: A bamboo torch tied to the tails of swans, cranes, peacocks, or other large water-flying birds shows lightning at night.

analyzed: vaidyutam bhasma aṅgi śamanam
translated: The ashes of lightning are soothing to the body.

original: strī /puṣpa /pāyitā māṣā vrajakulī /mūlaṃ maṇḍūka /vasā /miśraṃ culluyāṃ dīptāyām apācanam //
analyzed: strī puṣpa pāyitāḥ māṣāḥ vrajakulī mūlam maṇḍūka vasā miśram culluyām dīptāyām apācanam
translated: A paste of women's menstrual blood, flowers, and beans, mixed with the root of Vrajakulim and frog fat, should be cooked in a heated pan.

original: cullī /śodhanaṃ pratīkāraḥ //🔽pīlumayo maṇir agni /garbhaḥ suvarcalā /mūla /granthiḥ sūtra /granthir vā picu /pariveṣṭito mukhyād agni /dhūma /utsargaḥ //E
analyzed: pīlu mayaḥ maṇiḥ agni garbhaḥ suvarcalā mūla granthiḥ sūtra granthiḥ vā picu pariveṣṭitaḥ mukhyāt agni dhūma autsargaḥ eva
translated: The purification of the hearth is the remedy.🔽A gem made of Pīlu wood, containing fire, a knot of Suvarcalā root, or a knot of thread, wrapped in cotton, emits fire and smoke from the main part.

analyzed: kuśa āmra phala taila siktaḥ agniḥ varṣa pravāteṣu jvalati
translated: Fire sprinkled with Pīlu fruit oil burns in heavy rain and strong winds.

analyzed: samudraphenakaḥ taila yuktaḥ ambhasi plavamānaḥ jvalati
translated: Sea foam mixed with oil burns while floating in water.

original: plavamānānām asthiṣu kalmāṣa /veṇunā nirmathitoagnir naudakena śāmyati /
analyzed: plavamānānām asthiṣu kalmāṣa veṇunā nirmathitaḥ agniḥ na audakena śāmyati
translated: Fire churned from the bones of floating animals with a spotted bamboo stick is not extinguished by water.

original: udakena jvalati //🔽śastra /hatasya śūla /protasya vā puruṣasya vāma /pārśva /parśuka /asthiṣu
analyzed: udakena jvalati  śastra hatasya śūla protasya vā puruṣasya vāma pārśva parśukā asthiṣu
translated: It burns with water.🔽In the bones of the left ribs and hips of a man killed by a weapon or impaled on a stake,

original: kalmāṣa /veṇunā nirmathitoagniḥ striyāḥ puruṣasya vāasthiṣu manuṣya /parśukayā nirmathitoagnir
analyzed: kalmāṣa veṇunā nirmathitaḥ agniḥ striyāḥ puruṣasya vā asthiṣu manuṣya parśukayā nirmathitaḥ agniḥ
translated: fire churned with a spotted bamboo stick, or fire churned with a human hip bone in the bones of a woman or man,

original: yatra trir apasavyaṃ gacchati na caatraanyoagnir jvalati //
analyzed: yatra tris apasavyam gacchati na ca atra anyaḥ agniḥ jvalati
translated: where it goes counterclockwise three times and no other fire burns there.

analyzed: cuccundarī khañjarīṭaḥ khārakīṭaḥ ca piṣyate
translated: The excrement of a chuchundari, a khandariṭa, and a khārikīṭa are ground up.

analyzed: aśva mūtreṇa saṃsṛṣṭāḥ nigalānām tu bhañjanam
translated: Mixed with horse urine, it breaks the fetters.

analyzed: ayaskāntaḥ vā pāṣāṇaḥ kulīra dardura khāra kīṭa vasā pradehena dviguṇaḥ
translated: Or a magnet stone, doubled with an ointment of the fat of a kūrīra, a dardura, and a khārikīṭa.

analyzed: nāraka garbhaḥ kaṅka bhāsa pārśva autpala audaka piṣṭaḥ catuṣpada dvipadānām pāda lepaḥ
translated: The fetus of a naraka, ground with the feathers of a kankha, a bhāsa, a pārśva, and an utpala, is a foot ointment for quadrupeds and bipeds.

original: ulūka /gṛdhra /vasābhyām uṣṭra /carma /upānahāv abhyajya vaṭapattraiḥ praticchādya pañcāśad /yojanāny aśrānto gacchati //
analyzed: ulūka gṛdhra vasābhyām uṣṭra carma aupānahau abhyajya vaṭa pattraiḥ praticchādya pañcāśat yojanāni a śrāntaḥ gacchati
translated: Having anointed the soles of the feet with the fat of an owl and a vulture, and having covered them with banyan leaves, one walks fifty yojanas without fatigue.

analyzed: śyena kaṅka kāka gṛdhra haṃsa krauñca vīci rallānām majjānaḥ retāṃsi vā yojana śatāya
translated: The marrow or semen of a śyenagṛdhrakākakaukharallaghaṃsa or a krauñca is for a hundred yojanas.

analyzed: siṃha vyāghradvīpa kāka aulūkānām majjānaḥ retāṃsi vā
translated: The marrow or semen of a lion, tiger, leopard, crow, or owl.

original: sārvavarṇikāni garbha /patanāny uṣṭrikāyām abhiṣūya śmaśāne preta /śiśūn vā tat /samutthitaṃ medo yojana /śatāya //
analyzed: sārvavarṇikāni garbha patanāni uṣṭrikāyām abhiṣūya śmaśāne preta śiśūn vā tad samutthitam medaḥ yojana śatāya
translated: Having pressed the miscarriages of all castes into a bag, or the corpses of children of ghosts in a cremation ground, the fat produced from that is for a hundred yojanas.

analyzed: aniṣṭaiḥ adbhuta autpātaiḥ parasya audvegam ācaret
translated: One should cause alarm to the enemy with inauspicious and wondrous portents.

analyzed: ārājyāya eti nirvādaḥ samānaḥ kopaḥ ucyate
translated: The same is said of anger, which is called kopa.

analyzed: pralambhanam
translated: Seduction.

analyzed: tatra bhaiṣajya mantra yogaḥ
translated: Therein, the use of medicinal mantras and yoga.

analyzed: mārjāra auṣṭra vṛka varāha śva avidvāgulī naptṛkā kaulūkānām anyeṣām
translated: Of cats, camels, wolves, boars, dogs, sheep, two-toed ungulates, owls, crows, and other

original: vā niśā /carāṇāṃ sattvānām ekasya dvayor bahūnāṃ vā dakṣiṇāni vāmāni caakṣīṇi gṛhītvā
analyzed: vā niśā carāṇām sattvānām ekasya dvayoḥ bahūnām vā dakṣiṇāni vāmāni ca akṣīṇi gṛhītvā
translated: nocturnal animals, one, two, or many, having taken the right and left eyes,

analyzed: dvidhā cūrṇam kārayet
translated: and having made the powder in two parts,

original: tato dakṣiṇaṃ vāmena vāmaṃ dakṣiṇena samabhyajya rātrau tamasi ca paśyati //
analyzed: tatas dakṣiṇam vāmena vāmam dakṣiṇena samabhyajya rātrau tamasi ca paśyati
translated: then the right with the left, the left with the right, having well anointed, at night in the dark one sees.
One sour, the boar's eye, the light of the sky, the kalasarpa.

analyzed: etena abhyakta nayanaḥ rātrau rūpāṇi paśyati
translated: Having anointed the eyes with this, at night one sees forms.

original: tri /rātra /upoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śastra /hatasya śūla /protasya vā puṃsaḥ śiraḥ /kapāle mṛttikāyāṃ yavān āvāsyaavikṣīreṇa secayet //
analyzed: puṣyeṇa śastra hatasya śūla protasya vā puṃsaḥ śiraḥ kapāle mṛttikāyām yavān āvāsya avi kṣīreṇa secayet
translated: Having fasted for three nights, under the Pushya constellation, in the skull of a man killed by a weapon or impaled, having sown barley in clay, one should water it with cow's milk.

analyzed: tatas yava virūḍha mālām ābadhya naṣṭa chāyā rūpaḥ carati
translated: Then, having bound the garland grown from the barley, one moves about with lost shadow and form.

original: tri /ratra /upoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śva /mārjāra /ulūka /vāgulīnāṃ dakṣiṇāni vāmāni caakṣīṇi dvidhā cūrṇaṃ kārayet //
analyzed: tris atra aupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa śva mārjāra aulūka vāgulīnām dakṣiṇāni vāmāni ca akṣīṇi dvidhā cūrṇam kārayet
translated: Having fasted for three nights, he should, under the constellation Pushya, have the right and left eyes of a dog, a cat, an owl, and a vulture ground to powder.

analyzed: tatas yathāsvam abhyakta akṣaḥ naṣṭa chāyā rūpaḥ carati
translated: Then, having anointed his eyes with one of these powders, he moves about with his shadow and form destroyed.

original: tri /rātra /upoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa puruṣa /ghātinaḥ kāṇḍakasya śalākām añjanīṃ ca kārayet //
analyzed: tri rātra aupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa puruṣa ghātinaḥ kāṇḍakasya śalākām añjanīm ca kārayet
translated: Having fasted for three nights, he should, under the constellation Pushya, have a stick and collyrium made from the body of a man who has been killed by a poisoned arrow.

analyzed: tatas anyatamena akṣi cūrṇena abhyakta akṣaḥ naṣṭa chāyā rūpaḥ carati
translated: Then, having anointed his eyes with one of these powders, he moves about with his shadow and form destroyed.

original: tri /rātra /upoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa kālāyasīm añjanīṃ śalākāṃ ca kārayet //
analyzed: tri rātra aupoṣitaḥ puṣyeṇa kālāyasīm añjanīm śalākām ca kārayet
translated: Having fasted for three nights, he should have a collyrium and a stick made of black iron.

original: tato niśā /carāṇāṃ sattvānām anyatamasya śiraḥ /kapālam añjanena pūrayitvā mṛtāyāḥ striyā yonau praveśya dāhayet //
analyzed: tatas niśā carāṇām sattvānām anyatamasya śiraḥ kapālam añjanena pūrayitvā mṛtāyāḥ striyāḥ yonau praveśya dāhayet
translated: Then, having filled the skull of a creature that moves in the night with collyrium, he should place it in the vagina of a dead woman and burn it.

original: tad añjanaṃ puṣyeṇauddhṛtya tasyām añjanyāṃ nidadhyāt //
analyzed: tat añjanam puṣyeṇa ā uddhṛtya tasyām añjanyām nidadhyāt
translated: Having extracted that collyrium under the constellation Pushya, he should place it in that collyrium container.

analyzed: tena abhyakta akṣaḥ naṣṭa chāyā rūpaḥ carati
translated: Having anointed his eyes with it, he moves about with his shadow and form destroyed.

original: yatra brāhmaṇam āhita /agniṃ dagdhaṃ dahyamānaṃ vā paśyet tatra tri /rātra /upoṣitaḥ
analyzed: yatra brāhmaṇam āhita agnim dagdham dahyamānam vā paśyet tatra tri rātra upoṣitaḥ
translated: Where he sees a Brahmin who has installed the sacred fires being burned or about to be burned, having fasted for three nights there,

original: puṣyeṇa svayaṃ /mṛtasya vāsasā prasevaṃ kṛtvā citā /bhasmanā pūrayitvā tam ābadhya
analyzed: puṣyeṇa svayam mṛtasya vāsasā prasevam kṛtvā citā bhasmanā pūrayitvā tam ābadhya
translated: If one dies by oneself under the constellation Puṣya, having made a shroud with a cloth, filled the pyre with ashes, and bound it,

analyzed: naṣṭa chāyā rūpaḥ carati
translated: he moves about with his shadow and form destroyed.

original: brāhmaṇasya preta /kārye yo gaur māryate tasyaasthi /majja /cūrṇa /pūrṇāahi /bhastrā paśūnām antar /dhānam //🔽sarpa /daṣṭasya bhasmanā pūrṇā pracalāka /bhastrā mṛgāṇām antar /dhānam //
analyzed: brāhmaṇasya pretakārye yaḥ gauḥ māryate tasya asthi majja cūrṇa pūrṇā ahi bhastrā paśūnām antardhānam  sarpa daṣṭasya bhasmanā pūrṇā pracalāka bhastrā mṛgāṇām antardhānam
translated: In the funeral rites of a Brahmin, if a cow is killed, a snake-skin filled with the powder of its bones and marrow is the means of disappearance for animals.🔽For one bitten by a snake, a snake-skin filled with ashes is the means of disappearance for deer.

analyzed: ulūka vāgulī puccha purīṣa jānu asthi cūrṇa pūrṇā ahi bhastrā pakṣiṇām antardhānam
translated: A snake-skin filled with the powder of the tail, feces, and knee bones of an owl and a vulture is the means of disappearance for birds.

analyzed: iti aṣṭau antardhāna yogaḥ
translated: Thus, there are eight methods of disappearance.

original: baliṃ vairocanaṃ vande śata /māyaṃ ca śambaram /
analyzed: balim vairocanam vande śata māyam ca śambaram
translated: I pay homage to Bali, Vairocana, and Śambara, who have a hundred illusions.

original: bhaṇḍīra /pākaṃ narakaṃ nikumbhaṃ kumbham eva ca //
analyzed: bhaṇḍīrapākam narakam nikumbham kumbham eva ca
translated: Bhāṇḍīra, Pāka, Naraka, Nikumbha, and Kumbha.

analyzed: devalam nāradam vande vande sāvarṇi gālavam
translated: I pay homage to Devala, Nārada, and I pay homage to Sāvarṇi and Gālava.

original: eteṣām anuyogena kṛtaṃ te svāpanaṃ mahat //🔽yathā svapanty ajagarāḥ svapanty api camū /khalāḥ /
analyzed: eteṣām anuyogena kṛtam te svāpanam mahat  yathā svapanti ajagarāḥ svapanti api camūkhalāḥ
translated: By the application of these, your great sleep has been accomplished.🔽Just as pythons sleep and just as the leaders of armies sleep,

original: tathā svapantu puruṣā ye ca grāme kutūhalāḥ //
analyzed: tathā svapantu puruṣāḥ ye ca grāme kutūhalāḥ
translated: in the same way, let men sleep who are curious in the village.

analyzed: bhaṇḍakānām sahasreṇa ratha nemi śatena ca
translated: With a thousand baskets and a hundred chariot wheels,

original: imaṃ gṛhaṃ pravekṣyāmi tūṣṇīm āsantu bhāṇḍakāḥ //
analyzed: imam gṛham pravekṣyāmi tūṣṇīm āsantu bhāṇḍakāḥ
translated: I will enter this house. Let the baskets remain silent.

analyzed: namaskṛtvā ca manave baddhvā śunakaphelakāḥ
translated: Having bowed to Manu and tied up the dog and the donkey,

analyzed: ye devāḥ deva lokeṣu mānuṣeṣu ca brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: The gods who are in the worlds of the gods and the Brahmins among humans,

translated: The accomplished ones who have mastered the Vedas and the ascetics who are Kaula ascetics,

analyzed: etebhyaḥ sarva siddhebhyaḥ kṛtam te svāpanam mahat
translated: For all these accomplished ones, you have performed this great sleep-inducing rite.

analyzed: atigacchanti ca mayi apagacchantu saṃhatāḥ
translated: And may they pass beyond me and disperse together.
